questions.text: What is the normal value of Arden index?
questions.solution:
The Arden ratio, the ratio of the Light peak (Lp) to dark trough (Dt) is used to determine the normalcy of the results.

An Arden ratio of 1.80 or greater is normal, 1.65 to 1.80 is subnormal, and < 1.65 is significantly subnormal.

The EOG is abnormal in:
1.Best vitelliform macular dystrophy (early stage)
2. macular dystrophy (advanced stage)
3.Pattern dystrophies (normal or modestly subnormal)
4.Retinitis pigmentosa and rod-cone dystrophies
5.Oguchi disease
6.Fundus Albipunctatus (no notable light rise with dark adaptation of 15 minutes)
7.Choroideremia
8.Gyrate atrophy
9.Diffuse choroidal atrophy
10.Hypertensive retinopathy
11.Retinal detachment
12.Silicone oil exposure during retinal detachment repair surgery, even 4 mo after removal
13.Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity
14.Desferrioxamine
15.Diabetes, worsening with the duration of diabetes
16.Retained intraocular iron particles (siderosis bulbi)
17.Progressive high myopia
18.Choroidal malignant melanoma

The EOG is normal in:
Dominantly inherited drusen of Bruch's membrane
Congenital achromatopsia
Progressive diffuse cone dystrophy
Autosomal recessive and X-linked recessive congenital stationary nyctalopia
Carotid occlusive disease
Optic nerve disease


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 540.

questions.text: What is the most typical method of retinoblastoma spread?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Optic nerve invasion
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a common cancerous tumour that develops in one or both eyes from the neurosensory retina.
  • Retinoblastoma (RB) gene has been discovered as 14 band on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q 14) and is a 'cancer suppressor' or 'antioncogenic' gene. Retinoblastoma is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the RB gene by two mutations (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis).
  • The most frequent presenting symptom is leukocoria, or a yellowish-white pupillary reflex (cat's eye appearance in amaurosis).
  • Common spread involves direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349, 350.

questions.text: Which is the universal marker of limbal epithelial stem cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. ABCG2
 
  • ABCG2 is a member of the ATP binding cassette (ABC) transporters, localizes predominantly to the plasma membrane and has been proposed as a universal and conserved marker for stem cells from a wide variety of tissues.
 
  • Currently, of the most widely accepted combination of markers for LSCs (ΔNp63α, C/EBPσ, Bmi1, ABCG2, and Notch-1) only ABCG2 and Notch-1 are expressed on the cell surface.



Reference: Joe, Aaron W, and Sonia N Yeung. “Concise review: identifying limbal stem cells: classical concepts and new challenges.” Stem cells translational medicine vol. 3,3 (2014): 318-22. doi:10.5966/sctm.2013-0137

questions.text: What one of the following is not an indication of evisceration?
questions.solution:
Malignancy is NOT an indication of Evisceration.

Indications of evisceration:
  • Endophthalmitis, Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Penetrating ocular trauma
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma
  • Blind, painful eye

Contraindications: 
  • Known or suspected intraocular malignancy
  • Phthisis bulbi and microphthalmia (relative)
 
  • Evisceration may be more difficult in cases of phthisis bulbi or microphthalmos due to a lack of sufficient scleral shell volume to adequately encase the implant. While enucleation is generally the preferred surgical choice in these patients.
 
  • Malignancy is an absolute contraindication to evisceration. An enucleation should be performed whenever managing an eye suspected or known to harbor an intraocular malignancy.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 178,179.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in higher concentrations in the vitreous humour than in the blood?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Ascorbate
 
  • As compared to human aqueous humor, vitreous humor has high concentration of ascorbate.
 
  • Vitreous vitamin C (Ascorbate) is physiologically high in the non-diabetic eye whereas it is severely impaired in the diabetic eye. The mean concentration of ascorbate in the vitreous humor is approximately 2 mM, whereas blood levels are only 50–60 μM, which is a 33- to 40-fold difference.



Reference: Park, Sung Wook et al. “Association of vitreous vitamin C depletion with diabetic macular ischemia in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.” PloS one vol. 14,6 e0218433. 19 Jun. 2019, doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0218433

questions.text: What is the eye finding seen in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Ptosis.
  • Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid, which can partially or completely cover the eye which can be seen in the left eye in the given image.
  • It can occur due to various causes, including weakness or dysfunction of the muscles responsible for lifting the eyelid.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 395.

questions.text: Given below is the image of the patient who presented with diplopia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given images shows ptosis and down & out left eye ball in the primary gaze. There are defects in all eye movements with the exception of abduction (this shows maintained lateral rectus function). Such a presentation suggests oculomotor (third) nerve palsy. Down and out eye: 3rd nerve palsy.

Option 1: Lateral rectus palsy: Shows restriction in movement of abduction of ipsilateral eye. Occurs due to Abducens nerve palsy.

Option 2: Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia: Injury to MLF. Shows normal primary gaze. There is restriction of adduction and adducting saccades of the ipsilateral eye. On attempted lateral gaze, away from the side of the lesion, the abducting eye overshoots the target (dysmetria), giving the appearance of dissociated (disconjugate) nystagmus.

Option 4: Trochlear nerve palsy: Weakness of the superior oblique muscle allows unopposed action of its direct antagonist, the inferior oblique muscle, which results in an ipsilateral hypertropia and excyclotorsion. The classic sign of unilateral fourth nerve palsy is a contralateral head tilt (an ocular torticollis). 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 927, 1228-1233.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common fungal eye  infections in HIV-positive patients ?
questions.solution:
• The most frequent fungus infection seen in HIV patients is candidemia.
  • As a significant nosocomial pathogen, Candida albicans is the most prevalent species.
  • Keratitis, conjunctivitis, and endogenous fungal endophthalmitis are all most frequently brought on by it.
 
  • Predisposing conditions include diabetes, intravenous drug use, prolonged hospitalization, history of major surgery, bacterial sepsis requiring broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics, hyperalimentation, chronic indwelling catheters, and immunosuppression secondary to organ transplantation, chemotherapy or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
 
  • Aspergillus infection is reported in immunocompetent patients without predisposing condition. HIV-AIDS is generally NOT a predisposing factor.
  • Toxoplasma and Rhinosporidium both are Protozoa.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 734, 735.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve palsy is shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. VI nerve palsy

The image shows left eye in adduction, so there is an Abduction constraint which is seen on the left eye of the patient. The abducens nerve, which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is the cause of lateral gaze palsy. 

Nerve supply of EOM: [MNEMONIC: LR6, SO4, Rest 3]
  • All extraocular muscles are supplied by oculomotor nerve except:
  • Lateral Rectus : Abducens Nerve
  • Superior Oblique : Trochlear Nerve.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 1233.

questions.text: What is the typical rabbit weight used in ophthalmology research?
questions.solution:
The usual weight of a rabbit used in an ophthalmological experiment is around 1.5 to 2.5 kgs.
  • The rabbits weigh about 1.8-2.2 kg, male, and have no anterior segment lesions in both eyes. The right eyes were selected in the research group while the left eyes were taken as normal control group.
  • After performing vitrectomy, the research eyes of rabbits were divided into three groups: Group A, injection with 24 mg/mL cross-linked sodium hyaluronate gel; Group B, injection with 40 mg/mL cross-linked sodium hyaluronate gel; Group C, injection with steriled 0.9% saline, mean normal control.


Reference: Gong, Yan et al. “Effect on rabbits' intraocular structure by cross-linked hyaluronic formations as vitreous substitute.” International journal of ophthalmology vol. 13,10 1531-1537. 18 Oct. 2020, doi:10.18240/ijo.2020.10.04

choices.text: Diminution of field vision to 10° or less in better eye
Inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 3 meters or 10 feet
Vision 3/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye
Vision 4/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye

questions.text: Which of these does the NPCB not consider to be a proper definition of blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Vision 4/60 or less with the best possible spectacle correction in the better eye

Definition of Blindness as per NPCB (2017):
 
  1. Presenting distance visual acuity less than 3/60 (20/400) [Snellen’s]/ counting fingers at a distance of 3 metres in the better eye (OR)
  2. Limitation of field of vision to be less than 10 degree from centre of fixation.

Other definitions of Blindness:
 
  • Economic blindness: VA <6/60 to 3/60 in better eye.
  • Social blindness: VA <3/60 to 1/60 in better eye.
  • Legal/Manifest blindness: VA <1/60 to Perception of light (PL) in better eye.
  • Total/Absolute blindness: No PL (PL negative)


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 495, 496.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic procedures is not performed in a dilated pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Gonioscopy
 
  • Out of the following gonioscopy does not need dilation of the pupil.
  • All other procedures can be done under pupil dilatation as the angle structures cannot be properly evaluated under dilated pupil because the angle is reduced. 
  • All the anterior segment evaluation can be done without dilation but for posterior segment evaluation pupils should be dilated.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1029, 1030.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 589, 590.

choices.text: Irritation of both eyes with copious amounts of normal saline
Removal of chuna particles by double eversion of upper eyelids

questions.text: Which of the following is an immediate management strategy for a patient who gives a history of chuna falling into his eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Irritation of both eyes with copious amounts of normal saline

Immediate Phase:
  • Initial treatment of any chemical burn should begin immediately at the time and place of the injury. Because the area and duration of contact determines the extent of subsequent injury and prognosis, immediate copious irrigation with any available noncaustic fluid upon exposure is of paramount importance. Irrigation should be continued for at least 15 minutes with at least 1 L of irrigant, until the pH of the ocular surface reaches neutrality i.e. between 7.0 and 7.2.
  • Some evidence has shown a benefit when a borate buffer (Cederroth Eye Wash) is used for irrigation, compared with saline or tap water.

Acute and Reparative phase:
  • The pH should be rechecked with narrow-range pH test strips (between 6 and 8) at 15- to 30-minute intervals after stabilization to confirm that there has not been a change outside normal range. Such a change can signify the presence of a hidden particle in the eye that continues to elute chemicals onto the ocular surface.
  • A Morgan lens may be used with topical anesthesia to facilitate the irrigation process in a patient who is uncomfortable.

Ophthalmic examination: 
  • Once pH has been neutralized reliably, a complete ophthalmic examination is required to characterize the extent of the injury and plan further treatment. The initial screen should include a thorough sweep of fornices with eyelid eversion to detect and remove occult particles such as lime and plaster.
  • As discussed above, it is important to thoroughly assess the presence and degree of limbal ischemia as well as the degree of corneal epithelial defect and opacification. In eyes with chemosis, it is necessary to gently push aside chemotic conjunctiva from the limbus with a sterile ophthalmic sponge to gain good access to the limbus.
  • Fluorescein should be used to assess the status of the corneal and conjunctival epithelium, with the knowledge that fluorescein staining may be difficult to appreciate in the presence of a complete epithelial defect. Intraocular pressure (IOP) should be checked, as serious chemical burns can greatly increase or lower the pressure.
  • Examination of the rest of the eye should be attempted, although the initial exam may be limited due to the view through the cornea and patient discomfort. Finally, even in cases of purported unilateral chemical injury, the contralateral eye must still be examined carefully (including a check of the pH) in order to confirm that both eyes are not involved.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 295, 296.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient complains of persistent abdominal pain, but biochemical tests and an abdominal ultrasound show nothing abnormal. She suddenly complains of losing eyesight in both eyes after waking up from sleep. Ophthalmologist conducts examination and finds nothing. This condition is most likely because of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malingering
The given condition is most probably a case of Malingering.
 
  • Since the examination findings do not correlate with the history given by the patient for both, symptoms of the eye and GIT symptoms.
  • Malingering can be defined as the act of fabricating or exaggerating the symptoms of mental or physical disorders for a variety of 'secondary gain' motives, which may include financial compensation (often tied to fraud); avoiding school, work or military service; obtaining drugs; getting lighter criminal sentences; or simply to attract attention or sympathy.
  • Psychological evaluation, the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2) in particular, can be used to diagnose malingering.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 476, 494.

questions.text: The right lateral rectus has the following yoke muscle:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lt medial rectus.
 
  • The concept of yoke muscles in ocular movements refers to the pairs of muscles that work together to move the eyes in a coordinated manner.
  • Rotation of both eyes in the same direction is termed version. During version, the muscles of both eyes make an equal effort to rotate them to the same gaze angles (Hering’s law). These paired agonists are called yoke muscles.
  • The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction, which is the outward movement of the eye.
  • Its yoke muscle, the one that works in conjunction with it, is the medial rectus muscle of the opposite eye. 
  • The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction, which is the inward movement of the eye.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1194.

questions.text: Relative afferent papillary defect (RAPD) can be observed during damage to:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Optic nerve.
 
  • A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, is an abnormal response of the pupil to light stimulation.
  • It is typically observed during damage or dysfunction of the optic nerve, specifically the optic nerve fibers carrying the afferent (incoming) visual signals.
  • When there is a lesion or damage to the optic nerve, the affected eye will exhibit a reduced or impaired response to light compared to the unaffected eye.
  • This results in a relative difference in the pupillary response when the light is shifted from one eye to the other (Swinging Flash Light Test). 
  • Unilateral optic nerve disease produces a relative afferent pupillary defect on the same side of the lesion.
  • However, Optic tract lesions tend to demonstrate a relative afferent pupillary defect in the contralateral eye.
As the side of lesion is not mentioned in the question, Therefore, the preferred answer should be Optic nerve > Optic tract.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 887, 918, 919, 922.

questions.text: A patient with a known mutation in the "Rb gene" has retinoblastoma but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following malignancies is the patient's greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Osteosarcoma 

The Rb gene (retinoblastoma gene), located in chromosome 13q14, is a tumor suppressor gene involved in regulating cell division and preventing the formation of tumors.
  • When there is a mutation or loss of function in the Rb gene, it increases the risk of developing retinoblastoma, a malignant tumor of the retina. There is a strong association between hereditary retinoblastoma and Rb gene mutations with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in the teenage and young adult years.
  • Carriers of this trait have a 10,000-fold increased risk of developing retinoblastoma (often in both eyes) compared with the general population and are at greatly increased risk of developing osteosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas.
While these options (1, 3 and 4) represent potential risks, osteosarcoma is generally considered the greatest risk for patients with Rb gene mutations.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 291.

questions.text: What is the additional layer of cilia behind the grey line?
questions.solution:
Distichiasis is a condition characterized by the presence of an extra row of cilia at the opening of the meibomian gland, which is located posterior to the grey line.

  • It is sometimes referred to as second row of eyelashes.
  • The condition can be either acquired or congenital.
  • Acquired distichiasis is caused by metaplasia and dedifferentiation of meibomian glands, typically due to chronic ocular inflammation, such as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid. It typically presents itself as crops of stunted lashes originating from meibomian gland orifices.
  • Congenital distichiasis, on the other hand, is a rare, bilateral, and hereditary condition. It is characterized by the presence of a partial or complete second row of lashes originating from or slightly behind the meibomian gland orifices.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 386.

questions.text: What is Accomodative Esotropia most commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hyperopia
 
  • Accommodative esotropia is the most common esodeviation in children and is characterized by two mechanisms simultaneously occurring in the same individual. The first mechanism is high hyperopia, with an average of +4.50 D, and the second is a tendency for larger esodeviation at near fixation. This mechanism is called a high accommodative convergence-to-accommodation (AC/A) ratio.
  • Hypermetropia/ Hyperopia is a condition caused when the parallel rays of light coming from the infinity are focused behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. This causes vision to be blurry. Some potential complications associated with hypermetropia include recurrent styes, blepharitis and chalazion, which can result from frequent rubbing of the eyes to relieve fatigue and tiredness.
  • Accommodative esotropia can occur due to excessive use of accommodation to see close objects, as there is an increased convergence and miosis in the eye. Hypermetropia carries a higher risk of developing amblyopia compared to myopia. It is also associated with a higher risk of developing primary angle closure glaucoma due the smaller size and more shallower anterior chamber.

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1212, 1213.

questions.text: Which option is Lesion producing incongruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Optic tract

Wernicke's Hemianopic Pupil (or Pupillary hemiakinesia) is a type of afferent pupillary conduction defect caused by an optic tract lesion.

  • It is a disorder of the eye's nerve pathways that run to the brain. Specifically, an optic tract lesion causes an impairment of pupillomotor fibers, which pass through the brachium of the superior colliculus before terminating in the pretectal nuclei.
  • As a result, the affected eye will have a pupillary response when the other eye is stimulated, but the response is significantly reduced. This is often accompanied by decreased or absent vision in the affected eye.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 919.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with h/o of diabetes comes to the emergency room complaining of diplopia and a squint. Upon examination, it is discovered that the secondary deviation is greater than the primary deviation. Which of the following diagnoses is more likely
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Paralytic squint
 
  • The secondary deviation (deviation when the affected eye fixates on an object) is greater than the primary deviation (deviation when the unaffected eye fixates on an object) in Incomitant squint. Incomitant quint can be Paralytic or Restrictive. So, In paralytic or restrictive squint, 2° deviation > 1° deviation.
  • Moreover, the patient is a known diabetic, so prone towards nerve palsy.
  • Based on these findings, the most appropriate answer should be Paralytic squint than restrictive squint.
  • In paralytic squint, there is paralysis or weakness of one or more extraocular muscles, causing an abnormal eye alignment. Paralytic squint is characterized by a greater secondary deviation compared to the primary deviation. Whereas in Non-paralytic or Comitant squint, Primary deviation is equal to secondary deviation.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1200.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 365, 371.

questions.text: Which nerve is affected when the movement is lost in the primary gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Abducens Nerve palsy
  • Sixth nerve (Abducens) palsy results in paralysis of Lateral rectus muscle which is the principal abductor of eyeball.
  • Therefore, Abducens nerve palsy manifests as esotropia (adduction) which almost always affects the primary position.
  • The esotropia of a sixth nerve palsy initially exhibits the typical incomitance of a paralytic strabismus; the deviation is maximized in ipsilateral horizontal gaze and smallest in opposite gaze


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1233.

questions.text: Women in their middle years who have B/L proptosis, restricted ocular motility, and chemosis. Lab investigations reveal abnormal thyroid function. What's the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

Thyroid Eye Disease (TED) is the most common cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults.
  • It has been associated with smoking and affects women five times more than men.
  • It can be present with any thyroid status, including hyperthyroid/ hypothyroid/ euthyroid and can even occur in the absence of clinical and biochemical evidence of thyroid dysfunction.
  • Clinical features can include proptosis, soft tissue involvement, lid retraction, congestion and edema of the conjunctiva and eyelids, restricted ocular ductions with diplopia, and dysthyroid optic neuropathy (DON), resulting from apical compression of the optic nerve by the swollen muscles. The most frequent symptoms are pain and discomfort and a CT scan may reveal thickening of the extra ocular muscles with sparing of the tendons.
Diagnosis:

Diagnosis of TED is based on three aspects of the disease:
(i) Clinical Features: Characteristic findings such as lid retraction combined with proptosis and limited motility are highly suggestive of TED, particularly when bilateral.
(ii) Thyroid Function and Antibody Tests: Abnormal thyroid function tests (thyroxine and TSH levels) or a history of thyroid dysfunction help confirm the diagnosis, although 10% of TED patients may be euthyroid at onset. The presence of TSH-R antibodies has high sensitivity for active Graves’ disease.
(iii) Orbital Imaging: Computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or ultrasound may help confirm the diagnosis


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1344, 1345.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of a fixed dilated pupil, which of the following is used
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pilocarpine 0.1%

Anisocoria which increases in light is differentiated on the basis of “Ocular mobility” and “Pilocarpine test”.
  • On application of Pilocarpine 0.125%, pupils constrict in Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil. In cases of Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil/ fixed dilated pupil, constriction is seen with Pilocarpine 0.1%. 
  • In case of no constriction, Pilocarpine 1% is added: Constriction implies 3rd nerve palsy whereas No constriction implies Pharmacological mydriasis. 
Note- Cocaine test ( 2-4% ) is performed in Horner's syndrome in which small pupils fail to dilate on instillation of cocaine.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 965, 966.

questions.text: Identify the given ophthalmologic finding:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Vossius ring.

  • It is commonly seen after blunt truma to the eye.
  • A circular ring of fainted or strippled opacity is seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule.
  • It is due to striking of contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens, which results in impression of the iris on the lens during trauma. The ring is always smaller than the size of the pupil.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with the following visual field deficiency. Which section of the visual pathway could be the source of his suffering?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Left occipital lobe

The image here shows visual field defect of Right sided congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with macular sparing which commonly occurs due to occlusion of Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplying anterior part of visual cortex.

Therefore, the lesion is located at Left Occipital lobe.

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS: 


If nasal fibres are effected temporal visual field is effected and vice versa. Left occipital lobe receives left temporal fibres and right nasal fibres and thus opposite visual field is effected (9).


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 325, 327.

questions.text: What can be determined about the condition from the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Left third nerve paralysis 
 
  • The patient is unable to adduct, raise, or depress the left eye and has complete left eye ptosis. 
  • The levator palpebrae superioris, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior rectus muscles, all of which are damaged in this patient, are innervated by the third cranial nerve.
  • Ptosis due to LPS muscular paralysis. 
  • Deviation- The action of lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles cause the eyeball to be turned down, out and slightly intorted. 
  • Ocular movements in all directions except outward are restricted.
  • Accommodation is completely lost due to ciliary muscle paralysis
  • Pupil is fixed and dilated due to sphincter pupillae muscle paralysis. 
  • Raising the eyelid induces crossed diplopia.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text:
33-year-old female complaining of blurred vision in the right halves of both eyes.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Left optic tract
  • Injury to the left optic tract will lead to right sided homonymous hemianopia i.e blurring of right halves of both eyes.
  • Left Optic tract contains nasal fibers of the right side and temporal fibers of the left side, which are involved in this lesion.

VISUAL FIELD DEFECTS: 




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 5th edition, Page no 325, 326.

questions.text: What statement concerning the corneal epithelium is not true?
questions.solution:
False statement about corneal epithelium is Option 1: Bowman’s membrane can regenerate
 
  • Bowman’s layer is the second layer of cornea situated deeper to the anterior epithelium. It is an acellular layer and does not regenerate following an injury.
  • Therefore, injury to bowman’s layer leads to corneal opacity.
Other options: 
 
  • Option 2: Epithelial stem cells—undifferentiated pluripotent cells that serve as an important source of new corneal epithelium—have been localized to the limbal basal epithelium
  • Option 3: Cornea is lined by nonkeratinized, nonsecretory, stratified squamous epithelium, which is four- to six-cell-layers thick (40–50 µm).
  • Option 4: Extensive apical microvilli and microplicae characterize the cell membranes of the superficial cells.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 155, 156, 158.

questions.text: Topical administration of 1% pilocarpine failed to produce pupillary constriction in a patient who had a large, dilated pupil. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Pharmacological blockade

Anisocoria which increases in light is differentiated on the basis of “Ocular mobility” and “Pilocarpine test”.
 
  • On application of Pilocarpine 0.125%, pupils constrict in Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil. In cases of Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil/ fixed dilated pupil, constriction is seen with Pilocarpine 0.1%. 
  • In case of no constriction, Pilocarpine 1% is added: Constriction implies 3rd nerve palsy whereas No constriction implies Pharmacological mydriasis. 

1% Pilocarpine is a sufficient miotic dose for any eye, but a sphincter with all its cholinergic receptor blockade by atropine or tropicamide (i.e. eye with pharmacological blockade) does not constrict with pilocarpine 1%.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 965, 966.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about oculomotor nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Miosis. Complete Oculomotor Palsy leads to Mydriasis, NOT Miosis.
 
  • Along with the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and pupillary sphincter, the oculomotor nerve innervates four extraocular muscles: the medial, superior & inferior rectus and inferior oblique. As a result, during palsy there is total ptosis (Option 2)
  • Nerve to IO carries along with it nerve fibres supplying Sphinter pupillae via Short ciliary nerves; so there is dilated pupil when the palsy is complete (mydriasis, not the miosis). This is due to Sphincter denervation.
  • The affected eye is also turned outward (laterally), typically downward (Option 3).
  • Thus, it also leads to impaired visual fixation resulting in Diplopia (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: Which of the following is a FDA approved intravitreal steroid therapy for the treatment of Diabetic macular edema?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 0.7% Dexamethasone
 
  • Ozurdex is a dexamethasone implant in a concentration of 0.7mg which is used for the treatment of macular edema due to central retinal vein occlusion.
  • The dexamethasone intravitreal implant containing 700 μg dexamethasone (Ozurdex, Allergan, Irvine, CA) in a solid polymer drug delivery system that is also approved by the FDA for treatment of diabetic macular edema, in addition to macular edema from vein occlusions and uveitis.
  • The MEAD study showed that 0.7 mg dexamethasone resulted in 22% treated eyes versus 12% sham eyes gaining 15 or more letters.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 550.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the  relay centre of an upward gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Nucleus of Cajal
 
  • The three components that make up the neural circuitry responsible for vertical gaze stabilization are the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF), the interstitial nucleus of Cajal (INC), and the posterior commissure (PC).
  • Neurons within the INC have been identified as potential players in vertical gaze retention.
  • The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) contains the premotor substrate for ipsilateral horizontal gaze.
  • The premotor substrate for vertical gaze lies primarily in the midbrain reticular formation (MRF). The rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) contains neurons for both upward and downward saccades.
  • Their axons relay to neurons in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal, which discharge in relation to vertical eye position and play a role in vertical pursuit and eye position. 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: Oculomotor nerve palsy does not cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Miosis. Complete Oculomotor Palsy leads to Mydriasis, NOT Miosis.
  • Along with the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and pupillary sphincter, the oculomotor nerve innervates four extraocular muscles: the medial, superior & inferior rectus and inferior oblique. As a result, during palsy there is total ptosis (Option 2)
  • Nerve to IO carries along with it nerve fibres supplying Sphinter pupillae via Short ciliary nerves; so there is dilated pupil when the palsy is complete (mydriasis, not the miosis). This is due to Sphincter denervation.
  • The affected eye is also turned outward (laterally), typically downward (Option 3).
  • Oculomotor nerve is the efferent nerve of pupillary/ light reflex after relay in Edinger Westphal nucleus, so its palsy leads to impaired pupillary reflex (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: Which of the following most frequently manifests as bilateral proptosis in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Leukemia

Bilateral proptosis in children is the most common presentation of leukemia.
  • The most frequent of the options given for the origin of bilateral proptosis in children is leukemic infiltration into the orbit (chloroma).
  • Orbital infiltration or mass formation can result in proptosis or diplopia.
  • In a study by Russo et al. evaluation of orbital and ocular manifestations in the recruited patients with acute childhood leukemia revealed that orbital or ocular lesions were noted more commonly in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) (66.6%) than in those with ALL (15.1%)

Reference: Sivaperumal, Pon Ramya et al. “Bilateral Proptosis in a Child: A Rare Presentation of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.” Journal of ophthalmic & vision research vol. 13,4 (2018): 511-513. doi:10.4103/jovr.jovr_2_16

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the efferent pathway of the light reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Oculomotor nerve.
 
  • The oculomotor nerve, also known as cranial nerve III, is responsible for the motor control of most eye movements, including constriction of the pupil.
  • In the efferent pathway of the light reflex, the oculomotor nerve carries signals from the brain to the muscles that control the pupil's size, causing it to constrict in response to light.
Other options:
While the optic nerve (Option 1) and retina (Option 2) are involved in the afferent pathway of the light reflex, it is the oculomotor nerve that contributes to the efferent pathway by controlling the pupil's constriction.




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 327.

questions.text: The following is a feature of thyroid ophthalmopathy:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Restriction of eye movement.
 
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy or thyroid-associated orbitopathy, is an autoimmune condition commonly associated with Graves' disease.
  • It primarily affects the soft tissues and muscles around the eyes, leading to various ocular manifestations like exophthalmos, infrequent blinking and retracted eyelids. 
  • Restriction of eye movement is a characteristic feature of thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • It is caused by inflammation and fibrosis of the extraocular muscles, which can limit the ability to move the eyes freely.
  • Enophlamos and ptosis can be seen with Horner’s syndrome: Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome leading to enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1344, 1345.

questions.text: The angle of deviation in the right eye for the given figure is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: 15°
 
  • The angle of deviation refers to the angle by which the eyes deviate from their normal alignment.
  • In the given figure, we can see the corneal reflex is visible at the pupillary margin. Therefore,  according to Hirschberg Corneal reflex test (HBCRT), the angle of deviation in the left eye is 15°.
  • This means that the left eye is deviated by 15° from its normal alignment.
  • The specific degree of deviation, in this case, is 15°.
Hirschberg test done for angle of deviation. If corneal reflex in:
  • Centre of cornea - 0 degree
  • At pupil margin- 15 degree
  • In between pupil margin and limbus - 30 degree
  • At limbus - 45 degree

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1199.

questions.text: Which of the following does Oculus Dexter refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Right eye.
 
  • Oculus Dexter is a Latin term used to refer to the Right eye.
  • "Oculus" translates to "eye,"
  • "Dexter" translates to "right" or "on the right side."
  • Oculus sinister is referred  to Left eye


Reference: Caltrider D, Gupta A, Tripathy K. Evaluation of Visual Acuity. [Updated 2024 May 1]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564307/

questions.text: What is the term of the relationship between intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Terson's syndrome.
 
  • Terson's syndrome is the term used to describe the relationship between intraocular hemorrhage and subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding that occurs in the space between the brain and the thin tissues that cover it (subarachnoid space).






Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 268.

questions.text: What is the most common primary intraorbital malignant neoplasm in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Rhabdomyosarcoma
Remember, Retinoblastoma is NOT the most common intra-orbital tumor (arising from orbit)- a very common misconception which students have. Retinoblastoma is the most common intra-ocular neoplasm (i.e arising from inside eye), but the most common intra-orbital neoplasm in children is Rhabdomyosarcoma. (Answer has been confirmed from Ophthalmology & Pediatric Oncology faculty of AIIMS, Delhi)
 
  • Most common primary intra-orbital malignant neoplasm in Children: Rhabdomyosarcoma.
Other common tumours:
  • Most common primary intra-"orbital"malignant neoplasm in children: Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Most common primary intra-"ocular" malignant neoplasm in children: Retinoblastoma.
  • Most common primary intra-orbital malignant neoplasm in Adults: Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Most common primary intra-ocular malignant neoplasm in Adults: Malignant melanoma of Choroid
NOTE - The question is asking intra"orbital" neoplasm - not intra"ocular" - hence the answer is Rhabdomyosarcoma, not Retinoblastoma. 

Reference:
1. Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1322.
2. Rao, Ajay A et al. “A clinical update and radiologic review of pediatric orbital and ocular tumors.” Journal of oncology vol. 2013 (2013): 975908. doi:10.1155/2013/975908

questions.text: Identify the usage of BETTS Classification .
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Ocular Trauma.
 
  • The `Birmingham Eye Trauma Terminology System’ (BETTS) classification system is used in the context of ocular trauma.
  • It is specifically used to classify and describe open globe injuries, which are penetrating or perforating injuries to the eye.
  • The classification system helps in standardizing the documentation and communication of ocular trauma cases.
  • The BETTS classification system aids in determining the severity and prognosis of ocular trauma cases.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 444.

choices.text: Rb 1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene
Rb 1 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13
Hereditary retinoblastoma accounts for 90 percent of all cases
Positive family history is seen in 10 percent of patients with retinoblastoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of Retinoblastoma is not true?
questions.solution:
Incorrect option is 3: Hereditary retinoblastoma accounts for 90 percent of all cases.
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. 
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene (option 1) at chromosome 13q14 (option 2).
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei. 
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma accounts for approximately 10 percent of all cases (option 3 and 4). The majority of retinoblastoma cases (about 90 percent) are non-hereditary and occur sporadical.


Reference: Essential Paediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 607.

questions.text: Which nerve is possibly involved in a person presenting with headache, lacrimation and photophobia?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of headache, lacrimation and photophobia. the nerve most likely involved is trigeminal nerve. 
 

The trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve) is primarily responsible for sensory innervation of the face, including the eyes and surrounding structures. It also plays a role in some autonomic reflexes through its association with the parasympathetic fibers that mediate lacrimation.

A person presenting with headache, lacrimation, and photophobia could be experiencing conditions like:

  • Cluster headache: Often involves activation of the trigeminal autonomic pathways, leading to lacrimation, conjunctival injection, and photophobia.
  • Trigeminal neuralgia: Though less common with these symptoms, irritation of the trigeminal nerve could present with facial pain and autonomic symptoms.
  • Migraine: Trigeminal activation is involved in the pathophysiology of migraines, which can include photophobia and sometimes lacrimation.

Other options: 
 

  1. 6th CN (Abducens nerve):

    • Controls lateral eye movement (lateral rectus muscle). Dysfunction causes diplopia, not typically photophobia or lacrimation.

  2. 4th CN (Trochlear nerve):

    • Controls the superior oblique muscle for downward and inward eye movement. Dysfunction leads to vertical diplopia, not associated with headache, lacrimation, or photophobia.

  3. 3rd CN (Oculomotor nerve):

    • Controls most extraocular muscles and parasympathetic fibers for pupil constriction. Damage might cause ptosis and photophobia (due to a dilated pupil) but is not linked to lacrimation or trigeminal-mediated headache.

Thus, involvement of the trigeminal nerve (5th CN) is the most likely cause of these symptoms.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 103-105.

choices.text: CT scan is the investigation of choice

questions.text: Which of the following is true about optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) or Marcus gun pupil phenomenon is seen in case of optic neuritis.
 
  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD):
    • This is a hallmark feature of optic neuritis. It indicates an asymmetry in the afferent visual pathway and is detected using the swinging flashlight test.

Other options:
 

  1. Most common cause is Multiple Myeloma:

    • Incorrect. The most common cause of optic neuritis is multiple sclerosis (MS), not multiple myeloma. It may also occur due to infections or autoimmune conditions.

  2. Oral steroids are treatment of choice:

    • Incorrect. Oral steroids alone are not the treatment of choice because they have been shown to increase the recurrence rate of optic neuritis. High-dose IV methylprednisolone is preferred for faster recovery of vision, though the overall visual prognosis is good even without treatment.

  3. CT scan is the investigation of choice:

    • Incorrect. The investigation of choice is MRI of the brain and orbits with contrast, as it is sensitive in detecting demyelinating lesions and optic nerve inflammation. CT scans are less sensitive for such changes.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 329-331.

questions.text: The action of the superior oblique muscle is?
questions.solution:
Intorsion is the primary and depression/abduction is the secondary/tertiary action of the Superior Oblique.



 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 349,350,351,352 .

questions.text: A patient has bilateral right-sided loss of vision. The CT revealed a space occupying lesion. Identify the site of the lesion.
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Left optic tract

The patient with an intracranial space-occupying lesion is experiencing bilateral right-sided vision loss suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.
Here, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means, the lesion affects:
  • Visual field:
    • Left eye: nasal visual field is lost
    • Right eye: temporal visual field is lost
  • Nerve fibers:
    • Left: temporal
    • Right: nasal
Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibers from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 326.

questions.text: A young boy is noted to have a golden color ring over the iris. Which of the following investigations would help you in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: (3). Serum ceruloplasmin

The young boy with a golden color ring visible over the iris may have copper deposition in Descemet’s membrane in Wilson disease, termed Kayser-Fleischer rings. The ring is best seen in Gonioscopy. Penicillamine therapy may cause the ring to disappear.
Low serum Ceruloplasmin is a diagnostic of Wilson's disease.
Another Ocular Finding seen is Anterior capsular Sunflower Cataract.


Reference: Kanski's Clinical ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page No. 267, 301.

questions.text: A 30 year old male working in a chemical factory presented with red eyes lacrimation and burning sensation. What is the first line of management in the given case?
questions.solution:
• Steps in management of chemical burns to eye:
  • Initial step involves immediate and thorough irrigation with the clean water or normal saline.
  • Topical antibiotic drops to prevent infection.
  • Steroid eye drops to decrease inflammation, neutrophil infiltration, and treat anterior uveitis. It is advised to avoid use after 2 weeks, as steroids could disrupt collagen synthesis.
  • Cycloplegics, such as atropine, to enhance comfort.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 457-458.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of proptosis in middle aged individuals?
questions.solution:
• Graves ophthalmopathy is one of the most serious ocular manifestations of Graves disease.
  • Between the ages of 25 and 50, it's the leading cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults.
  • The mechanism proposed for this is the acute precipitation of a hypothyroid state which leads to an increase in TSH secretion.
  • This leads to stimulation of the retro-orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes which have the receptor for TSH.
Reference: Parson Disease of the eye, 23rd edition, Page No 1165.

questions.text: All of the following, are actions of inferior oblique, except:
questions.solution:
Intorsion is an action of superior oblique muscle, and NOT of Inferior oblique

Actions carried out by inferior oblique are:
  1. Primary action- extorsion
  2. Secondary action-elevation
  3. Tertiary action- abduction


Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) helps to keep the image stable on the retina during head movements. What is the gain of the VOR (eye velocity/head velocity)?
questions.solution:
The gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is 1, indicating that the eye velocity matches the head velocity but in the opposite direction.

The VOR maintains stable retinal images during head movements by causing the eyes to move at the same speed but in the opposite direction of the head. When tracking an object with both eye and head movements, the VOR is suppressed to prevent the eyes from moving contrary to the head.

The VOR is a type of physiological vestibular nystagmus and serves as the basis for the caloric test. When cold water is introduced into the right ear, the patient exhibits left jerk nystagmus (with the rapid phase directed to the left). Conversely, warm water causes right jerk nystagmus (with the rapid phase directed to the right). This can be remembered using the mnemonic ‘COWS‘ (Cold Opposite, Warm Same).


 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 354,374 .

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of eye injury during welding, coupled with the accompanying image, strongly suggests the presence of a superficial foreign body in the eye. The next step in management involves removing the foreign body using a 26-gauge needle.

Overview of Foreign Bodies in the Eye:
  • Foreign bodies, typically small particles such as dust, iron, or steel, can adhere to the conjunctiva or cornea, leading to immediate discomfort and reflex blinking.
  • These particles may attach to the palpebral conjunctiva and can be dragged across the cornea, resulting in excoriation. Steel and iron fragments can directly impact the cornea, penetrating the epithelium or substantia propria.
  • Diagnostic Techniques:
  • Fluorescein staining or oblique illumination of the anesthetized eye with a slit lamp can help locate the foreign body.
Risks of Retained Foreign Bodies:
If not removed, foreign bodies can expose the cornea to pathogens from the conjunctival sac, potentially leading to ulceration and subsequent extrusion of the foreign body within slough.
While the ulcer may heal, the presence of virulent organisms can result in a spreading ulcer, which may or may not present with hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber).

questions.text: Which of the following is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus?
questions.solution:
The right lateral rectus and left medial rectus are examples of yoke muscles.

Yoke muscles, also referred to as contralateral synergists, consist of pairs of muscles from each eye that contract simultaneously during version movements. These movements, known as conjugate movements, involve the synchronous (simultaneous) and symmetric movement of both eyes in the same direction.



Examples of yoke muscle pairs include:

Right medial rectus (MR) and left lateral rectus (LR)
Right lateral rectus (LR) and left medial rectus (MR)
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
Right inferior oblique (10) and left superior rectus (SR)
Right superior rectus (SR) and left inferior oblique (10)
Right inferior rectus (IR) and left superior oblique (SO)
(Note: MR stands for medial rectus, LR for lateral rectus, SO for superior oblique, 10 for inferior oblique, SR for superior rectus, and IR for inferior rectus.)

These pairs of contralateral synergists receive equal and simultaneous innervation during version movements, in accordance with Herring's Law of Equal Innervation.

choices.text: Best corrected visual acuity of less than 1/60 in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 in the better eye

questions.text: What is the definition of blindness as per the world health organisation?
questions.solution:
As per the new definition according to the world health organisation (WHO), blindness is defined as Best corrected visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.






Reference: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/58931/WHO_PBL_94.40.pdf

questions.text: A 5 year-old child presented with complaints blurring of vision. On examination, there was a difference in visual acuity, right eye being (+5D) and left eye (+1D). What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Anisometropia is the difference in refractive error between the two eyes. Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8e • Pg 737-738

choices.text: Right medial rectus (MR) and left medial rectus (MR)
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior oblique (IO)
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
Right medial rectus (MR) and right lateral rectus (LR)

questions.text: Which among the following are the yoke muscles of levodepression?
questions.solution:
• Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles that work together to move both eyes in the same direction.

  • Levodepression = downward movement of the left eye when looking to the left.

  • To move both eyes down and left:

    • Left eye: Inferior rectus (depresses in abduction)

    • Right eye: Superior oblique (depresses in adduction)

  • These two muscles act together as a yoke pair.

Other options:

  • 1. Right MR + Left MR → Medial recti are yoke muscles for conjugate horizontal adduction (convergence), not vertical depression.

  • 2. Right SO + Left IO → Correct pairing for depression in right gaze (dextrodepression).

  • 4. Right MR + Right LR → Antagonists for horizontal movement, not yoke muscles.

    YOKE MUSCLES


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, p. 359.

questions.text: A patient complains that he cannot see the left side of both his eyes. But his central vision seems to be working fine. What is the visual field defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient cannot see the left visual field of both eyes, meaning a right-sided retrochiasmal lesion (in the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex) is likely.

  • Central vision is spared → typical of macular sparing, usually seen in occipital lobe lesions because the macular cortex has dual blood supply (posterior and middle cerebral arteries).

  • This distinguishes it from complete homonymous hemianopia.

Other options:

  • Homonymous hemianopia → Loss of left visual field in both eyes without macular sparing.

  • Quadrantanopia → Loss of one quadrant of the visual field, not half.

  • Heteronymous hemianopia → Loss of opposite halves in each eye, e.g., bitemporal hemianopia in chiasmal lesions.





Reference

1.Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition - Pg mim 198-200

2.Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition , Pg 327

choices.text: The rest of the examination including Fundus exam was unremarkable, What is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.text: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a school vision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems. Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examination including Fundus exam was unremarkable, What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Amblyopia (commonly called lazy eye) is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario:

Clinical Clues:

  • Asymptomatic child with unequal visual acuity detected on school screening

  • Normal fundus examination

  • No structural abnormalities

  • Age: Most commonly detected in children aged 3–8 years

  • Visual acuity difference (20/20 vs 20/80) is typical

    What is Amblyopia?

Amblyopia is decreased vision in one or both eyes due to abnormal visual development in early childhood, without any detectable organic cause on eye exam.

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Interocular difference of ≥2 lines on a Snellen chart (e.g., 20/20 vs 20/80).

  • Best-corrected visual acuity ≤20/30 in the affected eye.

  • Normal fundus and ocular exam.


Common causes include:

  • Strabismus (most common)

  • Anisometropia (unequal refractive error between the eyes)

  • Visual deprivation (e.g., congenital cataract or ptosis)

    Clinical Features:

    Feature Description
    Decreased contrast sensitivity Difficulty distinguishing subtle shade differences.
    Reduced visual acuity Especially under binocular testing.
    "Sunglass effect" Affected eye perceives less brightness.
    Crowding phenomenon Struggles with recognizing letters or shapes when surrounded by others.


    Treatment Options:

    Modality Mechanism Notes
    Occlusion therapy Patching the dominant eye Typically 4–6 hours/day; mainstay of treatment.
    Pharmacologic penalization Atropine 1% drops in the sound eye Blurs near vision in the normal eye, encouraging use of amblyopic eye.
    Refractive correction Glasses or contact lenses Must address any anisometropia or refractive error before starting patching.
    Vision therapy (optional) Exercises to stimulate visual development Used as adjunct, especially in older children.



    Why not the other options?

  • Retinoblastoma – Would show signs like leukocoria, strabismus, or abnormal fundus.

  • Brain lesion – Would often show bilateral signs, field defects, or neurological symptoms.

  • Congenital cataract – Would be detected earlier, and cause visible opacity on examination.


Reference:Kanskis clinical opthalmology A systematic approach 8e page no 737-738

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness, particularly in developing countries.

  • Vitamin A is essential for:

    • Maintenance of healthy corneal epithelium

    • Phototransduction (as part of rhodopsin in rods)

  • Deficiency leads to:

    • Xerophthalmia

    • Bitot's spots

    • Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia

    • Permanent blindness if untreated

      WHO Perspective:

  • WHO recognizes vitamin A deficiency as a major public health problem in underdeveloped regions.

  • Preventive supplementation programs (e.g., 6-monthly megadose Vitamin A) are in place in many countries.

    Other options:

  • Refractive error – common, but not a major cause of blindness.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) – significant in preterm infants, but less common overall.

  • Injuries – important, but not the leading preventable cause.


Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page no 540

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which of the following is the best investigation for foreign body localization?
questions.solution:
In the case of ocular trauma with suspected intraocular foreign body (IOFB)—especially metallic or high-velocity foreign bodies—CT scan is the investigation of choice.

Why CT is best:

  • High sensitivity for detecting metallic and non-metallic foreign bodies.

  • Provides detailed cross-sectional images.

  • Can detect orbital fractures, depth, and exact location of the foreign body.

  • Safe even in the presence of metallic foreign bodies.

    Why others are incorrect:

Option Reason
1. MRI Contraindicated if metallic foreign body is suspected — can move metal and worsen injury.
2. X-ray Can detect metal but not sensitive for small or non-metallic foreign bodies; no depth info.
3. B-scan USG Useful but contraindicated if globe rupture is suspected; also less accurate than CT.

Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 22nd edition page no 394-39

choices.text: It is called as pin cushion effect

questions.text: After using eyeglasses, a patient complains of impaired vision, which gradually gets worse in both meridians. Which of the following statements regarding this ailment is not true ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Cylindrical lens increases the distortion.

Cylindrical lenses (Option 4) are typically used to correct astigmatism, not to increase distortion.

Other options:
  • The condition described in the clinical scenario is consistent with the phenomenon known as "pincushion distortion (Option 1).
  • "Pincushion distortion is commonly observed when using convex lenses, which is thicker at the center and thinner at the edges. (Option 2).
  • It causes a gradual worsening of vision in both meridians.
  • Aniseikonia (Option 3): Condition where there is a difference in the perceived size or shape of objects between the two eyes. Pincushion distortion can cause aniseikonia and result in impaired vision.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 48, 49.

questions.text: Which of the following locations is affected by a lesion that results in a keyhole-shaped visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Lateral geniculate body
 
  • Lesions involving the lateral geniculate body are frequently associated with visual field abnormalities that resemble Keyholes.
  • The coloboma of the iris can be observed if the question just asks about a keyhole-shaped defect and not a visual field defect.

Keyhole shaped defects:
  • Keyhole shape visual field defect: lesion at Lateral Geniculate Body
  • Keyhole vision with macular sparring: lesion at Occipital lobe.
  • Keyhole shape defect: Coloboma of Iris.





Reference: Luco, C et al. “Visual field defects in vascular lesions of the lateral geniculate body.” Journal of neurology, neurosurgery, and psychiatry vol. 55,1 (1992): 12-5. doi:10.1136/jnnp.55.1.12. URL: https://jnnp.bmj.com/content/55/1/12

questions.text: What angle does the largest letter in the Snellen chart subtend on the eye of someone reading it at a distance of 6 metres?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 50 minutes
 
  • The largest letter on the Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes when viewed from a distance of 60 meters.
  • Visual acuity refers to the eye's spatial resolution or its capacity to distinguish between two points.
  • The Snellen chart is utilized for assessing visual acuity. On this chart, the letters decrease in size as you move downward, and they should be read at distances of 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5, and 4 meters, respectively. At these distances, the letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Thus, the largest letter visible at 60 meters subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.

Visual acuity of the largest letter is 6/60. The minimum angle of resolution( MAR) at 60 meteres =1 minute. The MAR at 6 meters will be 60/6=10minutes.
Therefore, The angle subtended by the letter: 5x10=50 minutes.






Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: These eyeglasses are worn for:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bifocal glasses. Bifocal glasses are most commonly used for presbyopic individuals who have difficulty in both near and far vision. Presbyopia is an age related defect of vision caused due to decreased power of accommodation.
  • Executive bifocals are used for pediatric pseudophakia.
  • It is rarely used in Aphakia.
  • The image shows straight bifocals which are used in presbyopia.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
In the given image, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina, seen in myopia.

This phenomena occurs due to either increase in the power of the lens or due to lengthening of the eyeball.
Hence, the image is formed in front of the retina.
The defect is corrected by using a Concave lens.

questions.text: Which area of the eye makes up the most of the eye's refractive power?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anterior surface of cornea
 
  • The anterior surface of the cornea has an essentially spherical shape with a typical 8 mm radius of curvature. About two thirds of the eye's refractive power comes from this area.
  • Approximately two-thirds of refraction occurs at the air–tear–corneal interface, which generally parallels the anterior surface of the cornea.
  • Since the move from the air into the cornea is where the light undergoes the most change in index of refraction, the majority of that refraction in the eye occurs there.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 54, 77.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions does the image in question represent?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

The given case appears to be of Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia(INO), which is a  conjugate lateral gaze abnormality that causes adduction dysfunction in the afflicted eye.
  • INO occurs due to injury to the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF), between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus of the oculomotor nerve, interrupts transmission of neural impulses to the ipsilateral medial rectus muscle 
  • The afflicted eye does not adduct when an attempt is made to stare contralaterally (relative to the affected eye). However, there is nystagmus as the contralateral eye abducts.
Additionally, horizontal diplopia is brought on by the eyes' divergence.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 927, 928.

  • Radial keratotomy is no longer performed and LASIK is not the preferred choice for this particular patient. (Option 2)
  • Refractive surgery is not helpful in this age group. (Option 3)

choices.text: More common in males as compared to females
Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment
Retinal tear is less common and it is a late complication

questions.text: Which statement regarding degenerate myopia is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
 
  • Degenerative myopia, characterized by severe nearsightedness and progressive elongation of the eyeball, increases the risk of retinal detachment.
  • The stretching and thinning of the retina in degenerative myopia can lead to retinal tears or breaks, which may progress to retinal detachment if left untreated.

Other options:
  • Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia.
  • It is more common in females as compared to males. 
  • The condition has a racial predilection; it is more common in Jews and Japanese people, and most cases are of genetic origin.
  • Retinal tears are more common in degenerative myopia and can occur at any stage.

Reference: Parson’s diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 64.

choices.text: More common in males as compared to females
Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment

questions.text: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
 
  • Degenerative myopia, characterized by severe nearsightedness and progressive elongation of the eyeball, increases the risk of retinal detachment.
  • The stretching and thinning of the retina in degenerative myopia can lead to retinal tears or breaks, which may progress to retinal detachment if left untreated.

Other options:
  • Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia.
  • It is more common in females as compared to males.
  • Optic disc swelling or Pseudopapillitis is a feature of Hypermetropia, NOT Myopia.

questions.text: When reading the Snellen chart from a distance of 6 metres, what angle does the largest letter subtend on the reader's eye?
questions.solution:
For the 6/6 letter, the m inimum angle of resolution is 5 mins of arc [( 5min of arc) X 6/6 = 5mins of arc]. The largest letter on the Snellen's chart subtends an angle of 50 minutes in the eye when viewed from a distance of 6 metres i.e 60/6 x 5mins of arc = 50 mins of arc.

questions.text: Presbyopic correction in a 55-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. +2D

The treatment of Presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

Rough guide for providing presbyopic glasses in an emmetrope can be made from the age of the patient:
  • 45 years: +1 to +1.25D
  • 50 years: +1.25 to +1.75D
  • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
  • 60 years: +2.5 to +3D
Assuming age to be 55 years, +2 is the prescribed correction as we should never over-correct Presbyopia.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: An 60 year aged person's presbyopic correction power would be:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. +3D

The treatment of Presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

Rough guide for providing presbyopic glasses in an emmetrope can be made from the age of the patient:
  • 45 years: +1 to +1.25D
  • 50 years: +1.25 to +1.75D
  • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
  • 60 years: +2.5 to +3D
Assuming age to be 60 years, +3D is the prescribed correction as we should never over-correct Presbyopia.

questions.text: Which of the following prescription is an example of Simple Myopic Astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. -1 DC X 180 degree
 
  • Among the options provided, the correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC x 180 degrees. In SMA, one principal meridian is focused on the retina, while the other is positioned in front of it.
  • The prescription for glasses in cases of astigmatism includes three components: 
1. Power of the spherical component—either convex (+) or concave (-) diopter sphere (DS).
2. Power of the cylinder—either convex (+) or concave (-) diopter cylinder (DC).
3. Axis (orientation) of the cylinder.
 
  • For instance, in the prescription -1.00 DC x 180 degrees, there is no spherical component (or it is plano), meaning one meridian focuses on the retina, indicating simple astigmatism. The -1.00 DC signifies that a concave cylinder is employed to focus the myopic rays from the other meridian, with the cylinder axis oriented at 180 degrees.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: Name the following chart.

questions.text: Based on the patient's visual field investigation, determine the location of the lesion in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:

The most common intrinsic lesion is the pituitary adenoma which may promote compression of the optic chiasm causing visual disturbances. Other causes include third ventricular gliomas and craniopharyngioma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old guy had LASIK surgery to correct his myopia. What is the most effective way to test power?
questions.solution:
The best method to check for power with previous corneal refractive surgery is HAIGIS-L.

These options are various formulas used for calculation of power of IOL in various situations.
 
  • HAIGIS-L is used in post-LASIK/ PRK patients.
  • SRK-1 is used in case of normal axial length of eyeball.
  • SRK-2/T is used in case of longer eyeball than normal.

questions.text: What changes in the image can be seen as the objective lens' numerical aperture is increased?
questions.solution:
If the numerical aperture of objective lens is increased, the resolution of image gets increased.

Numerical aperture determines the resolving power of an objective, but the total resolution of a microscope system is also dependent upon the numerical aperture of the substage condenser. The higher the numerical aperture of the total system, the better the resolution.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10.

questions.text: A patient presented with head tilt to the left. On straightening, it leads to right hypotropia. On dextroversion and right head tilt, his right hypotropia seems to worsen. Paralysis of which among the following muscles is likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Using the park 3 step, since the patient has right eye hypotropia-

Step 1- The paralytic muscles are RSR, RIO, LIR, LSO

Step 2- Hypotropia increases on right gaze- RSR is involved in elevation of eyeball in right gaze. Similarly, LSO is involved in depression of eyeball in right gaze. 

Step 3- Since hypotropia increases on right head tilt, it leaves us with RSR. 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1224, 1231.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with a sudden and severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, with no perception of light. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflexes, fundus examination, and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could close her right eye and touch the tips of her fingers, but not her left. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this young lady who presents with sudden severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, with no perception of light and normal examination findings including pupillary reflexes, fundus and optokinetic nystagmus, who is able to touch tips of her finger with right eye closed but not with left eye closed, is functional vision loss.

Other options:
  • Option 1: Optic neuritis- ON presents with sudden painful DOV, and the pain increases on eye movements. Also ON shows abnormal light reflex like RAPD. Fundus is abnormal except Retrobulbar neuritis.
  • Option 2: AION- AION generally presents with altitudinal hemianopia. It also shows positive RAPD. Fundus shows Optic disc changes.
  • Option 3: CMV retinitis typically occurs in HIV affected patients with CD4 cell count < 50/microlitre. Fundus examination shows Cotton wool spots, Pizza pie appearance and Brushfire appearance.
Evaluating for an rAPD is very useful in the setting of functional vision loss because it is purely objective. Here the patient has normal pupillary light reflex and no significant changes in other objective tests also. Therefore, Functional vision loss is the most appropriate answer (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 704, 887, 892, 964.

questions.text: Where is Scarpa's staphyloma seen?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopia.
 
  • Scarpa's staphyloma or Posterior staphyloma is primarily seen in individuals with myopia, also known as nearsightedness.
  • Myopia is a refractive error in which the eye is unable to focus properly on distant objects, causing blurred vision.
  • In high myopia, the eyeball can elongate, leading to structural changes in the eye, including thinning and bulging of the posterior sclera.
  • Scarpa's staphyloma refers to the localized protrusion or bulging of the posterior sclera due to the elongation and stretching of the eyeball.
  • Common causes of ciliary staphyloma is end stage primary/secondary glaucoma and the most common cause for posterior/Scarpa’s staphyloma is pathological myopia.  



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 149, 150.

choices.text: Right medial rectus and Left lateral rectus
Right superior rectus and left inferior oblique
Right superior oblique and left inferior rectus
Right inferior rectus and left inferior oblique

questions.text: Which of the following is not a yoke muscles ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Right inferior rectus and left inferior oblique.
 
  • The concept of yoke muscles in ocular movements refers to the pairs of muscles that work together to move the eyes in a coordinated manner.
  • The right inferior rectus muscle primarily depresses, adducts, and extorts the eye, while the left inferior oblique muscle primarily elevates, abducts, and intorts the eye. These muscles do not function as yoke muscles since their primary actions are in different directions.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1194.

questions.text: What is Humphrey field analyser ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Automated Static Perimeter.
 
  • Humphrey visual field analyzer is an automated perimeter. 
  • They are computer-assisted machines that test visual fields by the static method.
  • Perimetry is the procedure of estimating the extent of the visual fields. 


There are 2 types of perimetry:
