questions.text: A patient with vision of 6/6, standing at a distance of 6 meters from the snellen's chart looking at the last line, makes what angle of resolution at the nodal point of his eye?
questions.solution:
• A person with 6/6 vision can resolve details on the smallest line of the Snellen chart when standing at 6 meters.
  • Each letter on the 6/6 line is designed to subtend an angle of 5 minutes of arc (5′) at the nodal point of the eye.
  • This is the standard definition of normal visual acuity, where the angular resolution of the eye is 1 minute of arc (1′) between two points, and the overall size of the smallest resolvable letter subtends 5′.

Thus, the angle subtended by the smallest line of letters (the 6/6 line) at the nodal point is 5 minutes of arc.




Reference: Parson's Diseases pf the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 84-89.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Goldmann's applanation tonometer (a) Visual field
2. Ishihara chart (b) IOP
3. Perimeter (c) Central vision
4. Pinhole (d) Color vision
questions.solution:
1. Goldmann's applanation tonometer → (b) IOP:

    • This device is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP), which is crucial for diagnosing glaucoma.

  2. Ishihara chart → (d) Color vision:

    • The Ishihara chart is used to test for color vision deficiencies, particularly red-green color blindness.

  3. Perimeter → (a) Visual field:

    • Perimetry measures the visual field, assessing peripheral and central vision, commonly used in glaucoma.

  4. Pinhole → (c) Central vision:

    • The pinhole test helps evaluate central vision by reducing refractive errors, isolating issues like uncorrected refractive errors from organic eye disease.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 343, 531, 533.

questions.text:
Identify the type of refractive error?

 
1. Myopia
2. Hypermetropia
3. Presbyopia
4. Astigmatism
questions.solution:
Answer: (4). Astigmatism

This image represents the configuration of rays refracted through a toric surface and is called Sturm’s conoid. Focal interval of Sturm refers to the distance between the two foci, B and F.
The horizontal and vertical rays of light converge at different points on the retina due to the irregular shape of the cornea or lens. This condition is known as astigmatism.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 84.

questions.text: 6y old child was found to have a power of -1D Spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees. What kind of Astigmatism does the child have?
questions.solution:
Vertical Meridian here is greater than the Horizontal meridian. , Hence this would be With the Rule Astigmatism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who is on antitubercular therapy (ATT) experiences red-green color discrimination issues. Which of the following ATT drugs is most likely responsible for this side effect?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis, leading to red-green color blindness and decreased visual acuity. The toxicity is dose-dependent and usually reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.

The mechanism involves interference with copper-containing enzymes in the optic nerve, resulting in demyelination and visual pathway impairment.

  • Rifampicin → Causes orange-red discoloration of body fluids.

  • Isoniazid → Causes peripheral neuropathy (due to pyridoxine deficiency).

  • Pyrazinamide → Causes hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complete anopia in the right eye. The lesion would be present in which specific anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
Complete anopia (total blindness) in one eye occurs when there is a lesion of the optic nerve on the same side.

Key points of visual pathway lesions:

  • Optic nerve lesion: Complete blindness in the affected eye.

  • Optic chiasma lesion (central): Bitemporal hemianopia (loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes).

  • Optic tract lesion: Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (same side of visual field lost in both eyes).

  • Optic radiation lesion: Contralateral homonymous quadrantanopia (partial visual field loss).

Since the patient has total loss of vision in the right eye, the lesion must be in the right optic nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of third cranial nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
• Intorsion is carried out by superior oblique muscle supplied by 4th cranial nerve while extortion is carried out by inferior oblique which is supplied by 3rd nerve .



Reference: Bruce BB, Biousse V, Newman NJ. Third nerve palsies. Semin Neurol. 2007 Jul;27(3):257-68. doi: 10.1055/s-2007-979681. PMID: 17577867.

questions.text:
A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below.




What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown in image is Bitemporal Hemianopia.(no temporal field of vision on both sides)

Bitemporal Hemianopia 
Hemianopia (or hemianopsia) refers to the loss of vision in half of the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia specifically denotes a loss of vision in the temporal halves of the visual fields of both eyes, typically caused by lesions affecting the optic chiasma.
The most frequent cause of bitemporal hemianopia is pituitary gland tumors. Other potential causes include suprasellar aneurysms,  suprasellar tumors such as craniopharyngioma.

Pathophysiology:
Damage to the central portion of the optic chiasm impacts the fibers that cross from the nasal retinas of each eye while leaving the uncrossed fibers from the temporal retinas unaffected. This results in the loss of vision confined to the temporal visual fields of both eyes, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
It is also referred to as heteronymous hemianopia, highlighting that the visual field loss in each eye occurs in non-overlapping areas.

questions.text: A male patient complained of visual disturbances. On examination, the light reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present. what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient shows:

    • Absent pupillary light reflex

    • Preserved accommodation reflex

  • This is the hallmark of Argyll Robertson pupil, classically associated with neurosyphilis.

  • Pathophysiology: Lesion in the pretectal area of the midbrain disrupts the light reflex pathway but spares the accommodation pathway.

    Remember like this, 

Other options:

  • Papilledema → Swelling of optic disc; light reflex may be sluggish but accommodation is not selectively preserved.

  • Horner’s syndrome → Miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis; light and accommodation reflexes usually preserved.

  • Optic neuritis → Pupillary light reflex is reduced or absent, but usually both light and accommodation are affected.



Reference

1.Harrisons Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition - Pg 2659

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertical diplopia upon climbing downstairs. On examination, he tilts his head on his shoulder while going downstairs. Which is the cranial nerve involved?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with:

    • Vertical diplopia, worse when looking downwards (e.g., climbing downstairs)

    • Compensatory head tilt toward the shoulder on the affected side

  • These are classic features of superior oblique (SO) palsy, which is innervated by cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve).

  • The head tilt minimizes diplopia by aligning the eyes correctly.

Other options:

  • Cranial nerve III (oculomotor) → Affects most extraocular muscles; presents with ptosis, “down and out” eye, pupil involvement.

  • Cranial nerve VI (abducens) → Lateral rectus palsy → horizontal diplopia, worse on looking toward the affected side.

  • Cranial nerve VII (facial) → Controls facial muscles; no effect on eye movements.


Reference
Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition - Page no: 357

questions.text: Which is the drug of choice for refractive testing in a child with squint?
questions.solution:
• Refractive testing in children requires cycloplegia (paralysis of accommodation) to accurately measure refractive errors, especially in cases of strabismus (squint).

  • Cyclopentolate 1% is preferred because:

    • Rapid onset

    • Shorter duration of action compared to atropine

    • Adequate cycloplegia for refraction without prolonged mydriasis

  • Used routinely for cycloplegic refraction in children.

Other options:

  • 1% Atropine → Strong cycloplegic, long-acting (7–14 days), mainly used therapeutically, not routine refraction.

  • Tropicamide → Short-acting mydriatic, insufficient cycloplegia for accurate refraction in children.

  • Homatropine → Intermediate-acting cycloplegic, less commonly used than cyclopentolate for refraction



Reference:
Kanski's Clinical opthalmology:A systematic Approach,8e,pg- 162

questions.text: A patient with corneal scar has a visual acuity of 6/36, which improves to 6/18 with a pinhole. The most likely reason for this is
questions.solution:
The pinhole test helps differentiate whether decreased vision is due to refractive error or organic pathology.

What does improvement with pinhole mean?

  • If vision improves with a pinhole, the cause is most likely refractive.

  • The pinhole blocks peripheral rays and allows only the central (paraxial) rays to enter, reducing the effect of irregular refraction.

    In this case:

  • Corneal scar → leads to irregular corneal surface → causes irregular astigmatism.

  • Since vision improves with a pinhole, it implies that part of the vision loss is optical (not retinal/optic nerve related).

  • Hence, irregular astigmatism is the most likely cause.

    Other options:

Option Reason it's incorrect
1. Malingering Vision typically does not improve with pinhole in malingering.
3. Cataract Pinhole may slightly improve vision, but not significantly with dense cataract.
4. Glaucoma It affects visual fields and optic nerve; pinhole has no benefit here.


Pinhole improves vision → think refractive error like astigmatism or early cataract (if mild).
No improvement → consider retinal/optic nerve pathology or media opacity.

Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page no 68

questions.text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.solution:
In a 3-year-old child with recent onset of accommodative esotropia, the first and best line of treatment is full cycloplegic refractive correction, usually with plus (+) lenses for hypermetropia.

Key Points:

  • Accommodative esotropia is most often due to uncorrected hypermetropia.

  • The child uses accommodation to focus, which triggers convergence due to the accommodative-convergence reflex, leading to esotropia.

  • Giving full hyperopic correction relaxes accommodation and reduces convergence, thus correcting the esotropia.

    Explanation of Other Options:

  • 1. Orthoptic exercise:
    These are mainly useful in older children or adults with convergence insufficiency or mild non-accommodative deviations. They are not effective in young children with accommodative esotropia.

  • 2. Surgery:
    Indicated only when refractive correction fails to completely eliminate the deviation (i.e., partially accommodative esotropia) or in non-accommodative types. It is not the first line in purely accommodative esotropia.

  • 4. Relieving prism:
    Used in selected cases for temporary relief, small-angle deviations, or to assess fusion potential, but not definitive treatment in accommodative esotropia.



Reference:Kanskis clinical opthalmology A systematic approach 8e page no 151-152

questions.text: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's vision?
questions.solution:
The child in the case has myopia (nearsightedness). 

What happens in Myopia?

  • The eyeball is longer than normal (axial myopia) or the cornea has excessive curvature.

  • Incoming light rays from distant objects are focused in front of the retina instead of directly on it.

  • As a result, distant vision is blurred, while near vision remains relatively clear.

    Clinical Clues in the Case

  • Reading book too closely → suggests near vision is clear, distance vision is poor.

  • Narrowing the eyes/squinting → increases depth of focus and temporarily sharpens vision.

  • Confirmed as myopia on exam.

    Correction Principle

  • To correct myopia, we need to diverge incoming parallel rays before they enter the eye, so that the image focuses on the retina instead of in front of it.

  • This is achieved by a concave (diverging) lens.


    Why not the other options?

  • Cylindrical lens → Used for astigmatism (irregular curvature of cornea/lens), not myopia.

  • Convex lens → Used for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and presbyopia, where image forms behind the retina.

  • Concave + convex combination (bifocals/progressives) → Used when a patient has two refractive errors (e.g., presbyopia with myopia), not in an isolated case like this child.


Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page no 331-333

questions.text: Identify the condition show in the image given below
questions.solution:
A pterygium, or wing-shaped protrusion of conjunctiva over the cornea, is visible in the illustration.
  • Pterygium is a growth of fibrovascular tissue on the cornea and conjunctiva. It occurs in the palpebral fissure, much more often nasally than temporally, although either or both (“double” pterygium) occur.
  • Elevated whitish opacities (“islets of Vogt”) and an iron deposition line (“Stocker’s line”) may delineate the head of the pterygium on the cornea.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.

  • This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium.

Elastotic degeneration with distortion of Descemet's membrane

questions.text: • Which of the following statements regarding pterygium is correct?
questions.solution:
Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea.
The Bare sclera technique refers to the surgical removal of the pterygium without any additional tissue graft or covering. This technique has been associated with a relatively high recurrence rate ranging from 30% to 80%, making it a less preferred option for pterygium surgery.

Other options:
  • Probe test helps to differentiate pterygium from pseudopterygium. Probe test is negative in pterygium i.e Probe cannot be passed underneath the pterygium. (Option 1)
  • Pterygium is primarily associated with long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight, not infrared radiation. (Option 2) 
  • This statement describes pinguecula, not pterygium. Pinguecula is a condition characterized by yellowish conjunctival deposits that do not extend onto the cornea. It is associated with elastotic degeneration and can cause distortion of Descemet's membrane. (Option 4)


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 89-91.

questions.text: A patient with conjunctival infection, which led to corneal perforation, was positive for Gram-negative coccoid appearance on Gram stain. Further investigation showed small translucent colonies, which is oxidase positive. What could be the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Infection with Gram negative diplococci forming small translucent colonies, which is oxidase positive is indicative of Neisseria gonorrhea.
  • Most common cause of Acute purulent/ Hyperacute conjunctivitis is N. gonorrhoeae > N. meningitidis
  • Moraxella is also a gram negative, oxidase positive cocci but Moraxella catarrhalis occur more commonly in young children and may occur in institutional epidemics. Moraxella axenfield is the causative organism of Angular conjunctivitis.
  • Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter are gram negative bacilli.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not true of acute conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Cornea is NOT infiltrated with conjunctivitis.
  • These infections normally are self-limiting, lasting 7–10 days, antibiotic therapy usually speeds the resolution and lessens the severity of the disease.
  • Topical Antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment in acute bacterial conjunctivitis, not the viral conjunctivitis (Option 3).
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic with good Gram-positive coverage, such as a third- or fourth-generation fluoroquinolone, 10% sodium sulfacetamide, or trimethoprim-polymyxin, may be used for 7–10 days
  • Vision and pupils remain unaffected (Option 1 and 4).
  • So, the better answer will be Option 2.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: What causes severe conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Neisseria.
 
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacterium that can cause severe conjunctivitis known as gonococcal conjunctivitis/ hyperacute conjunctivitis.
  • It is typically transmitted through sexual contact or from an infected mother to her newborn during delivery.
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis can result in marked redness, discharge, and swelling of the conjunctiva.
  • Untreated cases may lead to peripheral corneal ulceration and eventual perforation with possible endophthalmitis. Thus, it can cause potential vision loss.
  • Staphylococcus, Streptococcus and Haemophilus cause milder forms of self limiting acute conjunctivitis. 




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text:
A female comes with H/O contact lens use comes with following. What is the diagnosis?

1 .Trachoma
2. GPC
3. Spring Cataract
4. Acute follicular conjunctivitis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: GPC.
 
  • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
  • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
  • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: What is the cause of diplopia in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Astigmatism

 
  • Image above is showing a pterygium.  The Pterygium growing on the corneal causes irregular astigmatism and horizontal flattening of cornea leading to diplopia.
  • Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It occurs as a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc.
  • A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:
    • Cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
    • Head
    • Body
  • Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism. Diplopia is rare symptom if the pterygium involves the medial rectus.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 207.

questions.text: What kind of hypersensitivity results in phlycten?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.
 
  • Phlyctens are small, white or yellowish nodules that form on the conjunctiva or cornea.
  • They are commonly associated with ocular inflammation, specifically in conditions such as phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.
  • The development of phylectens is primarily mediated by Type-4 hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Type-4 hypersensitivity or delayed-type hypersensitivity or cell-mediated hypersensitivity: Characterized by the activation of T cells and the release of cytokines.
  • In case of phlyctens, the reaction is typically triggered by an immune response to antigens derived from bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus > Mycobacterium tuberculosis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: Which of the following causes a polymorphonuclear reaction and causes acute bacterial conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2. Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Polymorphonuclear reaction is a type of immune response that involves the activation and migration of white blood cells called polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) predominantly Neutrophils, to the site of infection or inflammation.
  • Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane that covers the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids, caused by bacteria.
  • Most common cause of acute bacterial conjunctivitis is Staphylococcus aureus associated with mucopurulent discharge.
  • Moraxella is cause of chronic conjunctivitis


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not result in hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Influenza virus.
 
  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis refers to inflammation of the conjunctiva characterized by hemorrhage or bleeding in the conjunctival blood vessels.
  • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, also known as Apollo disease, was first described in Ghana in 1969. Two picornaviruses, enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24, are the usual causative agents. Less commonly, it is caused by adenovirus type 11. 
  • Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid edema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.
Influenza virus (4), while it can cause conjunctivitis, is not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 185.

questions.text: Which of these is a cause of Angular conjunctivitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Moraxella.
 
  • Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation limited to the conjunctiva and the lid margins near the angles. It is often accompanied by maceration of the surrounding skin.
  • The most common causative organism is Moraxella axenfield/ lacunata, which is responsible for the characteristic appearance of bacilli placed end to end, leading to the alternative name of diplobacillary conjunctivitis.
  • The source of infection is typically the nasal tract of healthy individuals or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 184.

questions.text: A nodule around the limbus with hyperemia of the surrounding tissue in the left eye is evident in a malnourished youngster from a low socioeconomic background, living in crowded and filthy environments. Additionally, axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy are noted in him. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis.
 
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an Inflammatory condition that affects the conjunctiva, characterized by the presence of nodules or small elevations around the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera) and hyperemia of the surrounding tissue.
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It is more common in malnourished individuals from low socioeconomic back grounds living in crowded and filthy environments.
  • Axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy may be present, especially with Mycobacterial infection indicating a systemic inflammatory response associated with phlyctenular conjunctivitis.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: Histologically, Pineguecula is best characterized by-
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Elastotic degeneration 
 
  • Pinguecula is a common non-cancerous growth of the conjunctiva, typically located on the nasal side of the eye, adjacent to the cornea.
  • It is an elevated, horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that are white to yellow in color and adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area.

Histopathologically, pingueculae are characterized by: 
 
  • Elastotic degeneration of the collagen
  • Hyalinization of the conjunctival stroma
  • Collection of basophilic elastotic fibers
  • Granular deposit
  • Non involvement of the cornea


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency associated with the image shown below:
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Bitot spots in temporal bulbar conjunctiva seen due to deficiency of vitamin A. 
 
  • They are white patches of keratinized epithelium on sclera, more commonly seen on temporal side. 
 
  • It is categorized in stage X1B of WHO grading of vitamin A deficiency. It is reversible on administration of vitamin A. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 488, 489.

choices.text: Simple excision can result in 90-95% reduction in recurrence

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the given condition?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of pterygium and it's surgical excision has high rate of recurrence therefore third statement is incorrect. Simple excision alone is associated with a high recurrence rate (up to 30-50% or more). To significantly reduce recurrence (to 5-10%), adjunctive therapies such as: Conjunctival autografting, Mitomycin C, or Amniotic membrane grafting are often required. 

Other options

Option 1 - This is a true statement. Pterygium is fibrovascular overgrowth of the subconjunctival tissue

Option 2 - Pterygium has a distinct anatomy: Head: The apex extending toward the cornea; Neck: The middle part. and Body: The broader conjunctival part. Hence, option 2 is also correc

Option 4 - Correct.  Pterygium is classified as:
  • Progressive: Actively growing, vascular, and can encroach on the visual axis.
  • Regressive: Quiescent, less vascular, and non-threatening.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 90; Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 198, 199.

questions.text:
Identify the given picture.

1. Pinguecula
2. Dermoid
3. Dermolipoma
4. Pterygium
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Dermoid

The given image represents a child with a left-sided skin tag and an ocular lesion present at the limbus, likely a limbal dermoid.
These are common congenital tumours which usually occur at the limbus.
They appear as solid white masses, firmly fixed to the cornea. Dermoid consists of collagenous connective tissue, sebaceous glands and hair, lined by epidermoid Treatment is simple excision.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 96.

questions.text: On administration of phenylephrine, the following change was noted as shown in the images below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a nodule with surrounding redness. Upon administering phenylephrine, blanching of the superficial episcleral vessels is observed, suggesting the diagnosis of nodular episcleritis.

Phenylephrine 2.5% is used to distinguish between episcleritis and scleritis. The episcleral vessels, being superficial, will blanch with phenylephrine, whereas the vessels in scleritis will not.

Episcleritis is a benign, recurrent inflammation of the episclera and the overlying Tenon‘s capsule, but not the deeper sclera. It is more common in women and often associated with rheumatoid arthritis. This condition is characterized by redness, mild ocular discomfort, and a sensation described as gritty, burning, or like a foreign body.

Episcleritis can present in two forms:

1. Simple Episcleritis: Features sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera.


2. Nodular Episcleritis: Exhibits a pink or purple flat nodule with surrounding redness, typically located 2-3 mm from the limbus. The nodule is firm, tender, and can be moved separately from the sclera, while the overlying conjunctiva moves freely.



Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compresses, and artificial tears. For recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs may be used.

Scleritis involves inflammation of the sclera itself, commonly affecting individuals aged 40-70 years, with a higher prevalence in women. It is frequently linked to underlying systemic inflammatory conditions and is characterized by moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and reduced vision.

Scleritis is classified into immune-mediated non-infectious and infectious types:

1. Immune-Mediated Non-Infectious Scleritis:

Anterior Scleritis (98% of cases):

Non-Necrotizing Scleritis (85%): Includes diffuse and nodular types.

Necrotizing Scleritis (13%):

With inflammation: Vasa-occlusive, granulomatous, surgically induced.

Without inflammation: Scleromalaciaperforans.



Posterior Scleritis (2%).



2. Infectious Scleritis.



Treatment varies based on the type of scleritis:

Non-Necrotizing Scleritis: Treated with topical steroids and systemic indomethacin.

Necrotizing Scleritis: Requires topical and oral steroids, immunosuppressive agents, and possibly surgical interventions like scleral patch grafts.

Infectious Scleritis: Managed with antimicrobial therapy and, if necessary, surgical debridement.

 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 146-149 .

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical context and image (which typically shows large cobblestone-like papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva) strongly suggest Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis (GPC). It's a chronic inflammatory condition commonly seen in:

  • Contact lens users (especially soft lenses)

  • Patients with ocular prostheses or exposed sutures

Key features of GPC:

  • Large (>1 mm) papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva

  • Itching, foreign body sensation, mucous discharge

  • Contact lens intolerance

  • History of long-term lens use with poor hygiene or overwear

    Explanation of Other Options:

  • 1. Acute trachoma
    Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, presents with follicles, pannus formation, and Arlt’s line, not typically with large papillae.

  • 3. Spring catarrh (Vernal keratoconjunctivitis)
    Occurs in young males, seasonal (spring), with intense itching, cobblestone papillae, and shield ulcers, but usually bilateral and with a history of atopy.

  • 4. Follicular conjunctivitis
    Seen in viral and chlamydial infections; features follicles (small, dome-shaped, pale lesions) rather than giant papillae.


Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page no 48,65

questions.text: Which of these genes is commonly indicated in congenital cataract?
questions.solution:
• The CRYAA gene encodes for crystallin alpha-A, a major structural protein in the lens.
  • Mutations in this gene can lead to lens opacity and are frequently associated with congenital cataracts.
  • Other genes such as PITX3 and PAX6 can also contribute to congenital cataracts, but CRYAA is particularly significant.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 10.

Taylan ekerolu, Hande, and Gülen Eda Utine. “Congenital Cataract and Its Genetics: The Era of Next-Generation Sequencing.” Turkish journal of ophthalmology vol. 51,2 (2021): 107-113. doi:10.4274/tjo.galenos.2020.08377. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8109038/

questions.text: High molecular weight proteins in cataractous lens seen only in humans:
questions.solution:
HM3 and HM4 are insoluble high molecular weight proteins and found in cataractous lens. 



Trivia: Zainab got AIR 1 in AIIMS May 2015. She had attempted 199 questions out of 200 - the only question she left is this one. So if you got this right - feel proud of yourself. :)

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 326 e9.

questions.text: One year after having cataract surgery, a 63-year-old patient complains of having worse eyesight. The clinical image seen below was discovered. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: After cataract.
 
  • Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. 
  • In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ which almost always has remnants of the capsule. 
  • The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.
 
Other options: 
  • UGH syndrome (B): A rare complication of cataract surgery, causing glare, blurred vision, and pigment dispersion.
  • Irvine-Gass syndrome (C): Also known as pseudophakic cystoid macular edema, it involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula after cataract surgery, leading to decreased vision and potential distortions.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 410, 411.

questions.text:
Five days after having cataract surgery, a patient with the clinical picture below presented to the eye OPD.
The management of this ailment should include everything except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and images point to a diagnosis of Post-operative endophthalmitis, a dreaded complication of cataract surgery. Antibiotics administered intravenously have no/minimal role in the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • The preferred method of treatment involves injecting intravitreal antibiotics after removing 0.2–0.3 ml of vitreous tissue to prepare smears and collect cultures.
  • Intravitreal vancomycin provides broad coverage for over 99% of Gram-positive organisms, and ceftazadime is effective against 100% of Gram-negative bacteria observed in post-operative endophthalmitis.
  • Patients presenting with visual acuity at the level of light perception (PL +ve) compared with intravitreal antibiotics alone, pars plana vitrectomy with injection of intravitreal antibiotics appeared to improve the visual outcomes.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 727, 728.

questions.text:
Nowadays, lasers are used to conduct a range of eye procedures, including cataract surgeries, with minimal incisions, fewer postoperative problems, and quicker recovery times. What is the laser's pulse duration, as depicted below, used for cataract surgery?

1. 10-15 seconds
2. 10-12 seconds
3. 10-9 seconds
4. 10-6 seconds
questions.solution:
The image shown here shows Femtosecond laser. Femtosecond laser-assisted surgery (FLACS) represents a relatively new technology that some surgeons have adopted for cataract extraction. Pulse frequency of FLACS is 10^-15.

Advantages of Femtosecond laser:

  • Femtosecond lasers have a unique ability to create discrete photodisruption of tissue with minimal collateral effects.
  • This enables very precise cutting in ocular tissues, including the cornea, the lens capsule, and the crystalline lens.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 381, 382.

questions.text: What along with ascorbate and   \(\alpha-\) tocopherol keeps lens protein in a reduced condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Glutathione 
 
  • Antioxidant enzymes and antioxidants such as ascorbate, glutathione, tocopherols, and carotenoids maintain lens proteins in the reduced state and are the primary defense mechanisms.
  • Glutathione prevents lens opacity by free radical scavenging.
  • Principle mechanism is it keeps protein thiols in the reduced state, which helps to maintain lens transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystallin aggregates.
  • Glutathione peroxidase is found in significant amounts in both epithelial cells and fibres of the lens. It provides most of the protection against oxidative damage in the lens.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 326e5, 332.

choices.text: Equal concentration of soluble and insoluble protein

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the protein content in senile cataracts is correct?
questions.solution:
More insoluble proteins and less soluble proteins are seen in lenses with senile cataract.

  • In young individuals, most of the lens proteins are soluble but with age, some crystallines become insoluble and this is an important pathology in senile cataractogenesis.
  • Below the age of 50 years, approximately 4% of lens proteins are insoluble, but by the age of 80 years, this increases to 40%–50%.
  • Up to 80% of the nuclear proteins of an aged lens may be insoluble, and most of the nuclear α-crystallin is insoluble by the age of 45 years. This contributes to the loss of lens transparency and the development of senile cataract.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 326e9.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: A diabetic patient experiences hypopyon two days after having cataract surgery. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Intravitreal antibiotics.
 
  • Hypopyon is a purulent whitish exudate consisting of inflammatory cells in the inferior part of the anterior chamber. 
  • In a diabetic patient who develops hypopyon after cataract surgery, there is a higher risk of infection due to the compromised immune response and delayed wound healing associated with diabetes. So, it warrants a severe form of intra-ocular inflammation called Endophthalmitis.
  • The next step would be to administer intravitreal antibiotics.
  • Intravitreal antibiotics are injected directly into the vitreous cavity of the eye and provide targeted treatment for intraocular infections.
  • This approach allows for a higher concentration of antibiotics to reach the infection site, providing a more effective treatment compared to eye drops alone.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 725, 727.

questions.text: What stage of cataract surgery is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the capsulorrhexis step of cataract surgery (Anterior capsulotomy).

Anterior Capsule is stained using Trypan blue and is opened up using 2 techniques—Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorrhexis (CCC) and  Can opener technique.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: A boy with long fingers and a subluxation of the lens has a slender build and lacks cystathionine synthase. Which amino acid needs to be added?
questions.solution:
Long fingers with Ectopia lentis suggests Homocystinuria in this case.
  • Vitamin B6 and cysteine supplements are used to treat it.
  • Classic homocystinuria, the most common form, results from reduced activity of cystathionine β-synthase, that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. Cystathionine undergoes trans-sulfuration with the help of Cystathionase to convert into alpha-keto butyrate and cysteine. Thus in the absence of Cystathionine beta-synthase, cysteine is not formed.
  • Cysteine is involved in the metabolism of homocysteine, it is important to supplement with cysteine in order to reduce the amount of homocysteine in the body and lower the risk of medical complications.
  • Patients are advised protein and methionine restricted diet.


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3271, 3272.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man claims that nighttime driving caused his eyes to flare. His best vision correction is 6/12. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Glare at night time could be caused by posterior capsular opacification of the lens. As pupils dilate during the night, more light enters the eye, resulting in an increase in aberrations and thus creating more glare.
  • Posterior subcapsular opacities begin at the posterior polar region then spread toward the periphery. Patients have significant glare disability because of light scattering at the nodal point of the eye.

Note- Glare at night is history clincher for posterior subcapsular cataract whereas glare during day time is for ARMD. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 334.

choices.text: Sunflower cataract is caused by Wilson's disease
Christmas tree cataract is caused by Myotonic Dystrophy

questions.text: The following is not true about the causes of cataracts
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Oil-drop cataract is caused by Diabetes.
 
  • Oil-drop cataract refers to the presence of yellowish or brownish, oil-like droplets in the lens. It is not specifically caused by diabetes.
  • The most common cause of oil-drop cataract is galactosemia.
  • In galactosemia, the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens can lead to the formation of oil-drop opacities.
  • While diabetes can contribute to the development of certain types of cataracts, such as posterior subcapsular cataracts and snowflake cataracts, it is not associated with oil-drop cataracts.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 193, 200.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes the eye condition listed below?
questions.solution:
The image here shows brownish-yellow discoloration seen in the limbic region of the cornea, which points towards Kayser-Fleischer (KF) Ring usually seen in Wilson's disease.





Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 200.

questions.text: A six-month-old infant is diagnosed with bilateral cataracts. Which of the following can be suspected by a urine test?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Galactosemia.
 
  • Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder in which the body is unable to properly metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
  • Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose into glucose, leading to its accumulation in the body.
  • Galactosemia can present with bilateral cataracts, especially in infants.
  • The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 396.

questions.text: Which of the following has a visible soemmering ring?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Lens capsule.
 
  • Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication following uncomplicated cataract surgery.
  • It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that are left behind inside the capsular bag after surgery.
Clinical features:




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 221.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a limbal scar arrives at the ophthalmology clinic with noticeably impaired close and distance vision. A large and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex are all visible on clinical examination. With corrective lens of +11D, 6/6 vision is attained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Aphakia.

Aphakia refers to the absence of the crystalline lens in the eye.

The clinical findings consistent with aphakia in this case include:
  • A limbal scar.
  • Noticeably impaired close and distance vision.
  • A large and deep anterior chamber.
  • Iridodonesis (tremulousness of the iris).
  • A dark pupillary reflex.
The patient's visual impairment is attributed to the absence of the crystalline lens, and the corrective lens compensates for the refractive error caused by aphakia.
With a corrective lens of +11D, the patient achieves 6/6 vision, indicating the need for significant refractive power compensation.
Clinical findings given above are more consistent with aphakia than posterior lens dislocation.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 37, 38.

questions.text: A patient with uniocular diplopia arrives at the emergency room. A golden crescent is visible during inspection under oblique illumination, while a black crescent is visible during examination under coaxial illumination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Ectopia lentis.
 
  • Ectopia lentis is a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position. 
  • It may be partially or fully displaced. 
The clinical findings include:
  • A golden crescent visible during inspection under oblique illumination (represents the edge of the displaced lens)
  • A black crescent visible during examination under coaxial illumination (represents a shadow cast by the displaced lens)



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 334.

questions.text: An newborn exhibits a white pupillary reflex on both sides. On slit lamp examination, a spoke-like radial opacity zone is seen around the fetal nucleus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Lamellar cataract.
 
  • In the given scenario, a newborn exhibiting a white pupillary reflex on both sides and a spoke-like radial opacity zone around the fetal nucleus on slit lamp examination suggests the presence of a congenital cataract.
  • Lamellar cataract, also known as zonular or nuclear cataract, is a type of cataract that affects the central or cortical area of the lens. It is characterized by a disc-shaped opacity within the lens. The spoke-like radial opacity zone observed is a characteristic feature of lamellar cataract.
  • The white pupillary reflex (white pupil), occurs when light entering the eye is scattered or blocked by the opacity within the lens, resulting in the white appearance of the pupil during a red reflex examination.

Types of congenital cataracts:




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 335.

questions.text: An uncomplicated phacoemulsification with IO: implantation is performed on a 60-year-old diabetic patient. On the third postoperative day, he complained of pain, blurred vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reaction. Upon examination, aqueous cells were found to be 4+, there was hypopyon in the anterior chamber with posterior synechiae, and there was retrolental flare. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Endophthalmtis.
 
  • Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation, caused due to contamination with bacteria such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is the most common.
  • Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitiritis.
  • Endophthalmitis refers to infection/inflammation of all the inner layers of eyeball except the sclera. So it presents with a wide variety of clinical features.
  • The symptoms described by the patient, such as pain, blurred vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reaction, are consistent with the clinical presentation of endophthalmitis.
  • The presence of aqueous cells (4+), hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber), posterior synechiae (adhesion between the iris and lens or cornea), and retrolental flare (inflammation in the vitreous) further support the diagnosis of endophthalmitis.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 724-726.

questions.text: Exception to the given set of associations is -
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Galactosemia - Blue dot cataract.
 
  • Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder that impairs the body's ability to metabolize galactose.
  • Galactosemia-related cataracts typically present as bilateral, symmetric, and more commonly as a "snowflake" or "oil droplet" appearance.
  • Blue dot cataract, however, is not specifically associated with galactosemia.




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 193, 200.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition:
questions.solution:
The image provided shows white, flaky material deposited on the anterior lens capsule and the pupillary margin, which is characteristic of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PXF).

Features:

  • White, dandruff-like deposits are visible on the lens capsule and around the pupil.
  • This material is pathognomonic for PXF and can cause complications such as poor pupil dilation, zonular weakness, and glaucoma.
 
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related condition that involves the deposition of fibrillary material in the anterior segment of the eye.
  • It increases the risk of secondary open-angle glaucoma and complications during cataract surgery due to zonular instability.



Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 273, 1270, 1271.

questions.text: What is the most common condition causing moderate-severe blindness in India?
questions.solution:
In India, cataract is the most common cause of moderate to severe blindness. Here's a breakdown of the listed conditions:

  1. Cataract:

    • Accounts for the majority of blindness cases in India, particularly in older adults.
    • This is due to delayed access to surgical intervention, lack of awareness, and inadequate healthcare resources in rural areas.
    • Cataract blindness is treatable, and surgery is highly effective in restoring vision.

  2. Glaucoma:

    • A significant cause of irreversible blindness but ranks lower in prevalence compared to cataract.
    • Often asymptomatic in the early stages, leading to late diagnosis and management.

  3. Refractive Error:

    • The leading cause of avoidable visual impairment, but it is not the most common cause of moderate-severe blindness.
    • Proper correction with glasses or contact lenses can address this issue.

  4. Diabetic Retinopathy:

    • Increasing in prevalence due to the rising incidence of diabetes in India.
    • However, it is not as common as cataract when considering blindness on a population scale.



Reference: National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey India 2015-2019- A summary report, NPCBVI, MoHFW, GoI. URL: npcbvi.mohfw,gov.in/writeReadData/mainlinkFile/File341.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in complicated cataract?
questions.solution:
• Complicated cataract is a cataract that develops secondary to another ocular pathology, such as uveitis, glaucoma, or retinal detachment. It typically shows:

    • Bread crumb appearance: A granular or mottled appearance of the lens cortex.
    • Polychromatic lustre: Multicolored shimmering appearance due to changes in the lens proteins.
    • Appear after uveitis: Complicated cataracts commonly develop after chronic inflammation, such as uveitis.
 

  • Krukenberg spindle, on the other hand, is a vertical spindle-shaped deposit of pigmented cells on the corneal endothelium. It is a sign of pigment dispersion syndrome or pigmentary glaucoma, not associated with complicated cataracts.




Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 239, 276.

questions.text:
A 65 year-old woman patient presented with gradual, painless, progressive vision loss. What is the diagnosis and management of this patient?

1. Immature senile cataract: phacoemulsification with IOL
2. Rosette cataract: restrict glucose intake
3. Sunflower cataract: lens extraction
4. Zonular cataract: lensectomy
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Immature senile cataract

An elderly patient with painless, progressive, gradual diminution of vision is being examined. The pupil is dilated to allow examination of the lens, which reveals wedge-shaped opacifications with an iris shadow.
Triangular spokes of opacity with their apices towards the center are indicative of a cuneiform senile cataract. 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 194.

questions.text:
A 60-year old patient with a defect in both far and near vision hasn't needed to use spectacles for near vision since the last one year. What is the mechanism involved?

  
1. Index myopia
2. Curvatural myopia
3. Axial myopia
4. Positional myopia
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Index myopia

The elderly patient with myopia and hypermetropia (likely, age-related presbyopia) is seen to have a nuclear senile cataract on slit-lamp examination. The patient has been able to read again without the aid of spectacles since last year.
  • When nuclear sclerosis is prominent, the increasing refractive index (thus, index myopia) of the crystalline lens leads to the development of a progressive myopia.
  • As the converging power of the lens increases due to the hardening and inelasticity of the lens, a previously presbyopic patient may be able to read again without the aid of spectacles.
  • This phenomenon of improvement in vision is classically described as ‘second sight.’

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 196.

choices.text: Reach in approach has lesser post operative complications
People with cataract treated in makeshift operation centers
People with Cataract are sent to higher centers

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the reach in approach according to National Programme for Control of Blindness and visual impairment?
questions.solution:
Patients with cataract are not operated in Makeshift centres but are reffered back to base hospitals (reach in approach) as this has resulted in better results and reduction in complications.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 508, 509.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cataract would be present in a patient after a blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Occurs after blunt or penetrating trauma to the eye.
Presents as a star- or flower-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex of the lens.
The trauma causes shock waves that disrupt lens fibers, leading to the rosette pattern.
It is usually unilateral, corresponding to the injured eye, and may appear weeks to months after injury.
In contrast, sunflower cataract occurs in Wilson’s disease, Christmas tree cataract in myotonic dystrophy, and sparkle cataract in diabetes or age-related changes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the observation of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy suggest amoebic keratitis caused by Acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen that exists in both a trophozoite form and a resistant cystic form, with both forms being infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia, known as acanthopodia.

Humans can acquire the infection through inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, direct exposure through traumatized skin or eyes, or by ingestion of cysts.

Acanthamoeba infections primarily present as two chronic conditions:

Acanthamoeba keratitis: This eye infection typically occurs when amebic cysts enter through abrasions in the cornea. Most cases are linked to contact lens use.

Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis: Patients with Acanthamoeba keratitis commonly present with symptoms such as photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and a sensation of a foreign body in the eye. In contact lens users, the infection can often be bilateral.

Why the others are unlikely:
Naegleria fowleri causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis from fresh water (not corneal infection), Balamuthia causes granulomatous encephalitis, and Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal disease (and liver abscess), not keratitis.

questions.text: Condition causing Difference in the refractive power between two eyes is called ?
questions.solution:
• Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal.
  • A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated.
  • Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 44-45.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes posterior capsular opacification (PCO), commonly known as after-cataract, as it occurs after cataract surgery. This is the most frequent late complication following an uncomplicated cataract procedure. It results from the proliferation of residual lens epithelial cells within the capsular bag after surgery.

The gold standard treatment for this condition is posterior capsulotomy using an Nd-Yag Laser, which has a wavelength of 1064nm and acts by photodisruption. This procedure involves creating a small opening in the cloudy posterior capsule to restore clear vision. It is a safe, non-invasive outpatient procedure that effectively resolves the visual impairment caused by PCO.

This laser is also used for peripheral iridotomy for Angle Closure Glaucoma.

Other Options:

Option A: Argon Fluoride laser is an excimer laser with a wavelength of 193 nm. It works by Photoablation, and is used in corneal refractory procedures like LASIK and PRK.

Option B: Femto Laser is an advanced laser technology used in various ophthalmic procedures. It delivers ultrashort pulses (10¹ seconds) of energy with extreme precision, allowing non-thermal, tissue-preserving cuts. It has applications in procedures like LASIK and FLACS.

Option D: Argon Green laser has a wavelength of 514 nm, it works by Photocoagulation and is commonly used in Pan retinal photocoagulation and laser trabeculopasty.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female patient has had a diabetic cataract for the past 3 months. Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Diabetic cataracts develop due to the accumulation of sorbitol and fructose within the lens.

In individuals with diabetes, elevated blood glucose levels result in increased glucose concentrations in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose is converted into sorbitol through the polyol pathway, facilitated by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is subsequently converted into fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase, though this conversion occurs at a significantly slower rate. Additionally, the polar nature of sorbitol hinders its removal from cells through diffusion.

The accumulation of sorbitol and fructose in the lens leads to osmotic stress, resulting in overhydration, hydropic changes in lens fibers, and apoptosis of the lens epithelial cells. This secondary osmotic overhydration is responsible for the development of cortical opacities, which present in a characteristic pattern, leading to the formation of snowflake cataracts.

questions.text: What are the other clinical features associated with the following type of cataract
questions.solution:
The Christmas tree cataract‘s classic presentation includes small needle-like, multicolored crystals within the deep cortex of the crystalline lens. These refractile opacities can be found in a variety of colors, including red, green (hence the name), blue, pink, and gold. Christmas tree cataract is most commonly related to an accelerated breakdown of denatured proteins induced by elevated calcium levels in the lens. Peptides and amino acids accumulate in the reticular meshwork of the lens, and cysteine is concentrated to a level at which crystallization occurs. Christmas tree cataract is most commonly associated with autosomal-dominant myotonic dystrophy.              

Disease Type of cataract
Myotonic dystrophy  Christmas tree cataract
Wilson’s disease  sunflower cataract
Diabetes mellitus  snowflake cataract
Galactosemia  oil drop cataract
Blunt trauma  rosette cataract
Atopic dermatitis  shield cataract

Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition • Page no: 240

questions.text: A 22 year old boy presented with choreoform movements on evaluation he was found to have the following eye findings. Identify the disease
questions.solution:
The given image shows Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings and sunflower cataract which is seen in Wilson's disease and the history is suggestive of neuro Wilson's.
Neuro-WD has varied presentations, classified into three movement disorder syndromes:

Dystonia (dystonic postures and choreoathethosis)
Ataxia (ataxia with postural and intentional tremors)
Parkinsonian symptoms (hypokinesia, rigidity, and resting tremors).
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition • Page no: 200

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oil drop cataract seen?
questions.solution: Oils drop cataract is seen in Galactosemia. Central posterior lens opacity with a refractive pattern resembling an oil drop. Christmas tree cataract is seen in Myotonic Dystrophy. Snow flake cataract is seen in diabetes. Sunflower cataract is seen in Wilson disease. Ref-Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition • Page no: 200

questions.text: Which of the following cataract surgery prefers suturing with nylon 10-0?
questions.solution:
• ECCE involves a large scleral or corneal incision to remove the lens nucleus.

  • Because the incision is large and non-self-sealing, sutures are required to maintain wound integrity and prevent postoperative complications.

  • Nylon 10-0 is commonly used for corneal and limbal suturing due to its fine caliber and minimal tissue reaction.

Other options:

  • FLACS (Femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery) → uses small, self-sealing incisions, usually no sutures needed.

  • Phacoemulsification → uses small 2–3 mm self-sealing incision, rarely requires suturing.

  • Manual SICS (Small incision cataract surgery) → uses a scleral tunnel, usually self-sealing; sutures are rarely needed, except in complicated cases.


Reference
1.Parsons' Diseases of the Eye - Page number 635
2.Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition ,Page number 207, 208

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with a characteristic type of cataract as seen in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This picture shows an oil-drop cataract linked to galactosemia, a disease caused by insufficient galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

  • In children, galactosemia (a metabolic disorder due to deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase) can lead to early-onset cataracts.

  • The typical cataract type is “oil droplet” cataract seen in the lens nucleus.

  • Additional features: failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and vomiting after milk intake.

Other options:

  • Diabetes → Can cause posterior subcapsular or snowflake cataracts, usually later in childhood/adolescence.

  • Myotonic dystrophy → Cataracts are typically posterior subcapsular in young adults, not infants.

  • Wilson’s disease → Kayser-Fleischer rings in cornea; cataracts are rare.


Reference :

1.Lippincott's Illustrated biochemisty 6th Edition - Pg 141
2.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 30th Edition - page 203
3.Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition - Pg. 189

questions.text: What is the dye used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
• During cataract surgery, especially dense or mature cataracts, the anterior capsule can be difficult to visualize.

  • Trypan blue selectively stains the anterior capsule, improving visibility for capsulorhexis.

  • It is safe, widely used, and provides excellent contrast without damaging intraocular structures.

Other options:

  • Rose bengal → Used for corneal epithelial defects in ocular surface disease, not lens capsule.

  • Fluorescein green → Used for corneal staining and angiography, not anterior capsule.

  • Brilliant blue → Used for internal limiting membrane (ILM) staining in vitrectomy.



Reference:
1.Parsons' Diseases of the Eye - Page number 635
2.Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition ,Page number 207, 208

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with cotton bud

questions.text: Which of the following suggests episcleritis while distinguishing it from scleritis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine.
 
  • Episcleritis and scleritis are both inflammatory conditions that affect the outer layers of the eye.
  • One characteristic that suggests episcleritis rather than scleritis is the ability of the congested vessels to blanch or fade upon instillation of a vasoconstrictor, such as 10% phenylephrine eye drops.
  • In episcleritis, the blood vessels are superficial and located in the episcleral layer, allowing them to blanch when vasoconstrictors are applied.
  • In contrast, scleritis involves deeper layers of the sclera, and the blood vessels are less likely to blanch with vasoconstrictors.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 212, 213.

questions.text: A known case of Rheumatoid arthritis attended ophthalmology OPD with the complaints as shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows scleral thinning with protusion of uveal tissue through it. In a patient of rheumatoid arthritis, this diagnosis goes in favor of Scleromalacia perforans. 
 

Scleromalacia Perforans is a severe form of scleritis that occurs primarily in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by painless thinning and perforation of the sclera, typically in the inferior quadrant of the eye.

Pathophysiology: Immune-mediated inflammation leads to thinning and weakening of the sclera, without significant initial inflammation.

Clinical Features:
  • Asymptomatic in early stages.
  • Gradual thinning of the sclera, which may eventually lead to perforation.
  • Unlike typical scleritis, pain and redness may be minimal or absent in advanced stages.
Diagnosis: Based on clinical examination, with potential imaging (e.g., ultrasound, OCT) to assess scleral thinning and perforations.

Treatment: Primarily involves managing the underlying rheumatoid arthritis with immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, methotrexate, biologics). Surgical repair may be needed for scleral perforations.

Prognosis: Early detection and treatment can slow progression, but if untreated, it may lead to severe complications, including loss of the eye.

Scleromalacia perforans is a sight-threatening complication of rheumatoid arthritis that requires prompt and aggressive management to prevent irreversible damage.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 97, 147-149, 180, 183, 257, 398.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not cause amorphous whorls like corneal deposits?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Chlorthiazide
 
  • A case of vortex keratopathy is suggested by an amorphous whorl-like corneal deposit. All of the aforementioned drugs, except chlorthiazide cause this syndrome.
  • Deposits in the inferior and central cornea in a whorl-like pattern termed cornea verticillata. Appears as fine tan or brown pigment in the epithelium. Deposits seldom affect vision
  • This is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium seen in patients on long-term treatment with medication such as Amiodarone, Chloroquine, Phenothiazines and Indomethacin. It is also seen in patients with Fabry disease and its carrier state.
  • The condition is generally asymptomatic, harmless and reversible on stopping the drug. The whorl-like pattern shows the direction of migration of corneal epithelial cells. Occasionally, the condition has been known to cause glare and surface discomfort which responds to topical lubricants.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an absolute contraindication for corneal transplantation
questions.solution:
TB meningitis is NOT an absolute contraindication for corneal transplantation

Tissue from patients exhibiting risk factors for, clinical evidence of, or physical evidence of relevant communicable disease and high-risk behavior associated with relevant communicable disease may not be suitable for transplant.

The possible contraindications include:
  • Rabies,
  • Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C,
  • Creutzfeldt-Jacob Disease,
  • Retinoblastoma,
  • Bacterial/ fungal keratitis,
  • Bacterial/ fungal endophthalmitis,
  • HIV, Herpes Simplex Virus,
  • Prion Disease,
  • Human T-Cell Lymphotrophic Virus (HTLV),
  • Ocular Adenocarcinoma,
  • Malignant Tumors of Anterior Segment,
  • Reye Syndrome,
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE)
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy,
  • Leukemias, Active disseminated lymphomas,
  • Active infectious endocarditis,
  • active septicemia, Dementia,
  • Down Syndrome,
  • Congenital Rubella,
  • Recipient of non-synthetic dura mater graft,
  • Neurological Diseases of unknown cause.

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 197.

questions.text: When there has been a hypoxic damage, the cornea swells up from the accumulation of
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Lactate
 
  • When there is hypoxic damage, the cornea can swell up, resulting in corneal edema.
  • Hypoxia refers to a lack of oxygen supply to the tissues.
  • In cases of hypoxia, anaerobic metabolism occurs in the cornea.
  • Anaerobic metabolism leads to the accumulation of lactate, a byproduct of glucose metabolism in the absence of oxygen.
  • The accumulation of lactate in the cornea disrupts osmotic balance, causing edema or swelling.
  • Corneal edema can impair vision and cause discomfort.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 232.

choices.text: Fungal hyphae are seen on KOH mount

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a feature of fungal corneal ulcer.
questions.solution:
As compared to Bacterial Ulcers, in Fungal Ulcers (of equal size) symptoms are less marked than signs.
Signs:
  • Ulcers with feathery margins
  • Hypopyon: Thick, immobile (fixed) and non-sterile
  • Immune ring of Wessely
  • Satellite lesions: Pathognomonic of Fungal keratitis
  • Marked ciliary and conjuctival congestion
Diagnosis: Clinical + KOH mount shows fungal hyphae



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175, 176.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used to diagnose corneal granular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Masson’s trichrome
  • Trichrome Masson is used in staining for Granular dystrophy, Lattice dystrophy, Avellino  dystrophy.
  • Masson’s trichrome staining shows accumulation of hyaline material in the corneal stroma and beneath the epithelium. 
  • PAS(Periodic acid Schiff) for lattice dystrophy, Macular dystrophy, Avellino dystrophy.
  • Alcian blue for Macular dystrophy
  • Congo red (under polarization) Lattice dystrophy ,Avellino dystrophy



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 262, 263.

questions.text:
The eye was photographed as shown below. It displays abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, and perforation of the cornea. All can cause hypotonic maculopathy,
with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Suprachoroidal hemorrhage.
 
  • Hypotonic maculopathy refers to the swelling and dysfunction of the macula due to chronic low intraocular pressure (IOP) less than 6 mm Hg.
  • It can occur as a complication of ocular conditions involving corneal abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, or perforation.
  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage refers to bleeding between the choroid and the sclera, typically caused by trauma or surgical complications.
  • While suprachoroidal hemorrhage can lead to elevated intraocular pressure (hypertony), it does not directly cause hypotonic maculopathy.
 
Other options:
  • The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (option D). 
  • Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of uvea (option C), penetrating injury (option B), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uraemia and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.


Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 326, 327, 610.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrived with right eye pain and watering that had been present for 36 hours. A 3 x 2 cm corneal ulcer measuring raised borders, fluffy hyphae, finger-like projections, and minor hypopyon in the cornea is discovered during examination. What organism is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Aspergillus
 
  • Pain and watering in the eye for 36 hours with presence of corneal ulcer having elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon is highly suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer.
  • Among the options, Aspergillus is the only fungus.
  • Fungal corneal ulcers are commonly caused due to injury by vegetative material. These ulcers have feathery borders. Along with this, satellite lesions, ciliary congestion and a Wessely immune ring can be seen around the ulcer.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: Usually, corneal dystrophies are:
questions.solution:
• Corneal dystrophies are noninflammatory, hereditary corneal disorders which are characterized by bilateral, nonvascularized corneal opacities.
  • They mainly affect a particular layer of the cornea.
  • They are predominantly primary corneal disease i.e not associated with any systemic disease. 


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 186.

choices.text: Topical natamycin only, no need to drain the hypopyon

questions.text: Following an eye stick injury, a farmer visited the ophthalmological emergency department with blurred vision, redness, tearing, photophobia, pain, and a feeling of a foreign body. A corneal ulcer with redness and fuzzy edges is discovered during examination. The image below depicts an eye. How are you going to handle this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case is of a Fungal Corneal Ulcer with immobile hypopyon.
  • Topical Natamycin is effective against yeasts and has a broad spectrum of activity against filamentous organisms.
  • There is no need to drain the hypopyon as white blood cells present in a hypopyon provide protection against an invading infection, thus one should never try to drain it.
  • However, a persistent hypopyon can lead to anterior synechiae and close-angle glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: What is the critical angle of the cornea-air interface?
questions.solution:
Critical angle of the air-corneal interface is 46 degrees.
  • Normally, the angle of the anterior chamber cannot be seen directly through the slit lamp due to the phenomenon of total internal reflection, where rays of light emitted from the angle structures are reflected back into the eye by the cornea.
  • This effect is caused by the angle at which these rays hit the cornea-air interface being higher than the critical angle of approximately 46°.
  • Gonioscopy works on this principle of Total internal reflection. If light from the interior of the eye strikes the cornea at an angle steeper than 46° (the critical angle), the light will exit the eye and the trabecular meshwork will be visible.



Reference: Principles of Gonioscopy, American Academy of Ophthalmology (2017), URL: https://www.aao.org/education/disease-review/principles-of-gonioscopy

questions.text: Which organismal infection is extremely virulent and may result in the perforation of a corneal ulcer within 48 hours?
questions.solution:
Eighty percent of bacterial corneal ulcers are caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Pseudomonas species.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most pathogenic ocular pathogen which can cause corneal perforation in just 72 hours.

The organism readily adheres to damaged epithelium. Stromal invasion is rapid. Pseudomonas keratitis tends to progress rapidly if inadequately treated. Most commonly, the organism produces destructive enzymes, such as protease, lipase, elastase, and exotoxin, which result in necrotic, soupy ulceration.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 222.

questions.text: What deficit is associated with circumcorneal vascularization?
questions.solution:
• Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency is manifested principally by lesions of the mucocutaneous surfaces of the mouth and skin like cheilitis, glossitis, angular stomatitis.
  • In addition, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes have been described with riboflavin deficiency.

 circumcorneal vascularization







Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2526.

questions.text: Which one of the following contains long-spaced collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cornea
 
  • Long-spaced collagen is seen in the corneal stroma in old age.
  • This is a special arrangement of collagen seen in the old age which is not seen in younger individuals and it correlates with the age related changes seen in cornea.
  • Long spaced collagen is not seen in diaphragm, tympanic membrane or basement membrane.




Reference: Hirano K, Nakamura M, Kobayashi M, Kobayashi K, Hoshino T, Awaya S. Long-spacing collagen in the human corneal stroma. Jpn J Ophthalmol. 1993;37(2):148-55. PMID: 8230839.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text: Which of the following causes an infection that results in a fungal-like lesion on the cornea?
questions.solution:
• Nocardia asteroides, a filamentous bacterium, causes keratitis that resembles corneal ulcers caused by fungus. The ulcer presents with a filamen­tous appearing border and satellite lesions.
