  • Nocardia is a Gram-positive, filamentous bacteria. Nocardia is obligatorily aerobic and variably acid-fast. On Gram staining, the filaments of these organisms are seen as branching and intertwined; some might display terminal clubs, and the filaments often fragment into bacillary and coccoid forms.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 222.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrived with right eye pain and watering that had been present for 36 hours. A 3 x 2 cm corneal ulcer measuring raised borders, fluffy hyphae, finger-like projections, and minor hypopyon in the cornea is discovered during examination. What's the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
• Pain and watering in the eye for 36 hours with presence of corneal ulcer having elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon is highly suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer.
 
  • Among the options, Aspergillus is the only fungus.
 
  • Fungal corneal ulcers are commonly caused due to injury by vegetative material. These ulcers have feathery borders. Along with this, satellite lesions, ciliary congestion and a Wessely immune ring can be seen around the ulcer.
 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: Pick the most appropriate diagnostic approach for the clinical symptom shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Serum ceruloplasmin.
 
  • Kayser–Fleischer ring is a brownish-yellow area of copper deposition that is present in the peripheral Descemet membrane. 
  • This is seen in Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) and occurs due to a deficiency of ceruloplasmin. 
  • Fleischer's rings seen in keratoconus are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination.
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin level is diagnostic of Wilson's disease.



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3236.

questions.text: Kayser-Fleischer rings (KF rings) can be observed in:
questions.solution:
KF rings are brownish-yellow discolorations seen in the limbic zone of the cornea and occur due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane. 
Amongst the given options, KF rings are characteristically seen in Wilson's disease. 

 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3236.

questions.text: The least common corneal dystrophy is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Macular dystrophy
 
  • Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic disorders that affect the cornea, the transparent front part of the eye.
  • Macular dystrophy, also known as Groenouw type II dystrophy, is one of the rarest forms of corneal dystrophy.
  • Macular dystrophy primarily affects the central portion of the cornea, known as the macula, and is characterized by the presence of small, round opacities.
  • Compared to other corneal dystrophies, macular dystrophy is relatively uncommon, making it the least common among the options listed.


 Reference: Parsons, Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 187.

choices.text: Whole eye needs to be preserved in tissue culture
Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding corneal transplantation is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count.
 
  • Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count.
  • Specular microscopy is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize and analyze the corneal endothelium, which is the innermost layer of the cornea. 
  • It provides information about the endothelial cell density, morphology, and other parameters, which are crucial in evaluating the health of the cornea for transplantation.

Other options:
  • Option 1:  In corneal transplantation, only the cornea is transplanted, not the whole eye. The cornea can be preserved using various methods, such as organ culture or cold storage.
  • Option 2:  Donor corneas can be accepted even if the donor is older than 60 years.
  • Option 4: Unlike solid organ transplants (e.g., kidney, heart), cornea being an avascular structure corneal transplantation does not typically require strict HLA (human leukocyte antigen) matching between the donor and the recipient.

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 297.
Parson’s diseases of the eye, 23rd edition, Page no 197.

questions.text: What is the characteristic finding of fungal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are pathognomonic of fungal keratitis, which is an inflammation of the cornea caused by fungal infection.

  • It is a secondary complication in which an inflamed area of the cornea is surrounded by an area of uninfected but inflamed tissue.
  • This typically occurs when a fungal infection has spread to the cornea from an adjacent area of the eyelid or eye socket.
  • This type of lesion is seen often in Aspergillus species and can lead to a decrease in vision if not treated.
Other options:- 
  • Dendritic ulcer is seen in HSV keratitis
  • Ring abscess is seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • White hypopyon seen in both bacterial and fungal corneal ulcer hence not specific 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.
Parson’s diseases of the eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: Which corneal layer contributes to keep the cornea dehydrated?
questions.solution:
Endothelium is a thin layer of cells that lines the inside of blood vessels and serves as a barrier between the bloodstream and surrounding tissues.
  • The endothelium is usually only about 5 millimeters (mm) thick. It is composed of a single layer of flat polygonal cells that are highly metabolically active. It regulates the movement of substances, regulates blood pressure.
  • It contains an "active pump" mechanism called Na+-K+-ATPase to maintain the cornea in a dehydrated state. This pump helps to regulate the water content of the eye, which helps to maintain its shape and avoid dehydration.
  • The endothelium also produces anti-inflammatory substances that reduce inflammation throughout the body.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 157.

questions.text:
In relation to the KF Ring, what is true?
A. Pathognomic of Wilson’s Disease
B. Seen in superior and inferior Descemet’s Membrane
C. Seen in all patients with Neurological involvement
D. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement
E. Disappears with Desferrioxamine
questions.solution:
True statements are:
Statement B: KF ring is seen in the superior and inferior Descemet’s membrane.
Statement C: Seen in all patients with neurological involvement. KF ring is seen in >95% patients of Wilson’s disease with Neurological involvement.

Incorrect statements:
A: Along with Wilson’s diseases, KF ring is also seen in: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), Cholestasis etc.
D: KF ring is associated with around 65% of those with hepatic involvement.
E: They disappear on treating with copper chelating agents like D-penicillamine and may reappear with progression of the disease.
Desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent




Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2549, 2615, 3236, 3237.

questions.text: What is the most common ophthalmological symptom of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
• Most common ophthalmic manifestation of COVID - 19 is follicular conjunctivitis. It is the inflammation of conjunctiva that is usually associated with viral infections. Examination shows appearance of follicles in the palpebral conjunctiva.
 
  • Severe hemorrhagic conjunctivitis and pseudomembrane formation have also manifested several days after the onset of COVID-19 systemic symptoms.



Reference: Hu K, Patel J, Swiston C, et al. Ophthalmic Manifestations of Coronavirus (COVID-19) [Updated 2024 May 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556093/

questions.text:
A patient who had just experienced vegetative matter trauma and a swollen left eye came.
Additionally, the patient had a corneal ulcer and hypopyon. The following organism is the most likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. MYCOTIC CORNEAL ULCER (Phycomycosis)
 
  • Aspergillus, Candida, and Fusarium are the most common causative agents. Injury due to vegetative material is a common cause. Injudicious use of antibiotics and steroids increases the risk of fungal infections.  A typical fungal ulcer has fingerlike expansions into the surrounding stroma beneath the intact epithelium and has a dry, greyish white appearance. 
  • The immune ring of Wessely is sterile, and there are numerous satellite lesions. Even if the ulcer is extremely small, a large, non-sterile, infectious hypopyon (pseudohypopyon) typically develops. 
  • The drug of choice for filamentous infections is Natamycin, and for Candida, it is Amphotericin B (0.15%).


Reference: Parson’s diseases of the eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: What keeps the cornea transparent?
questions.solution:
Correct option ia 3: Keratan Sulphate.
 
  • Keratan sulphate is found in the cornea and plays a critical role in maintaining corneal transparency. 
  • It is involved in the structural organization of the corneal matrix and contributes to the clarity of the cornea.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text: DOV under low-light conditions, accompanied with dry eyes and ocular surface abrasion. Which deficiency is related?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A (Retinoic acid) deficiency can cause dry eye illness. Mild deficiency causes conjunctival alterations and a severe deficiency leads to xerophthalmia
  • Night blindness/Nyctalopia or DOV under low light conditions is the earliest symptom of Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Retinoic acid formulations are applied topically and taken orally to treat this problem.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 540.

questions.text: A man who injured his eye while using a hammer and chisel to try to break a stubborn stone was sent to the hospital. Which of the following investigations would be harmful?
questions.solution:
When a patient has metallic foreign bodies or implants in their body, MRI is not advised.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan is contraindicated in cases of magnetic or magnetizable foreign bodies, but is very useful in detecting a wooden foreign body and vascular changes.
  • Computerized axial tomography (CAT) scan: The thinnest slices are used to localize a small foreign body with great accuracy. The extent of bony, soft tissue and intracranial injuries can also be assessed.
  • Ultrasonography allows the detection of most foreign bodies, as well as associated intraocular conditions such as retinal detachment, suprachoroidal haemorrhage and a perforating injury of the eye.

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 504.

questions.text: What proportion of endothelial cells are lost during the automated penetrating keratoplasty of Descemet's membrane stripping?
questions.solution:
Percentage of endothelial cell loss during Descemet 's membrane stripping in automated penetrating keratoplasty 30-40% .
  • Following DSEK/DSAEK the endothelial cell loss rate can be as high as 56% in the first year, although with standardized technique, the endothelial cell loss has been reduced to less than 35%.
  • The incidence of endothelial cell loss in donor tissue of Descemet stripping endothelial keratoplasty is nearly 35%, mainly in the central area of graft. Compared with penetrating keratoplasty, EK involves more donor-tissue manipulation including lamellar dissection and folding, which could potentially damage donor endothelium.
  • Therefore, best possible answer should be Option 3> Option 4.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 389.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Herpes Zoster keratitis?
questions.solution:
Herpes Zoster ophthalmicus commonly causes acute epithelial keratitis [i.e. punctuate epithelial keratitis and pseudo dendritic keratitis, anterior stromal keratitis, disciform (deep stromal) keratitis or endothelitis and serpiginous ulceration. However, sclero-keratitis (limbal vascular keratitis) is least common.

Other options:
Option 1: Active viral infections tend to affect the epithelium, leading to punctate epithelial keratitis and pseudo-dendrites
Option 2: It is characterized by multiple, fine, granular, coin-shaped infiltrates in the anterior stroma and may cause permanent scarring
Option 4: Disciform keratitis is a deep stromal infiltrate that develops 3–4 months after the acute phase, characterized by a central disc-shaped area of diffuse corneal edema that results from endotheliitis and anterior chamber inflammation


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 180.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to treat a fungal corneal ulcer as adjuvant therapy?
questions.solution:
Atropine helps to prevent the constriction of the ciliary muscle, which can potentially lead to complications related to inflammation of the iris, such as an increased production of connective tissue in the eye, known as posterior synechiae. It is often used in the treatment of corneal ulcer as a preventive/ adjunctive measure.
  • Control of infection is attained by the use of antifungal drugs; heat is employed to prevent stasis, encourage circulation and repair, while local rest is attained by the use of cycloplegics such as atropine.
  • Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal keratitis (Option 3).
  • Pilocarpine and Lidocaine has no role in treatment (Option 2 and 4).


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 177.

questions.text: Which of the following is not given as eye drops for corneal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Fluorometholone is a topical corticosteroid used to control ocular inflammations. It is not given as eye drops in corneal ulcer.

These infections can be tenacious, and host suppression of infection is very important,  so corticosteroid use is generally not recommended in the management of fungal keratitis. Rather it is contraindicated.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 229.

questions.text: Which symptom does not describe a corneal ulcer brought on by a fungus?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Ulcus Serpens.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. The corneal ulcer appears dry with delicate feathery finger-like extensions. 
Ulcus serpens is a hypopyon corneal ulcer caused by pneumococcus. Hence not seen in this condition.
  • Option 1: The immune ring of Wessely is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).
  • Option 2: In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon is not sterile. The fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation.
  • Option 3: A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation), as well as multiple, small satellite lesions, may be present.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

choices.text: Copper deposit in Descemet's membrane of the cornea

questions.text: The following is not a correct statement regarding Wilson's disease:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
 
  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, not an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • The deposition of copper in the basal ganglia can result in neurological manifestations, such as movement disorders, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive impairment.
  • One of the characteristic features of Wilson's disease is the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings (copper deposits accumulation in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea).
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to the rupture of Descemet's membrane.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3235, 3236.

questions.text: A frequent user of contact lenses complains of acute pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision for more than two weeks that do not improve with conventional treatment. Upon examination, it is discovered that the affected eye has a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrate and underlying epithelial abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a severe corneal infection caused by the protozoan Acanthamoeba, commonly seen in frequent contact lens users.

Key clinical features:
  • Acute pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision persisting for more than two weeks despite conventional treatment.
  • Paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrate and underlying epithelial abnormalities.
  • The presence of Stromal infiltrate in the corneal stroma is a key finding in Acanthamoeba keratitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 230, 231.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from a rural area visits the ophthalmology clinic with a 10-day history of vision problems. He describes how, around 15 days prior, vegetative stuff had fallen into his left eye. Upon inspection, a corneal ulcerative lesion with feathery borders and creamy exudates is discovered. There were a few satellite lesions as well. Which is the most likely etiological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Fusarium sp.
 
  • The given scenario with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and thick hypopyon and the microscopic findings of branched, septate hyphae suggest mycotic keratitis caused by Aspergillus or Fusarium. 
  • Fusarium species are filamentous fungi commonly found in the environment, including soil and plants.
  • They can cause a severe corneal infection known as fungal keratitis
  • Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and immunocompromised individuals. It usually is caused by filamentous septate organisms such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, or yeasts such as Candida albicans.





Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: What is the wavelength of the laser used to shape the cornea in refractive surgery (in nanometers)?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: 193 nm.
 
  • Refractive surgery procedures like LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) and PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy), use an excimer laser to reshape the cornea and correct vision problems such as nearsightedness, farsightedness, and astigmatism.
  • The excimer laser emits ultraviolet light in the range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
  • The most commonly used wavelength for an excimer laser in refractive surgery is 193 nm.
  • The argon-fluorine excimer lasers emit energy at a wavelength of 193 nm. This wavelength falls in the UV-C range of the light spectrum.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 88.

questions.text: How is Corneal sensation is measured?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Aesthesiometer.
 
  • An Aesthesiometer is a specialized instrument used to assess corneal sensation. 
  • It measures the threshold of touch or the minimum stimulus required to elicit a response from the cornea.
  • The patient is asked to indicate when they first feel the touch, and the threshold is recorded as the length of the filament required to elicit the sensation.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 279.

questions.text: Such a treatment is carried out for:
questions.solution:
• The given image demonstrates INTACS, which is done for keratoconus.
 
  • Keratoconus, also known as conical cornea, is a non-inflammatory condition affecting the axial cornea.
  • It is characterized by central or paracentral thinning and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea, which are pathognomonic features.
  • This condition is associated with defects in mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 128, 135-137.

questions.text: A fisherman with a history of trauma with a fish tail presents with pain and blurring of vision. What is the sign in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Hypopyon is the accumulation of neutrophils and fibrin that typically settles ventrally within the anterior chamber.
 
  • The white pus settled in the anterior chamber as shown in the image is the hypopyon. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 105, 110, 160, 521.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Habb's striae are horizontal breaks in descement's membrane seen in congenital glaucoma.
 

  • Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory thinning of the cornea leading to its conical protrusion. Key features include:

    1. Irregular astigmatism: Caused by distortion of the corneal surface.
    2. Munson's sign: A V-shaped indentation of the lower eyelid seen in downgaze, due to the conical shape of the cornea.
    3. Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy: A characteristic finding due to irregular corneal curvature.
 

  • Haab's striae, on the other hand, are horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane seen in congenital glaucoma, not keratoconus.




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 100, 135-137.

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with lagophthalmos. On examination the patient was found to have orbicularis oculi paresis and decreased corneal sensations. Which of the following is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi paresis, and decreased corneal sensations in this patient is Mycobacterium leprae.

  • These symptoms are consistent with the ocular manifestations of Leprosy.
  • Leprosy is caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae, which primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes.
  • Involvement of the facial nerve can lead to orbicularis oculi paresis, resulting in difficulty closing the eyelids completely (lagophthalmos).
  • The decreased corneal sensations can occur due to the neuropathy associated with leprosy.
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 5,6,68,69,73,74,78,116,378,491,519 .

questions.text:
Which dye and filter are used in the following investigation?

1. Fluorescein, green filter
2. Fluorescein, cobalt filter
3. Lissamine, green filter
4. Lissamine, cobalt filte
questions.solution:
Answer: 2. Fluorescein, cobalt filter

The image given is of a dendritic ulcer seen in herpetic keratitis.
Corneal ulcers can be detected with the help of fluorescein sodium dye and a cobalt-blue filter. The epithelial defect of the cornea appears opaque green with a cobalt blue filter.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 480, 524.

questions.text: Identify the filter used for detecting corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Corneal ulcer can be detected with fluorescein dye with cobalt filter.
The epithelial defect appears green with cobalt blue filter.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 101, 107.

questions.text: 34y old Boxer is unable to see things clearly. He was advised for an eye surgery as he does not want to wear VIsual aids. WHich among the following is not recommended?
questions.solution:
Radial Keratotomy -RK is not recommended in patients who are boxers or Army men as RK weakens the Cornea, hence there is increased risk of Globe rupture following blunt trauma. This is seen more RK >PRK..

Radial Keratotomy involves making deep radial incisions in the peripheral part of cornea leaving the central 4 mm.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No: 52.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with complaints of itching and a Foreign body sensation in his eye. Upon examination, a shield ulcer is observed. The condition commonly associated with these findings is?
questions.solution:
• Shield ulcer is a characteristic corneal complication seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), also known as spring catarrh.

  • VKC is a chronic allergic conjunctivitis that commonly affects boys aged 5–15 years, often with a history of atopy or seasonal allergy.

Clinical clues:

  • Intense itching and foreign body sensation

  • Thick, ropy discharge

  • Giant cobblestone papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva

  • Shield ulcer on the cornea caused by mechanical abrasion from the large papillae and inflammatory mediators

Other options:

  • Autoimmune: Not typically associated with shield ulcers.

  • Tuberculosis: Can cause phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis, not shield ulcer.

  • Trachoma: Causes Herbert’s pits and pannus, not shield ulcer.



Shield ulcer in spring catarrh

questions.text: What is the common cause of childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of childhood blindness in developing countries like India is Vitamin A deficiency.

Mechanism:

  • Vitamin A is essential for maintaining the integrity of the conjunctival and corneal epithelium and for the visual cycle in the retina.

  • Its deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, Bitot’s spots, keratomalacia, and ultimately irreversible corneal scarring and blindness.

Other options:

  • Retinopathy of prematurity: Important cause in premature infants but less common overall.

  • Injuries: Cause traumatic blindness, more common in older children or adults.

  • Refractive error: Causes visual impairment, not blindness, and is easily correctable.

Hence, Vitamin A deficiency remains the leading cause of preventable childhood blindness worldwide.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of using contact lenses, presented with pain, redness and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and a moderate flare reaction. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described are classic for bacterial keratitis, especially in contact lens users:

  • Pain, redness, purulent discharge → hallmark of bacterial infection.

  • Greyish-white serpiginous corneal ulcer → typical of bacterial keratitis (often Pseudomonas aeruginosa in contact lens users).

  • Hypopyon (4 mm) and anterior chamber flare → indicate severe anterior segment inflammation.

Key points:

  • Contact lens wear is a major risk factor for bacterial keratitis, especially Gram-negative bacteria (Pseudomonas) and Gram-positive bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus).

  • Fungal keratitis usually occurs after trauma with vegetative matter and often shows feathery edges, satellite lesions.

  • Viral corneal ulcer (herpes simplex) → dendritic or geographic ulcers, minimal purulent discharge.

  • Parasitic ulcer (Acanthamoeba) → severe pain out of proportion, ring infiltrate, often in prolonged contact lens wear.

questions.text: In ocular surface examination and dry eye staining, which sequence of dyes is applied?
questions.solution:
#controversial 

The correct answer is: 2. Fluorescein → Lissamine Green → Rose Bengal  (NOTE: #controversial - answer given as 4 in certain "Qbanks" - however, we have confirmed with faculty of AIIMS, Delhi that the sequence F-L-R is correct)

Explanation for the sequence

1.Fluorescein: Stains areas of epithelial damage. Highlights corneal abrasions, punctate epithelial erosions, and epithelial defects.Applied first because it does not interfere with the uptake of the other dyes.

2. Lissamine Green: Stains damaged and devitalized epithelial cells and mucin-deficient areas. More comfortable than Rose Bengal (less irritation). Used after fluorescein to enhance detection of conjunctival surface damage.



3. Rose Bengal: Stains devitalized and dead epithelial cells as well as mucin-deficient areas. Causes more irritation and discomfort compared to Lissamine Green. Used last to avoid interference from other stains.




Reference  Srinivas SP, Rao SK. Ocular surface staining: Current concepts and techniques. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2023 Apr;71(4):1080-1089. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_2137_22. PMID: 37026238; PMCID: PMC10276680.

questions.text: A child has elevated liver enzyme levels. A ring-like structure is noted on ocular examination as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the cause for this?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of elevated liver enzymes and the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, as seen in the image, is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease. The KF ring is formed due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea.

Wilson's Disease Overview:
Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase. This genetic defect leads to impaired copper excretion from the liver, resulting in copper accumulation in various organs.

Clinical Features:
Hepatic manifestations: Hepatitis, cirrhosis, and liver failure.
Neuropsychiatric symptoms: Behavioral disturbances, movement disorders, such as the characteristic wing-beating tremor.
Ophthalmic findings:
Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF ring): Copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea.
Sunflower cataract: Copper deposition in the posterior capsule of the lens.

Management: Early diagnosis and treatment with copper-chelating agents like penicillamine or trientine are crucial to managing the disease and preventing progression.

Other Options:

Option A: Zinc deficiency results in acrodermatitis enteropathica, characterized by diarrhoea, diaper rashes and hypogonadism.

Option B: Selenium deficiency results in Keshan's disease, characterized by cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Iron excess is seen in hemochromatosis, which is characterized by deposition of Iron in Liver (causing cirrhosis), heart (causing Dilated cardiomyopathy), skin and pancreas (causing bronze diabetes) and pituitary gland (resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. However, deposition in eyes is uncommon.

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstay of the management of trachoma. What does the S in this acronym represent?
questions.solution:
The S in the acronym SAFE stands for surgery.

Trachoma is managed according to the WHO SAFE strategy, which includes Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement. Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery is performed to correct complications such as trichiasis (inward-turning eyelashes) and entropion (inward-turning eyelids). In severe cases with significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty (corneal transplant) may be necessary.

Trachoma is a chronic infective conjunctivitis and a leading cause of blindness worldwide. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, specifically the TRIC (Trachoma Inclusion Conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. The disease has two stages:

Active inflammatory stage (more common in children):

Presents with mild symptoms like ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge.
Examination shows conjunctival follicles with Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes) and corneal Herbert's follicles.

Cicatricial chronic stage (more common in middle age):

Patients may experience pain, tearing, photophobia, and eventually loss of vision.
Conjunctival concretions (whitish deposits of mucus in glands of Henle) and Herbert pits (scarred remnants of healed follicles) are seen.
Corneal opacity develops in the later stages.
This stage may also involve trichiasis and entropion, which can further damage the cornea and contribute to vision loss.



WHO currently uses the FISTO grading system to assess trachoma's severity:

F: Follicular inflammation
I: Intense inflammation
S: Scarring
T: Trichiasis
O: Corneal opacity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN  night blindness  lack of rhodopsin
X1A  conjunctival xerosis  conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots  conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2  Corneal xerosis  corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3 of the corneal surface liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface -

Stockers line is the deposition of iron on the advancing edge of pterygium Ocular manifestations of Vitamin A deficiency include (refer image folder). Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition • Page nos 487-490

questions.text: A 30 year old male working in a chemical factory presented with red eyes lacrimatiom and burning sensation. What is the first line of management in the given case?
questions.solution:
Steps in management of chemical burns to eye:
Initial step involves immediate and thorough irrigation with the clean water or normal saline.
Topical antibiotic drops to prevent infection.
Steroid eye drops to decrease inflammation, neutrophil infiltration, and treat anterior uveitis. It is advised to avoid use after 2 weeks, as steroids could disrupt collagen synthesis.
Cycloplegics, such as atropine, to enhance comfort.
Ref: online source - Soleimani M, Naderan M. Management Strategies of Ocular Chemical Burns: Current Perspectives. Clin Ophthalmol. 2020;14:2687-2699. Published 2020 Sep 15. doi:10.2147/OPTH.S235873

questions.text:
A patient underwent surgery on her middle ear and a nerve was injured intraoperatively. She came a week later to OPD with difficulty in closing her eyes on the same side. Ocular examination reveals decreased corneal sensation and dryness of the cornea.
Which of the following cranial nerves was most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient with a past history of intra-op nerve injury during middle ear surgery presented with dry eye, decreased corneal sensation, and incomplete eyelid closure (lagophthalmos) due to injury to cranial nerve (CN) VII.
Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve injury, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear. Hence, they can be injured due to surgery of the middle ear.
Clinical features include dry eyes, decreased corneal sensation which can eventually lead to mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown.
CN VII lies in proximity to the middle ear. Hence there are chances of nerve injury during middle ear surgery. Ref - Kanski clinical ophthalmology 9th edition page 219-220;

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which among the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
• History of vegetative trauma: Common with fungal infections, especially Fusarium and Aspergillus.

  • Delayed symptoms (5 days): Fungal keratitis often has an insidious onset.

  • Slit-lamp signs (presumed image shows fungal ulcer):

    • Dry, feathery borders

    • Satellite lesions

    • Possibly a hypopyon (often thick and immobile in fungal ulcers)

      Option Analysis:

  • Satellite lesion – Classic finding in fungal corneal ulcers.

  • Dendritic ulcer – Seen in Herpes Simplex Virus keratitis.

  • Ring abscess – Characteristic of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

  • Reverse hypopyon – Seen in silicone oil in the anterior chamber (post-retinal surgery).

     

Finding Associated Condition
Satellite lesions Fungal corneal ulcer
Dendritic ulcer Herpetic keratitis
Ring abscess Acanthamoeba keratitis
Reverse hypopyon Silicone oil post-retinal surgery


Reference:Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition Page no 176

questions.text: A foreign body made of iron has been retained. Which research is most effective for keeping an eye on vision?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. ERG
  • ERG (Electroretinogram): This test measures the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina to light stimulation. It can assess the function of the retina and is particularly useful in cases where there may be damage or concerns about the function of the retina due to a foreign body or other trauma.
  • Additionally, full-field ERG testing has a role in ocular trauma in establishing a diagnosis of siderosis when an iron-containing small metallic intraocular foreign body is suspected, and serial ERGs can be helpful in monitoring the health of the retina in these cases.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 463.

questions.text: What do subretinal demarcation lines (The water marks) indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Old Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
 
  • RRD is defined as egress of vitreous into the potential subretinal space between the neural retina and the RPE via a retinal break (rhegma= rent or rupture).
  • A demarcation pigment line indicates the existence of fluid egress via an outer wall hole into the subretinal region, causing a detachment, in chronic (older) cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 646, 650.

choices.text: It is caused due to fibrous bands in the vitreous

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. It is caused due to fibrous bands in the vitreous
 

  • Fibrous bands in the Vitreous cause Tractional Retinal detachment !  
  • The most common cause of Tractional RD is Diabetic Retinopathy. 
  • Epiretinal membranes (ERMs) are proliferations of cells that form an avascular fibrous membrane along the surface of the inner retina.
  • All other options are true, floaters and photopsia is seen in Retinal tear. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 629, 646, 651.

questions.text: What causes a "cherry red spot" to appear after trauma in children?
questions.solution:
Cherry red spots after trauma are seen in children due to Berlin’s edema (Commotio retinae).
 
  • This is a common result of a blow on the eye.
  • A milky white cloudiness due to edema appears over a considerable area at the posterior pole with a cherry red spot in the foveal region, which may sometimes disappear after a few days when vision is usually restored.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 500.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 448, 449.

questions.text: A painful unilateral vision loss is seen in a patient. He provides a timeline of afterimage persistence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Ocular ischemic syndrome
 
  • Decrease in visual acuity in OIS may be severe, with acute or subacute presentation
  • Visual fields on presentation can vary greatly from normal, to a central scotoma, nasal defects, centrocecal defects, and the presence only of a central or temporal island.
  • A history of transient visual loss is present in approximately 10–15% of patients with OIS. This is most frequently caused by transient embolization of the CRA or its branches, but vasospasm may also play a role. In these cases, a dark or black shade spreads across the visual field that lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Less commonly, severe carotid artery disease causes transient visual loss as a result of choroidal hypoperfusion. Conditions that either increase retinal metabolic demands or decrease perfusion pressure can precipitate transient visual loss and reflect the inability of a borderline ocular circulation to maintain stable the ocular blood flow. This has been reported following exposure to bright light, postural change, or after eating a meal. Visual loss resulting from hypoperfusion of the choroid often lasts several minutes to hours and may be associated with positive visual phenomena.

Pain:
  • Pain may be present in up to 40% of the eyes with OIS. Pain may be the result of increased IOP or may be ischemic in origin. Ischemic pain begins gradually over hours to days and is described as a dull, constant ache in the affected eye, over the orbit, upper face, and temple, and may worsen when the patient is upright. Lying down relieves or lessens pain.
  • The description "ocular angina" may be used to describe this discomfort. Ischemic pain may be confused with that from secondary glaucoma, but pain in eyes with OIS would not be explained by a slight IOP elevation. Pain from both increased IOP and ischemia may be present in the same patient. In older patients, giant cell arteritis should be excluded.

Hallucinatory Palinopsia:
  • Refers to a pathological group of visual symptoms in which there is an abnormal persistence or recurrence of an image in time.
  • Palinopsia is associated with a dysfunction of visual memory. It can be caused by posterior cortical lesions or seizures . Examples of lesions that may cause hallucinatory palinopsia are neoplasms, infarctions, hemorrhages, arteriovenous malformations, aneurysm, abscesses, and tuberculomas. The seizures that cause palinopsia are associated with metabolic imbalances, such as hyperglycemia, carnitine deficiency, ion channel disturbances, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
  • Illusory palinopsia is associated with alterations in visual perception of a real external stimulus affected by immediate environmental factors. Illusory palinopsia can be caused by changes in neurotransmitter receptors associated with migraines hallucinogen persisting perception disorder (HPPD) , trauma to the head, or drugs or other medications. Medications that have been reported to cause illusory palinopsia include trazodone , nefazodone, mirtazapine , topiramate, clomiphene, oral contraceptives, and risperidone. Palinopsia may also be idiopathic.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: Where are the Hollenhorst plaque and the Cherry Red Spot most visible?
questions.solution:
Cherry red spots and Hollenhorst plaque are seen in both CRAO and BRAO. But the incidence of CRAO is more common than BRAO.
A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because the nerve fiber layer is thin.
Three main types of retinal emboli have been identified in CRAO:
• Cholesterol (Hollenhorst plaque).
• Platelet-fibrin.
• Calcific.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 521, 524.

questions.text: To evaluate the function of _____, a multifocal ERG is helpful.
questions.solution:
ERG is useful to assess the function of macular cones.

The multifocal (mf)–ERG represents a cone-generated response of localized retinal function in the central macula, which is useful in establishing the presence of macular dysfunction.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 462.

questions.text:
The patient had severe transverse myelitis along with recurrent optic neuritis in both eyes. Right eye visual acuity is 6/60, and left eye visual acuity is 6/18.
Steroids had a 50% response rate in the patient. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
History of recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis and significantly diminished visual acuity in both eye along with responsiveness to steroids suggest the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica.

Neuromyelitis optica is an aggressive inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of ON and myelitis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3477.

questions.text: Retinal area seen with a direct ophthalmoscope is:
questions.solution:
The area of the fundus visualized by direct ophthalmoscopy at any given focus is 2 Disc Diopters (DD). This means that the size of the field of view that can be seen through the ophthalmoscope is roughly twice the size of the disc of the eyeball, which is approximately 1 DD. 



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text: Diabetic Retinopathy and vitreous haemorrhage are both present in this 40-year-old male. What's the reason?
questions.solution:
Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina). In an affected individual, these blood vessels become weak and easily damaged, which can lead to bleeding and vision loss.
  • Neovascularization is the formation of new blood vessels produced in response to hypoxia, or low oxygen levels, in the retinal tissue.
  • Neovascularization of the disc, or disc neovascularization, is a common finding in diabetic retinopathy and usually appears as a ring of small, dilated blood vessels around the optic disc.
  • The new blood vessels are often fragile and bleed easily, leading to vitreous haemorrhage, a condition in which the vitreous chamber of the eye becomes filled with blood.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545, 546.

questions.text: A diabetic man in his 60s who had previously experienced reading vision problem presented to the ophthalmology OPD for evaluation. What does the fluorescein angiogram reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
 

  • Neovascularization: The hallmark feature of PDR is the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization), which occur in response to retinal ischemia (lack of oxygen). These vessels typically form on the optic disc (disc neovascularization) and along the retinal periphery.

  • Vitreous Hemorrhage: The newly formed blood vessels are fragile and prone to rupture, leading to bleeding into the vitreous cavity. This can cause sudden vision loss and the appearance of floaters in the visual field.

  • Retinal Detachment: The abnormal blood vessels can contract, causing the retina to detach from its underlying layers. This can lead to severe vision loss and is a common complication in PDR.

  • Fibrous Tissue Formation: In addition to blood vessels, fibrous tissue can form as a result of the neovascularization. This fibrous tissue can cause traction on the retina, further contributing to retinal detachment and other complications.

  • Macular Edema: Although more common in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), macular edema can also occur in PDR. This involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula, leading to blurred central vision.




Severity classification of DR:

Stage 1: Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Microaneurysm plus hard exudate
Stage 2: Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Stage 1 + IRMA
Stage 3: Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Retinal hemorrhage in 4 quadrants
  • Venous bleeding in 2 quadrants
Stage 4: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Neovascularization

FA image of PDR showing Neovascularisation: 



Labelled FA image of various findings seen in Diabetic Retinopathy:


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man who had suddenly lost vision in his left eye came to the emergency room. The fluorescein angiography produced the image that is displayed below. Below is an illustration of the optical coherence tomography image. Which layers of the retina experience fluid buildup?
questions.solution:
• The arrow in the given picture points towards Retinal Pigment epithelium.
  • The OCT and FFA in this case point to Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR), which is characterised by fluid buildup in the subretinal space and separation of retinal pigment epithelium from the neurosensory retina.


FFA shows the characteristic Mushroom/ Umbrella pattern or Smoke stack appearance.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 607-609.

questions.text: A male 7-year-old child is seen with normal vision in his right eye (6/6) and the ability to see hand movements close to the face in his left eye. On fundoscopy, the left eye had a retinal detachment, subretinal yellow exudates, and telangiectatic vessels, while the right eye was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of Coat’s disease, it’s an idiopathic retinal telangiectasia, generally of onset in early childhood. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation, and frequently exudative retinal detachment, without signs of vitreoretinal traction.

Definition: a localized, congenital, retinal vascular disorder consisting of abnormal telangiectatic segments of blood vessels that result in leakage.

Key Features: 
• Retinal telangiectasia.
• Retinal capillary nonperfusion.
• dilated intercapillary spaces.
• Lipid exudate.
• subretinal fluid.

Associated Features:
• Usually unilateral.
• Male predominance.
• Fibrovascular macular scars.
• Leucocoria.
• Rare systemic associations, especially muscular dystrophies.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 562.

choices.text: Ask for history of trauma in the other eye

questions.text: A young man appears with a central scotoma in his left eye. His right eye had a 6/6 vision rating. Upon examination, there was focal foveal detachment in the left eye. What would be the following course of action?
questions.solution:
The next step would be to inquire about the use of steroids.

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR) is an idiopathic eye disorder observed in mostly young to middle-aged Caucasian males. It is characterized by leakage from the choriocapillaris resulting in a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina.

Risk factors may include psychological stress, type A personality, steroid administration, Cushing syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, and pregnancy.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 607.

questions.text: A 28-week-old infant was born with respiratory distress syndrome. His infection manifested on day fourteen of birth. There were no other co-morbidities found. At what postnatal age should he be examined for retinopathy of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Suspected ROP screening is done at 4 weeks of the postnatal period(PNA) or 32 weeks of PMA (Post Menstrual age) - whichever is later. The question specifically mentions time from birth, for it should be 4 weeks.
 
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity is an eye condition that affects premature infants of very low birth weight who have been exposed to high concentrations of oxygen. These infants have an incompletely vascularized retina which makes them susceptible to oxygen damage.
  • The vascular complex structures of the retina grow from the hyaloid vessels of the optic disc towards the nasal and temporal peripheries but do not reach the temporal periphery until a month after delivery.

Given the progressive nature of ROP, as well as the proven benefits of early diagnosis and timely intervention to minimize the risk of severe visual loss, a joint statement outlining the principles of a screening program for ROP has been set forth:
  • Screening for ROP should be performed in all infants with a birth weight at or above 1500 g or gestational age of 30 weeks or less (as defined by the attending neonatologist) and selected infants with a birth weight between 1500 and 2000 g or gestational age of more than 30 weeks with an unstable clinical course.
  • In most cases, at least two examinations should be performed. One examination may suffice if it shows unequivocally that retinal vascularization is complete bilaterally. The first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of chronological (postnatal) age or between 31 and 33 weeks of postmenstrual age (PMA) (calculated as GA plus chronological age), whichever is later.
  • Infants with immature retinas (no ROP) vascularized into zone II or III may be examined at 2-week intervals.
  • Infants with type 2 prethreshold disease require weekly or twice weekly exams.
  • Infants with type 1 prethreshold disease should be considered for peripheral laser ablation.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 538.

questions.text: On his 45th birthday, a person is identified as diabetic. When do you intend to advise a dilated fundoscopic examination?
questions.solution:
• The patient should visit an ophthalmologist immediately at the time of diagnosis, as there can be a large sub clinical phase of the disease which would have already caused a lot of damage to the eye.
  • In case of Type 1 DM, it is 5 yr after diagnosing or during puberty.
 
  • Both should be routinely observed yearly.
 
  • Although all agree that screening of asymptomatic diabetic patients is critical, the most cost-effective timing remains controversial. It generally is agreed that type 2 diabetics should be examined at the onset of their disease, then yearly thereafter. Type 1 diabetics do not have to be examined until 5 years into their disease course, but no sooner than puberty, then yearly thereafter. If retinopathy is detected, the frequency of examinations should be increased appropriately.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 552.

questions.text: The initial sign of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms. In which of the following layers is diabetic retinopathy involved?
questions.solution:
While DR involves both OPL and INL, Inner nuclear layer(INL) is involved in microaneurysms of diabetic retinopathy. Microaneurysms are out-pouchings of capillary walls, which form due to a lack of pericytes or two arms of a capillary loop fusing. They usually develop in the inner nuclear layer and can lead to plasma leakage into the retina due to a breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier, or can become thrombosed.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 544.

questions.text: Retinal detachments are sealed using air insufflation during a non-invasive surgery called pneumatic retinopexy. Which of the following gases is used in pneumatic retinopexy?
questions.solution:
Sulphur hexa fluoride is used in retinopexy. Pneumatic retinopexy is an outpatient procedure used to reattach a retina without scleral buckling by using an expanding gas bubble. It is a fast and minimally invasive procedure with lower success rates than conventional surgery, and is typically used for retinal detachment in the higher two-thirds of the peripheral retina.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 476, 668.

questions.text: Where does optical atrophy not occur?
questions.solution:
Optic atrophy is not seen in polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy.

While Retinitis pigmentosa, Methanol poisoning and Central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO) can lead to optic atrophy.

Causes of Optic atrophy:



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 870.

questions.text: Premature baby weighing 1000 gms or less is most likely to suffer from:
questions.solution:
Premature infants who are exposed to high levels of oxygen within the first ten days of life are at risk of developing bilateral proliferative retinopathy.

This is caused by vasoconstriction of immature vessels due to the high levels of oxygen, leading to hypoxia of retina causing neovascularization and  formation of fibrous tissue. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 537.

questions.text: Diffuse mottling of retina with focal areas of increased and decreased pigmentation between posterior pole and equator (Salt and pepper retinopathy) is observed in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Resolving retinal detachment is not related to salt and pepper retinopathy and is instead a consequence of a traumatic ocular event.
 
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy is an inherited condition and usually affects the peripheral retina.
  • It is characterized by diffuse mottling of the retina with focal areas of increased and decreased pigmentation between the posterior pole and the equator.
  • The condition is usually benign and does not progress to any underlying retinal pathology.
Causes of Salt and Pepper retinopathy are:
  1. Congenital Rubella syndrome
  2. Congenital Syphilis syndrome
  3. Leber's amaurosis
  4. Fundus Flavimaculatus (Stargardt's disease)
  5. Thioridazine/Phenothiazine toxicity
  6. Atypical retinitis pigmentosa

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 490, 709, 950.

questions.text: The risk of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is increased in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is a medical condition that occurs when the retina gets separated from the back wall of the eye. This damages the blood vessels and nerve cells in the eye, leading to vision loss. The causes of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment include trauma to the eye, a tear or hole in the retina, lattice degeneration and age-related changes in the vitreous humor that causes the retina to pull away from the back wall of the eye.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 647, 648.

questions.text: Most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma:
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is a common and serious congenital intraocular tumor of childhood occurring in 1 in 15,000-20,000 live births.

It is usually detected between 1-2 years of age and can be bilateral in 25-30% of cases. 90% of the cases are sporadic, while 10% are familial.

Most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is Leukocoria and strabismus.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: Which of the following does not show calcification?
questions.solution:
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a congenital condition characterized by the failure of regression of the primary vitreous during fetal development. It is typically associated with a fibrovascular stalk extending from the optic disc to the lens. While PHPV can present with various ocular abnormalities, calcification is not a typical feature of this condition.

On the other hand, the other options mentioned can show calcification:

  1. Optic nerve Drusen: Optic nerve Drusen refers to calcified deposits that can accumulate within the optic nerve head. These calcified deposits can be visualized on fundus examination.

  2. Choroid osteoma: Choroid osteoma is a rare benign tumor of the choroid layer in the eye. It is characterized by the presence of mature bone tissue. Calcification is a prominent feature of choroid osteoma.

  3. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina. It can show calcification within the tumor mass, which can be observed in imaging studies such as computed tomography (CT) or ultrasound.

Therefore, among the given options, option 1 (Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous) is the correct answer as it does not typically show calcification


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 435, 586, 592, 593.
Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.

choices.text: Viral nucleic acid detection from the intraocular fluid
Viral antibody detection in blood by ELISA

questions.text: Most rapid and accurate method to diagnose CMV retinitis:
questions.solution:
Isolation of CMV or detection of its DNA in appropriate clinical specimens is the preferred approach rapid approach for diagnosis of CMV retinitis.
 
  • PCR of ocular fluid offers the highest utility when laboratory confirmation is necessary. Both aqueous and vitreous samples are adequate substrates for PCR.
  • CMV retinitis is typically diagnosed through a comprehensive eye examination conducted by an ophthalmologist.
  • The ophthalmologist will look for telltale signs of retinitis, such as yellow-white patches, retinal hemorrhages, "bull's-eye" lesions, cotton-wool spots, intraretinal exudates, and flame-shaped hemorrhages. 
     
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 704.

questions.text: According to the ISNT rule, which is the thinnest portion of the neuro-retinal rim?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Temporal.
 
  • The ISNT rule is used to describe the thickness of the neuro-retinal rim. The neuro-retinal rim refers to the portion of the optic nerve head that surrounds the cup, which is the central depression in the optic disc. This pattern of rim width is known as the ISNT rule (inferior > superior > nasal > temporal).
  • The “ISNT rule” (which states that, in a normal eye, the neuroretinal rim width follows a characteristic pattern of Inferior ≥ Superior ≥ Nasal ≥ Temporal) may be helpful as a general principle to differentiate normal from glaucomatous nerves.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1032.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with 100-day glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)
 
  • 100-day glaucoma is a neovascular glaucoma that occurs in ischemic type of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It is known as 100-day glaucoma because it occurs 3 months after the episode of CRVO. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG following ischemic CRVO.
  • Fundus examination shows massive enlargement of retinal veins and massive retinal hemorrhages giving a "splashed tomato appearance". Other findings include cotton wool spots, optic disc edema and neovascularization at the disc and in the periphery.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 529.

questions.text: Roth spots can be found in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Acute leukemia. Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia.
 
  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. In Roth's spot the white center due to coagulated fibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. They are typically associated with certain medical conditions.
  • Roth's spots may be seen in: Leukemia, Diabetes, Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE), Sickle cell retinopathy, Hypertensive retinopathy, HIV retinopathy, Systemic lupus erythematosus etc.
  • Patients with leukemia can present with retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, Roth spots, retinal microaneurysms, or neovascularization



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 793.

questions.text: Arden Index is linked to the:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: EOG (Electrooculogram) 
  • The Arden Index is associated with the EOG (Electrooculogram).
  • During Electro-oculography (EOG), the patient is asked to alternately look towards two targets placed in front of him to the right and to the left, and the potentials recorded by the electrodes are printed. 
  • The potentials are continuously recorded for a fixed time interval in a light-adapted and dark-adapted state. 
  • The ratio of the light peak over the dark trough is known as the Arden index.
  • It is useful in diagnosing objectively the early stages of retinal diseases that affect the retinal pigment epithelium or in cases where the fundus cannot be clearly seen.

Arden Index Classification:






Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 540.

questions.text: Which is the exception to the blind spot/optic disc enlargement
questions.solution:
Optic nerve hypoplasia (aka optic disc hypoplasia) does not result in blind spot/optic disc enlargement. 

POAG(primary open angle glaucoma), papilloedema and medullated nerve fibres result in enlarged blind spot. Other causes of enlarge blind spot include - Optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc. 

Optic nerve hypoplasia 
 

Optic nerve hypoplasia (ONH) is a congenital condition where the optic nerve is underdeveloped or smaller than normal. This leads to a reduced number of nerve fibers, which can result in visual impairment. Key features include

A. Small optic disc: The optic nerve head may appear smaller or pale compared to a normal optic disc.
"Double ring" sign is seen on fundus examination - the sign appears as a peripapillary yellowish, mottled halo that surrounds the hypoplastic(small) optic disc.

B. Visual Impairement

C. Maybe part of a syndrome (such as Septo-Optic Dysplasia) and can be associated with other abnormalities, including pituitary dysfunction, midline brain abnormalities, and endocrine disorders.
 

Other options
  • Option 1- POAG - Barring of Blind spot is one of the earliest visual field changes in POAG.
  • Option 3 - Papilledema: the blind spot enlarges as the edematous optic disc swells past its normal limits.
  • Option 4 -An improper myelination of the retinal nerve fibers results in a disorder known as medullated nerve fibres (also known as optic disc medulaltion). Beyond the lamina cribrosa, myelination continues and extends into the retina for an undetermined amount of space beyond the optic disc. The blind spot enlarges as a result of this.
Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 312, 323, 343.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1059.

questions.text: Identify the possibility in the given FFA picture.
questions.solution:
Macular ischemia is visible on the FFA picture, that is the central dark region.
 
These microaneurysms can be seen as pinpoint hyperfluorescent lesions on this fluorescein angiography image spread throughout the macula. Additionally, you can see a region of fluorescein leakage, which is brought on by neovascularization and leaky new blood vessels in that region. Additionally, the superior arcade of this picture exhibits intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs).



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 517-519.

questions.text: What is ETDRS done for ?
questions.solution:
A randomized clinical trial called the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
The study's findings showed that focal photocoagulation has a positive impact on diabetic macular edema.
The ETDRS study significantly influenced the management of diabetic retinopathy and diabetic macular edema, establishing laser photocoagulation as a standard treatment and paving the way for further studies on anti-VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) therapies in diabetic eye disease.
Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) and recent anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) clinical trials results are applied in the management of diabetic macular edema or neovascularization which has reduced the risk of severe visual loss to less than 5%.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 543.

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Exudative Retinal Detachment (ERD): An exudative retinal detachment (which is often caused by a choroidal tumour) is characterized by shifting subretinal fluid and separated retinal layers. This fluid accumulates due to leakage from blood vessels, fluid in the space below the retina, or overproduction of fluid within the retina itself. 
     
  • Tractional Retinal Detachment: This type of retinal detachment is caused by an abnormal adherence or adhesion between different layers of the retina. It is characterized by retinal mobility being severely reduced, and no shifting subretinal fluid present. The retinal tissue remaining attached could cause the retina to become stretched or pulled away from its underlying layer. 
     
  • Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD): This type of detachment occurs when a hole or tear develops in the retina and fluid from the vitreous space passes through the hole or tear, causing the retina to lift away from the retinal pigment epithelium.


 

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 650.

questions.text: Choose what photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. macula and optic nerve
 
  • Photostress recovery time (PSRT) is the time taken for visual acuity to return to normal levels after the retina has been bleached by a bright light source.
  • Photostress recovery time measurement procedure is known as Photostress test. Normal recovery time is about 15–30 seconds.

Purpose: 
  • Can differentiate between retinal and post retinal disease.
  • The photostress test is a simple, easy and quick clinical technique that can differentiate between retinal (macular) and post retinal (e.g. optic nerve) disease.


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 89, 90.

questions.text: What is the most common way for retinoblastoma to spread?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Direct spread via Optic nerve (Answer has been confirmed by Pediatric Oncology Faculty at AIIMS, Delhi - Kindly see the reference article by them)
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a common cancerous tumour that develops in one or both eyes from the neurosensory retina.
  • Retinoblastoma (RB) gene has been discovered as 14 band on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q 14) and is a 'cancer suppressor' or 'antioncogenic' gene. Retinoblastoma is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the RB gene by two mutations (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis).
  • The most frequent presenting symptom is leukocoria, or a yellowish-white pupillary reflex (cat's eye appearance in amaurosis).
  • Common spread involves direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.
Reference: Aditya K Gupta et al https://pm.amegroups.org/article/view/5703/html

questions.text: An elderly female with gradual painless DOV fundus findings image :
questions.solution:
The given picture shows hard exudates as seen in Diabetic Retinopathy.

A potentially dangerous side effect of macular edema in people with diabetes mellitus is the development of hard macular exudates. They develop in the Outer plexiform layer of the retina. Hard foveal exudate deposition, one of the most prevalent and early clinical indications of diabetic retinopathy, has been linked to visual impairment.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: A youngster that underwent enucleation and had a whitish pupillary reflex exhibits the Flexner Winter Steiner Rosette. What is the most probable  diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flexner wintersteiner rosettes are seen in cases of retinoblastoma. Presence of leukocoria, i.e. white eye relfex also confirms the diagnosis.
The most frequent intraocular cancer in children and infants, accounting for 3% of all paediatric malignancies, is retinoblastoma. The RB1 gene, also known as a tumour suppressor gene, is the cause of it.

Image shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes—arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent “lumen”.






Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1325.

questions.text: The Mizuo phenomenon is seen during:
questions.solution:
Mizuo-Nakumara phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease.
  • Oguchi's disease is an autosomal recessive form of congenital stationary night blindness and is caused by a disruption in the steps of inactivation of rod phototransduction.
  • The Mizuo phenomenon is a term used to describe reversible changes in the fundus color from a gold leaf-like reflex under light conditions to the normal orange–red color after full dark adaptation, which is typically seen in Oguchi's disease.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 488.

questions.text: Which are the most radioresistant cells in the retina?
questions.solution:
#Controversial
1>2

The most radioresistant cells in the retina are the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). (answer confirmed by Ophthalmology faculty at AIIMS, Delhi)

RPE cells are relatively resistant to radiation due to their low mitotic activity and high metabolic capacity. In contrast, other retinal cells, such as ganglion cells, rods and cones, and bipolar cells, are more sensitive due to their higher turnover rates and metabolic demands.

Thus, the correct answer is: Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Reference: Early Ultrastructural Changes After Low-dose X-irradiation in the Retina of the Rat, Nature (1989), URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/eye198998.pdf

questions.text: The symptoms of dengue virus infection in the eye consist of all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The effects of dengue virus in the eyes can show up in multiple ways, including maculopathy (damage to the macula, an area near the center of the retina that is responsible for clear central vision), vitreous hemorrhage (bleeding in the vitreous, the gel-like substance that fills the middle of the eye), and optic neuritis (inflammation of the optic nerve, which sends visual information from the eyes to the brain).
  • Blurring of vision is the most common presenting symptom followed by scotoma. Ocular findings were mostly seen in the posterior pole of the fundus, manifesting as retinal hemorrhages, macular edema, foveolitis, vasculitis, and optic neuropathy.
  • However, cataracts (cloudy areas in the lens of the eye, which can cause vision problems) have not been reported to be caused by Dengue in the medical literature.
  • Most patients with dengue-related ophthalmic complications recover spontaneously without any treatment. Patients with severe visual loss or bilateral involvement were treated with systemic steroids and occasionally immunoglobulins.
  • Prognosis of dengue-related ophthalmic complications is favorable; almost all patients had normal or showed improvement in visual acuity and complete resolution of dengue ophthalmic complications was noted in almost all cases.



Reference: Yip, Vivien Cherng-Hui et al. “Ophthalmic complications of dengue Fever: a systematic review.” Ophthalmology and therapy vol. 1,1 (2012): 2. doi:10.1007/s40123-012-0002-z

questions.text: What is the pathology depicted in the below histopathology picture of the retina?
questions.solution:
Drusen are signs of harm to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a layer of cells that gives nourishment and protection to the retina. They appear as yellowish deposits beneath the retina and are typically considered one of the earliest stages of age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), a condition that can cause irreversible vision loss. Visual impairment can be caused by a generalized granularity and/or atrophy of the RPE, photoreceptors, and the choriocapillaris. 



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1323.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 586, 589.

questions.text: A patient who had cataract surgery a year prior is currently receiving medication for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient described an instantaneous, painless loss of vision. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in question has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, cataract surgery and Fluorescein angiogram of the patient shows classic “petalloid” appearance of fluorescein leakage in the late phase of the angiogram, which is indicative of cystoid macular edema (CME).

CME is a frequent complication following cataract surgery and is also known as Irvine–Gass syndrome. CME is the most common cause of vision loss after cataract surgery.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 626, 627, 630.

questions.text: Photophobia and a subnormal electroretinogram response were observed in a 20-year-old male patient. What is the source of his ailment?
questions.solution:
He is suffering from cone dystrophy.

Cone dystrophy patients usually present with progressive central acuity loss, color vision disturbances, and photophobia.

Cone-Rod dystrophy is characterised by:
  • depressed scotopic electroretinogram results (ERG)
  • depressed or extinguished photopic ERG
  • depressed Electrooculographic (EOG) findings


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 501.

questions.text: Which of the following protozoa can affect the eye?
questions.solution:
Toxoplasmosis can affect eye.
  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an apicomplexan obligate intracellular parasite.
  • Toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of posterior uveitis.
  • After acute necrotizing retinitis, granulomatous lesions and chorioretinitis can be seen in the posterior chamber in toxoplasmosis.
  • Other ocular complications include iridocyclitis, cataract, glaucoma
  • On fundoscopy it causes a Headlight in fog appearance. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 739.

questions.text: What is the most common complication after lens extraction in persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous?
questions.solution:
Most common complication after lens extraction in persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous is retinal detachment.

Both retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage are the complications of surgery in persistent hyperplasia primary vitreous.
But retinal detachment is more common as compared to vitreous haemorrhage.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 844, 845.

questions.text: Which of the following cells contributes to the development of the retina's inner limiting membrane layer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Muller cells.
 
  • The inner limiting membrane (ILM) is a layer located at the innermost surface of the retina.
  • It is composed of specialized cells and extracellular matrix components.
  • Muller cells (Muller glial cells), play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of the retina's inner limiting membrane.
  • Muller cells are a type of glial cell that spans the entire thickness of the retina.
  • They provide structural support, contribute to the blood-retinal barrier, and participate in the formation of the ILM by secreting extracellular matrix components.
Retinal glial cells:





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 419.

questions.text: Except for_____ each has a cherry red spot visible.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: None.

Cherry red spot can be seen in all the diseases given above.

Niemann Pick Disease:
  • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by the abnormal accumulation of lipids in cells throughout the body.
  • In Niemann-Pick disease, a cherry red patch can be observed on the retina of the eye.

GM1 gangliosidosis:
  • GM1 gangliosidosis is a rare genetic disorder that affects the CNS.
  • In GM1 gangliosidosis, a cherry red spot can be seen on the macula of the retina.

Tay-Sachs disease:
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence of a specific enzyme, resulting in the accumulation of certain fats in the brain and nerve cells.
  • In Tay-Sachs disease, a cherry red spot can be observed on the macula of the retina.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 521.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man who had his cataract removed and an IOL implanted 3 weeks prior complains of worsening eyesight.
