Slit-lamp examination reveals honeycomb maculopathy, and fluorescein angiography (FA) reveals hyperfluorescence resembling "flower petals." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Cystoid Macular Edema.
 
  • In the macula, the central part of the retina responsible for sharp, central vision.
  • In this case, the patient underwent cataract removal and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, which are common procedures performed to treat cataracts and improve vision.
  • However, the worsening eyesight and the presence of honeycomb maculopathy on slit-lamp examination are indicative of macular involvement.
  • In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance).
  • On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance".



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 627, 628, 630.

questions.text: A young adult presented with night blindness and tubular vision. On examination, Intraocular Pressure was observed to be 18mm and the anterior segment was remarkable. Fundoscopy showed attenuation of arterioles and waxy pallor of the optic disc with bony corpuscles like spicules of pigmentation in mid periphereal retina. Ring scotomas were observed on perimetry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Pigmentary Retinal Dystrophy.

Pigmentary Retinal Dystrophy (Retinitis Pigmentosa), is a group of inherited disorders characterized by progressive degeneration of the retina. 
It primarily affects the photoreceptor cells, leading to visual impairment.



Systemic associations with pigmentary retinal dystrophy:





Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 303.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in case of Fundoscopy of a patient showing chalky white optic disc with well defined margins. Retinal vessels and surrounding Retina appear normal?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Primary Optic Atrophy
 
  • Primary Optic Atrophy is degeneration or loss of optic nerve fibers leading to the pale appearance of the optic disc.
  • Primary optic atrophy shows a chalky white disc and well-demarcated margins. It is caused by a lesion proximal to the optic disc without papilloedema, e.g., multiple sclerosis, retrobulbar neuritis. 




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 335.

questions.text: Retinoblastoma is most commonly spread by -
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Optic Nerve.
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. 
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or near the optic disc (from where it spreads most commonly). 
  • This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues results in marked proptosis. 
  • Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349, 350.

questions.text: What is Central Retinal artery occlusion known to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Orbital mucormycosis > 2. Diabetic Retinopathy (#controversial)(Option 2 as better answer has been confirmed by faculty from AIIMS,Delhi)
 
  • Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is known to be associated with Orbital mucormycosis.
  • CRAO is sight-threatening emergency caused by a sudden blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to ischemia of the retina. It is commonly associated with embolism, infections and vasculitis. Inflammation in the form of vasculitis or infection (e.g., varicella or mucor infection), optic neuritis, or even orbital disease (e.g., mucormycosis) may cause central retinal artery obstruction.
  • Orbital mucormycosis is a rare but serious fungal infection caused by the rhizopus species.
  • Rhizopus is knownn be to be angio-invasive- can lead to the invasion of blood vessels, including the central retinal artery, resulting in CRAO and subsequent loss of blood supply to the retina 
Other risk factors for CRAO include:
  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma
Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is known to be associated with CRVO but not CRAO. Diabtetic Retinopathy is an MICRO-angiopathy - hence will affect small vessels and does NOT lead to occlusion in bigger vessel like Central retinal artery. Infection and embolus are more common - hence, Orbital mucormycosis is a better answer.
 

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 520.

questions.text: A known case of diabetes mellitus had developed pre-retinal hemorrhage neovascularization of the disc. Such a case should be managed by:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy and therefore, the next step in management is to perform a pan retinal photocoagulation. 
 
  • Neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and pre-retinal hemorrhage are signs of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a severe form of diabetic eye disease. In this stage, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization) grow on the optic disc and elsewhere in the retina, which can lead to complications like retinal hemorrhages, retinal detachment, and vision loss.
  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the gold standard treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It involves applying laser to areas of the retina away from the macula to reduce the production of angiogenic factors (such as VEGF) that contribute to neovascularization. The goal of PRP is to prevent further neovascular growth and reduce the risk of complications like vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachment.
Other options:
 
  1. Anti-VEGF drugs: These can be used in cases of macular edema or to treat neovascularization in specific cases, but for diffuse neovascularization like NVD, PRP is typically preferred.
  2. Grid photocoagulation by Laser: This is used for diabetic macular edema, not for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with neovascularization.
  3. Focal photocoagulation by Laser: This is used for localized areas of diabetic macular edema, not for neovascularization or widespread retinal involvement in PDR.

Therefore, pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the correct approach to manage this condition.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 285-287, 290, 291.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
• Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19.
  • It is typically mild and presents with symptoms like redness, tearing, foreign body sensation, and photophobia.
  • This condition is thought to occur due to the viral infection or the associated inflammatory response.
 



Reference: Rokohl, Alexander C et al. “Ocular Involvement in COVID-19: Conjunctivitis and More.” “Okuläre Mitbeteiligung bei COVID-19: Konjunktivitis und mehr.” Klinische Monatsblatter fur Augenheilkunde vol. 238,5 (2021): 555-560. doi:10.1055/a-1344-8138. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34020483/

Nasiri, Naser et al. “Ocular Manifestations of COVID-19: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis.” Journal of ophthalmic & vision research vol. 16,1 103-112. 20 Jan. 2021, doi:10.18502/jovr.v16i1.8256. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7841281/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common tumor to be associated with retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
• RB1 gene present on chromosome 13 is a tumor suppressor gene that is mutated in patients with Retinoblastoma.
 
  • Amongst other common tumors caused due to RB gene mutations - Osteosarcoma is the most common tumor followed by STS (Soft tissue sarcoma). 

  • Retinoblastoma is associated with a germline mutation in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene. This mutation increases the risk of developing other malignancies, particularly in hereditary retinoblastoma cases.

  • Osteosarcoma:

    • It is the most common second primary tumor in survivors of hereditary retinoblastoma, typically arising in adolescence or adulthood.
    • The risk is particularly elevated due to the same RB1 mutation involved in cell cycle regulation.


Other options:
 

  1. Medulloblastoma:

    • While it is a common brain tumor in children, it is not significantly associated with retinoblastoma.

  2. Melanoma:

    • There is a slightly increased risk of melanoma in hereditary retinoblastoma survivors, but it is less common than osteosarcoma.

  3. Pinealoblastoma:

    • Also called trilateral retinoblastoma when associated with bilateral retinoblastoma.
    • It is a rare association seen in hereditary cases but is much less common than osteosarcoma.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2698.

questions.text: Punched lesion in retina is caused by all except?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 3: Posterior staphyloma.

Punched lesions in the retina are typically seen in conditions that involve inflammation or developmental abnormalities. Let's review the given options:

  1. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis infection can cause punched lesions in the retina. It is a common cause of focal retinochoroiditis.

  2. Congenital rubella: Congenital rubella infection can lead to a triad of findings known as the "congenital rubella syndrome," which includes cataracts, deafness, and retinopathy. The retinopathy in congenital rubella can present with punched lesions.

  3. Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a structural abnormality of the eyeball where there is a bulging or elongation of the posterior segment. It is not associated with punched lesions in the retina.

  4. Choroidal coloboma: Choroidal coloboma is a congenital defect in the choroid layer of the eye. It can be associated with punched lesions in the retina.

    Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 150,170,546 .

questions.text:
A lady presented with sudden painless loss of vision in the right eye one day back. On examination right eye has relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) while other ocular examinations were normal. What investigations should be done next to make the diagnosis 
(i) MRI brain and orbit with contrast 
(ii) Estimation of blood glucose, RFT and LFT 
(iii) Anti NMO and MOG antibody 
(iv) Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Differential diagnosis of sudden painless loss of vision:
  • Hyphema
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal Artery Occlusion
  • Retinal Vein Occlusion
  • Retinal Detachment
  • Optic Neuritis
Acute painless loss of vision and relative afferent pupillary defect on ocular examination is indicative of optic neuritis.
To confirm the diagnosis of Optic neuritis -(i) MRI brain and orbit with contrast and (iii) Anti NMO and MOG antibody are required. 
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 329,330,3477 .

questions.text: 70y old diabetic was screened for Diabetic retinopathy, and was classified as Severe NPDR. Which of the following is not feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Disk new vascularization is not a feature of non proliferative diabetic retinopathy and this is seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
 
  • Severe NPDR follows the 4-2-1 rule
  • Diffuse retinal hemorrhages and micro aneurysms in all four quadrants.
  • Venous beading in two or more quadrants.
  • Intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant.
 Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe fertile changes sin diabetic patients. It is classified into following times:
  • Non proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  •  Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  •  Diabetic maculopathy
  •  Advanced diabetic eye disease

 Management of diabetic retinopathy includes intravitreal anti VEGF drugs, intravitreal steroids laser therapy and or surgical management.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 286, 287.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child visited the ophthalmologist exhibiting a white eye reflex, and ultrasonography revealed an intraocular mass with calcifications. The family history indicated that the child's father had a similar condition and underwent the removal of one eye (enucleation). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in a young child, coupled with intraocular calcifications on ultrasonography and a positive family history, is classic for retinoblastoma — the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood.

It results from a mutation in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 13q14.

  • Inherited (germline) form: Autosomal dominant with high penetrance, often bilateral and multifocal.

  • Sporadic (somatic) form: Usually unilateral.

Clinical clue: The father’s history of similar disease with enucleation suggests a hereditary (germline) mutation.

Ultrasound finding: Intraocular mass with calcifications — pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Toxocara infestation: Causes endophthalmitis, no calcification.

  • Congenital glaucoma: Causes buphthalmos, photophobia, tearing — not leukocoria.

  • Neurofibroma: Affects optic nerve or orbit, not intraocular retina.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. He underwent a cataract surgery 1 month ago. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed a flower-petal appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with blurring of vision after cataract surgery — a classic scenario for postoperative cystoid macular edema (CME), also called Irvine-Gass syndrome.

Key points:

  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Shows “flower-petal” or “cystoid” pattern due to leakage of fluorescein from perifoveal capillaries into the cystoid spaces of the macula.

  • Risk factors: Diabetes, complicated cataract surgery, uveitis, epiretinal membranes.

  • Clinical features:

    • Gradual painless blurring of central vision

    • Usually develops 4–6 weeks after cataract surgery

Other options:

  • Central serous retinopathy: Serous detachment of retina, often in young adults, shows smokestack or inkblot pattern on FFA.

  • Age-related macular degeneration: Drusen, neovascularization; FFA shows late leakage in CNV.

  • Macular hole: Full-thickness defect in macula; FFA shows window defect, not flower-petal pattern.

questions.text: 35 year old male with high myopia suddenly presented with history of flashes of light and left eye, what could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario of a patient with severe myopia, experiencing sudden flashes of light the likely cause could be retinal detachment.
  • Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
  • Examination findings- RAPD, Altered red reflex, Vitreous pigment on anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign), Shifting fluid sign.
Risk factors include
  • myopia,
  • previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia,
  • a family history of retinal detachment, and
  • trauma.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 309-313.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of A and B waves

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Retinitis Pigmentosa
questions.solution:
• Night Blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigementosa.
  • It is a retinal dystrophy that occurs due to degeneration of Photoreceptors involving the rods more than cones.
  • It can be sporadic or Inherited.
  • It can be Autosomal dominant, Reccesive or XLR.
  • Initial presentation is worsening of night blindness.
  • Fundoscopy-Atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, Intraretinal Perivascular bone spicule changes.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 296-298.

questions.text: Which is the second most common cause of vision loss due to retinal vascular disease?
questions.solution:
• Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most common cause of vision loss from retinal vascular disease, following diabetic retinopathy.
  • There are two types of RVO: central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) and Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO).
  • Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) is caused by blockage of one of the tributaries of the central retinal vein. It's characterized by dilated and tortuous veins, flame-shaped and dot and blot hemorrhages, and retinal edema.
  • BRVO is more common than CRVO. Some of the risk factors for BRVO are old age, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, smoking, obesity and hypercoagulable states.
  • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)- An occlusion of the main retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve.
  • It's typically caused by thrombosis and appears similarly to BRVO, but with hemorrhage in all quadrants of the retina with macular edema.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 280.

questions.text: An 3-year old child is having amblyopia in right eye. What is the preferred treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
• Amblyopia (“lazy eye”) = decreased visual acuity in one or both eyes due to abnormal visual development in early childhood.

  • Common causes: strabismus, anisometropia, visual deprivation (e.g., cataract).

  • Best treatment in a 3-year-old:

    • Occlusion therapy (patching): Cover the normal (better-seeing) eye → forces the amblyopic eye to work and develop proper visual connections.

    • Can be combined with correction of refractive error (glasses).

  • Other options:

    • Radial keratotomy: Surgical correction for refractive error (e.g., myopia) — not indicated.

    • Spectacles/refraction with near addition: Corrects refractive error, but not sufficient alone for amblyopia at this age.

    • Observation: Not appropriate — early intervention is crucial, especially before 7–8 years (“critical period” of visual development).

So, the preferred treatment is occlusion therapy.

questions.text: Fundoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fundus image showing a cherry-red spot suggests central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include:

Heart disease
Carotid artery disease
Mucormycosis
Varicella infection
Radiation exposure
Trauma

Causes:

Emboli, most commonly originating from the carotid artery or heart, are the leading cause of CRAO. Other types include cholesterol, calcium, and platelet fibrin emboli.
Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
Retinal arteritis leading to arterial occlusion
Angiospasm
Increased intraocular pressure
Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features:

Sudden, painless loss of vision
Amaurosis fugax (temporary monocular blindness due to ischemia), as seen in this patient
Absent direct pupillary reflex
Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) present

Fundus examination findings:

Markedly attenuated, thread-like arteries
Interrupted blood flow in veins (cattle track appearance)
Cherry-red spot
Severe retinal edema
Retinal pallor

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who was using presbyopic glasses for the past few years is now able to comfortably read the newspaper without the glasses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical phenomenon of improvement in near vision observed in a presbyopic patient is referred to as the "second sight phenomenon." This improvement occurs due to index myopia, which arises from the development of nuclear cataracts.

Presbyopia, often described as age-related visual impairment, is characterized by a physiological inability to accommodate, resulting in a gradual decline in near vision. The typical treatment for presbyopia involves prescribing appropriate convex lenses for near tasks.

In the case of nuclear cataracts, nuclear sclerosis leads to an increase in the lens's refractive index, resulting in progressive myopia known as index myopia. As a presbyopic patient develops a nuclear cataract, the elevated refractive index of the lens compensates for their impaired accommodation ability.

Consequently, this allows a presbyopic individual to read without glasses due to the enhancement in near vision, a phenomenon termed "second sight." However, it is important to note that this increase in refractive index also leads to a deterioration in distance vision.

questions.text: A 65 year old male who is a chronic smoker presented with painless central blurring of vision. Fundoscopy showed yellowish subretinal deposits as shown in the image. What could be the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Macular degeneration refers to a group of diseases associated with loss of central vision and damage to the macula. Degenerative changes occur in the pigment, neural, and vascular layers of the macula. The dry macular degeneration is usually ischemic in etiology, and a wet macular degeneration is associated with leakage of fluid from blood vessels, usually referred to as age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).
PHYSICAL FINDINGS
•
Decreased central vision
•
Macular hemorrhage, pigmentation, edema, atrophy
•
The most common abnormality seen in age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the presence of drusen, or yellowish deposits deep to the retina; this may be early in course of disease. Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition • Page No. 498

questions.text: a 55y old male came with history of sudden onset painless loss of vision with history of floaters one week back. Patient also gives hsitory of Cataract surgery in the same eye 4 weeks back. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The above clinical history of Recent cataract surgery with sudden painless loss of vision with history of floaters is suggestive of retinal detachment. It occurs due to accumlation of fluid between the Neurosensory retina and Retinal Pigment epithelium due to a retinal tear. Clinical features - Photopsia,Floaters and visual field defects. Signs- Hypotony, Shafer sign( pigments in anterior vitreous), detached retina is convex in configuration. Ref- Ophthalmology by Khurana 7th edition Page 309-312

questions.text: The fundoscopy findings of a known case of HIV with low CD4 counts in shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The picture depicts the classic "sauce and cheese" or Pizza-pie look of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, a disorder that is frequently managed with ganciclovir. Can be given intravenously or as intravitreal injection, depending on severity.

Given the patient's immunocompromised status (transplant recipient) and the fundoscopy findings, which show patchy retinal necrosis with irregular borders and concomitant retinal hemorrhages, CMV retinitis is the most likely diagnosis.


 

Other options:

  • Acyclovir / Valacyclovir → Active against HSV and VZV, not effective against CMV.

  • Trifluridine → Topical antiviral for herpes simplex keratitis, not for CMV retinitis.




Reference
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition ,Page no: 276

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution:
• In adults, the most common primary intraocular malignancy is uveal (choroidal) malignant melanoma.

  • It arises from melanocytes of the uveal tract (choroid, ciliary body, iris).

  • Presents with: visual disturbances, visual field defects, or a pigmented intraocular mass.

Other options:

  • Retinoblastoma → Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, rare in adults.

  • Reticulum cell sarcoma → Rare intraocular lymphoma, uncommon primary tumor.

  • Neurofibroma → Usually orbital/eyelid tumor, not primary intraocular malignancy.


Reference
Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition - Page no: 917

questions.text: A patient complains of visual blurring which is relieved on its own. Fundus examination showed papilledema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Amaurosis fugax is a transient, painless monocular visual loss caused by temporary retinal or optic nerve ischemia, usually due to embolism from carotid artery or heart.

  • Symptoms: visual blurring or “curtain coming down” that resolves spontaneously within minutes.

  • Papilledema is not a classical feature of amaurosis fugax itself, but transient disc edema can occur in some ischemic episodes.

Other options:

  • Retinal detachment → Sudden onset of flashes, floaters, or curtain-like visual loss; does not resolve spontaneously.

  • Blindness → Permanent loss of vision, not transient.

  • Angle-closure glaucoma → Acute painful visual loss with halos, headache, nausea; vision loss is not transiently resolving.


Reference
Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition - Page no 213, 703,794

questions.text: A hypertensive patient comes to the OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. On fundoscopy, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages , cotton wool spots, and disc edema were found. What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Hypertensive retinopathy is graded using the Keith-Wagener-Barker classification:

  • In this patient:

    • Flame-shaped hemorrhages 

    • Cotton wool spots 

    • Disc edema / papilledema 

  • Presence of papilledema = Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

Other options:

  • Grade I → Mild arteriolar narrowing only.

  • Grade II → AV nicking or focal constrictions.

  • Grade III → Hemorrhages + cotton wool spots but no papilledema.


Reference
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8e ,Pg 557-558

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a similar picture given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of a cherry red spot on fundoscopic examination is a classic finding in CRAO.

What is a cherry red spot?

  • It's the appearance of the fovea as a bright red spot on the macula.

  • Caused by the surrounding retina becoming pale due to ischemia, while the fovea remains reddish due to its thinness and separate choroidal blood supply.

    Differentiation:

Condition            Fundus Finding Pain Onset Key Point
CRAO Pale retina + cherry red spot Painless Sudden Emergency – embolic cause common
CRVO Blood and thunder appearance (dilated veins, retinal hemorrhages) Painless Sudden No cherry red spot
BRAO Localized retinal whitening Painless Sudden May or may not have cherry red spot
BRVO Sectoral hemorrhages Painless Sudden No cherry red spot

Common causes of CRAO:

  • Emboli from carotid artery or heart (most common)

  • Giant cell arteritis (in elderly)

  • Hypercoagulable states


Reference: Comprehensive opthalmology by AK khurana 6th edition page no 269-270

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology is characteristic of retinoblastoma, a malignant intraocular tumor of childhood.

Key Features of Retinoblastoma:

  • Age group: Typically presents in children <5 years

  • Presentation:

    • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) – most common presenting sign

    • Strabismus, decreased vision

    • Rarely, painful red eye if there's secondary glaucoma

  • Histology:

    • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes: Round tumor cells arranged around a central lumen (resembling a flower)

    • Indicative of photoreceptor differentiation

  • Management: Depends on the stage – includes chemotherapy, enucleation, radiotherapy, and focal therapies.

    Why not the others?

Option Why Incorrect?
Medulloblastoma CNS tumor; seen in cerebellum; shows Homer Wright rosettes
Astrocytoma Glial tumor; not associated with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes
Rhabdomyosarcoma Soft tissue tumor; commonly affects orbit but not intraocular structures; no Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 647

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination in the affected eye , a relative afferent pupillary defect is seen , however the optic disc was normal. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is optic neuritis.

The patient presents with sudden loss of vision, painful ocular movements, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and a normal optic disc. These findings are characteristic of optic neuritis, particularly retrobulbar neuritis, where inflammation affects the optic nerve behind the globe, leaving the optic disc initially normal. Central scotoma is a common visual field defect in this condition.

Other options

  • Eale’s disease is primarily a retinal vasculitis with hemorrhages and neovascularization, not an acute optic neuropathy.
  • Neuroretinitis presents with optic disc swelling and a macular star, which are absent in this case.
  • Optic nerve glioma is a slow-growing tumor that causes gradual rather than sudden vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions warrants laser trabeculoplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma
 
  • Laser trabeculoplasty is a treatment option used to manage certain types of glaucoma, which is characterized by increased intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma is a specific type of glaucoma associated with the buildup of extracellular material on ocular structures, particularly the trabecular meshwork.
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.
  • Argon or selective laser trabeculoplasty can be performed in XFS if the angle is open enough to allow laser application
  • Laser trabeculoplasty can be effective in improving the outflow of fluid through the trabecular meshwork and reducing the IOP in pseudoexfoliative glaucoma.
Indications: 
1.Patients with OAG, uncontrolled by medical therapy - the IOP remains above the target IOP despite maximum medical therapy that can be tolerated.
2.In patients with OAG with poor compliance to medical treatment, the IOP remains above the target IOP, and the glaucomatous optic atrophy worsens.
3.Patients with OAG with poor tolerance to medical therapy.
4.Patients with pseudoexfoliation or pigmentary glaucomas.
5. Angle-closure glaucoma with a patent iridotomy.
6.When the glaucoma surgery needs to be deferred or delayed

Contraindications: 
1.Inflammatory glaucoma - as post-laser inflammations will increase, leading to further IOP spikes.
2.Advanced glaucoma
3.Poor visualization of the TM due to synechiae- as the site of action is trabecular meshwork.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1076.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young adult who had 60 mmHg of IOP reported having painful red eyes. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Acute angle closure glaucoma: This condition presents with sudden onset of severe eye pain, usually accompanied by redness, blurred vision, and markedly elevated IOP (often exceeding 40 mmHg). It can also cause nausea and vomiting. Acute angle closure glaucoma is a ophthalmic emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1064, 1065.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic techniques is not performed on a patient with dilated pupils?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Gonioscopy.

Out of the following gonioscopy does not need dilation of the pupil. All other procedures can be done under pupil dilatation as the angle structures cannot be properly evaluated under dilated pupil. All the anterior segment evaluation can be done without dilation but for posterior segment evaluation pupils should be dilated.
 
  • Gonioscopy is a diagnostic procedure used to examine the drainage angle of the eye.
  • It involves using a specialized lens called a gonioscope to visualize the structures of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Dilated pupils can restrict the visualization of the angle structures, making it challenging to perform accurate gonioscopy.
  • Therefore, gonioscopy is generally not performed on patients with dilated pupils.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1029, 1030.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 589, 590.

questions.text: Which ophthalmological study is being conducted in this illustration?
questions.solution:
The image shows Applanation tonometry. The most popular applanation tonometer was designed by Goldmann (GAT) for use with the Haag-Streit slit lamp. 

GAT is based on the Imbert–Fick principle, which states that the force necessary to applanate a perfectly elastic, infinitely thin, dry sphere divided by the area flattened (P = F/A) equals the pressure inside the sphere.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1025.
Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought in with complaints of photophobia and bilateral proptosis along with eye watering. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with bilateral proptosis and photophobia in a 2 year old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Sturge-Weber syndrome's most prevalent ocular symptom is
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome is glaucoma.
 
Studies have reported that it is seen in 30%-70% of the patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome and can be present at birth or may develop later in life. The most common age of onset is 6 years.

In patients with Sturge–Weber syndrome or its variants, presentation at birth is associated with a gonioscopic appearance of the anterior chamber angle that cannot be differentiated from that of primary congenital glaucoma



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1107.

questions.text: One can observe black deposits on the conjunctiva of glaucoma patients upon using:
questions.solution:
Adrenochrome deposits are common after chronic use of topical epinephrine for glaucoma.

One classic cause is oxidation of epinephrine drops, which can lead to conjunctival deposits of adrenochrome, a melanin-like pigment accumulation.



Reference: Domarus D. Adrenochromeinlagerungen in die Kornea ("Schwarze Hornhaut"). Klinisch-pathologischer Fallbericht [Adrenochrome deposits in the cornea ("Black cornea"). A clinical-pathological case report]. Ophthalmologica. 1977;175(3):166-70. German. doi: 10.1159/000308650. PMID: 896145.

questions.text: Which of the following medications alters the aqueous outflow by acting on the trabecular meshwork?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Pilocarpine

1.Timolol- Beta blockers- MOA: Act on beta adrenergic receptor on the ciliary body and decrease aqueous production.
2.Pilocarpine- Cholinergic agonists- MOA: Constricting the ciliary body muscles that are connected to the scleral spur to open the trabecular meshwork mechanically and increase the outflow of aqueous humor through trabecular meshwork.
3.Brimonidine-Alpha adrenergic agonists-MOA: Act on alpha adrenergic receptors on ciliary vasculature and decrease aqueous production and also increase uveoscleral outflow.
4.Brinzolamide-Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors-MOA: decrease aqueous production by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the ciliary processes.






Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1121, 1122.

questions.text: What is the Express glaucoma implant made of?
questions.solution:
• Ex-Press glaucoma implants are made of stainless steel. The Ex-Press Mini Glaucoma Shunt is a biocompatible device designed by Optonol Ltd. (Neve Ilan, Israel) to reduce intraocular pressure. It is 3 mm long and has a diameter of 400 microns.
  • It is a non-valved, MRI compatible, stainless steel device with a 50 micron lumen and a disc on one end and a spur-like extension on the other to prevent extrusion.
  • The Ex-PRESS implant is a biocompatible, non-valved stainless steel device that was initially designed to be implanted under the conjunctiva to allow drainage of aqueous humor into the subconjunctival space.
  • Implantion under a scleral flap is recommended to limit excessive aqueous flow and to decrease postoperative complications of subconjunctival implantation such as hypotonia and conjunctival erosion



Reference: Altinel, Meltem Guzin et al. “Ex-PRESS implantation for different types of glaucoma.” International journal of ophthalmology vol. 12,8 1290-1297. 18 Aug. 2019, doi:10.18240/ijo.2019.08.09

questions.text: What types of cells are affected by glaucomatous optic atrophy?
questions.solution:
• Progressive optic neuropathy results from death of retinal ganglion cells(RGCs) in a typical pattern which results in characteristic optic disc appearance and specific visual field defect.
  • RGCs death is initiated when some pathological event blocks the transport of growth factors (neurotrophins) from the brain to the RGCs.
  • The blockage of these neurotrophins initiates a damaging cascade and the cell is unable to maintain its normal functions. The RGCs losing their ability to maintain normal functions undergo apoptosis and trigger apoptosis of adjacent cells.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 261.

questions.text: Which cells are most frequently impacted by glaucomatous optic atrophy?
questions.solution:
Ganglion cells are the most commonly affected cells in glaucomatous optic atrophy.

Glaucoma is second leading cause of blindness and is characterized by optic disc changes and visual field defects. Due to increased intraocular pressure, there is loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGC) and their axons over a period of many years.



 

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 261.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below should not be administered to a patient with narrow-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Homatropine
 
  • Anticholinergic agents like- Atropine, Cyclopentolate, Homatropine can precipitate angle closure glaucoma and is thus contraindicated.
  • Mydriasis is a precipitating factor for angle closure glaucoma as it reduces the angle and Homatropine is a mydriatic agent. 
  • Pilocarpine, Timolol and Acetazolamide are used for the treatment of angle closure glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1064.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to control raised IOP?
questions.solution:
• To reduce IOP in glaucoma, Mannitol, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like Methazolamide, alpha 2 agonists like Brimonidine and Apraclonidine (a clonidine derivative), beta blockers like Timolol, prostaglandin analogues like Latanoprost, and miotics like Pilocarpine are employed.
  • On the other side, dexamethasone tends to raise IOP. Corticosteroids induce IOP elevation in susceptible patients by reducing trabecular outflow facility through changes to the mechanical structure of the trabecular meshwork, extracellular matrix trabecular deposits, and reduction of trabecular endothelial functional and phagocytic activity.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1085, 1086, 1120.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about POAG is correct?
A. The blockage at the level of TM is seen on gonioscopy
B. First degree relatives are at 1% more risk of developing POAG
C. On dilating the pupil, IOP always rises
D. Visual Field Defect can be therein the normal C:D ratio
E. Family members are having more chances of developing steroid responsiveness
questions.solution:
The true statements for POAG are D and E.

Statement D:
- A deficiency in the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) may be the source of visual field defects.
- RNFL defect is a precursor to chronic optic neuritis, and the initial Cup: Disc ratio is normal.

Statement E:
- Patients with POAG and their offspring and siblings are more likely steroid responders ie they respond to 6 weeks topical steroid therapy with a significant rise of IOP.

Other statements:

Statement A- Inability to visualize the normal trabecular meshwork on gonioscopy is seen in primary angle closure glaucoma.

Statement B-Siblings are at 10% increased risk of developing POAG where offspring are at 4% increased risk.

Statement C- Primary angle closure glaucoma is associated with exacerbation of IOP with pupillary dilatation and not POAG.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1115.
Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 266, 270.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 236.
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, Page no 349.

choices.text: Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the incidence of POAG
Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Family history is not a risk factor for POAG
Increased cup:disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect in relation to the progression of ocular hypertension in POAG?
questions.solution:
Primary open angle glaucoma risk factors include family history. Gene mutations of WDR 36, optineurin, Myo C are implicated in POAG. 

High risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to POAG:

1. Ageing- as age increases risk also increase
2. Raised IOP- > 30 mmHg; reducing IOP delays incidence of POAG
3. Central Corneal Thickness- < 550 microns
4. Disc ratio- Increased Cup:Disc ratio> 0.7 (normal- 0.3-0.4)
5. Splinter hemorrhages
6. Pattern standard deviation in Humphrey’s analyzer



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1055.

questions.text: Right eye discomfort and redness are evident in the patient. Upon examination, the anterior chamber has keratin precipitates, cells, and fare along with an IOP of 40 mmHg. Which of the following anti-glaucoma medications shouldn't be administered?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of acute anterior uveitis - inflammation of uveal tissues. Miotics and prostaglandin analogs are relatively contraindicated in an inflamed eye since these drugs may worsen the inflammation by enhancing the breakdown of the blood aqueous barrier.
  • Disrupted blood- aqueous barrier results in obstruction of the aqueous outflow facility. Cytokines , released from inflammatory cells further exacerbate inflammation 
PG analogues breaks down the blood–aqueous barrier potentially worsening or reactivating uveitis, cystoid macular edema (CME) and herpes infections.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1123.

questions.text: Bronchial asthmatic patient developed glaucoma. Which medication from the list below will be administered to this patient for OAG?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is the drug of choice in the given scenario.
  • In situations of POAG and a history of bronchial asthma, beta blockers are contraindicated because they further constrict the airways and exacerbate asthma.
  • In patients with asthma who have never taken corticosteroids before, latanoprost therapy has no effect on resting or triggered airway function or asthma symptoms. Patients with glaucoma and concurrent bronchial asthma may benefit from latanoprost treatment.
  • Carboprost, Gemeprost, Alprostadil are not indicated in the treatment of glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1121, 1123.

questions.text: A one-month-old baby is diagnosed as having photophobia and watery eyes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with photophobia and blue sclera in a one-month old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. 

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)/Buphthalmos is a rare condition caused by genetically defined defects in the trabecular meshwork and anterior chamber angle, which result in high intraocular pressure (IOP), but no other ocular or systemic developmental problems. It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Stenopic slit is not used for:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Corneal tattooing. Stenopaeic slit is not used for corneal tattooing.
 
  • A stenopaeic slit is an ophthalmological instrument placed in front of the eye running along the line of sight. It is used in:
  1. Fincham's test (Option 1)
  2. To find out the axis of cylinder in astigmatism for correction of glasses (Option 2)
  3. To find out the optimal site for Iridectomy (Option 3) for treatment of corneal opacities.
  • The Fincham test (performed using stenopaeic slit ) is used to differentiate between the colored halos due to Cataract and colored halos in corneal edema due to Glaucoma.
  1. Halos are broken into fractions/ scattered in: Cataract.
  2. Halos remain intact but the brightness decreases in: Glaucoma.
Image showing Stenopaeic slit:




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 138, 139, 251.

questions.text: What does a patient with secondary glaucoma, iris atrophy, and a permanently dilated pupil after penetrating keratoplasty suggest?
questions.solution:
These clinical features are suggestive of Urrets-Zavalia syndrome.
 
  • Urets-Zavalia Syndrome (UZS) is a rare postoperative complication characterized by a fixed dilated pupil with accompanying iris atrophy following penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) for keratoconus in patients who receive mydriatics.
  • Recent research shows that progression to secondary glaucoma is reportedly observed in approximately one-quarter of cases 


Reference: Kurtz, Shimon, and Maayan Fradkin. “Urrets-Zavalia Syndrome Following Cataract Surgery.” Case reports in ophthalmology vol. 12,2 659-663. 20 Jul. 2021, doi:10.1159/000513959

questions.text: Which tonometer is used for the irregular surface of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonometer used for irregular surface of the cornea is Mackay-Marg tonometer.
 
  • In Mackay Marg tonometer, concept is, force required to keep the flat plate of a plunger flush with a surrounding sleeve against the pressure of corneal deformation.
  • MacKay-Marg tonometer is useful in measuring IOP after keratoplasty and in scarred corneas in which Goldmann is not useful.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 108.
Jain, Arun K MD; Sukhija, Jaspreet MS; Gupta, Amod MS. ProTon tonometer determination of intraocular pressure in patients with scarred corneas. Indian Journal of Ophthalmology 54(2):p 95-98, Apr–Jun 2006. | DOI: 10.4103/0301-4738.25829

questions.text: What is the purpose of Imbert Fick's Law Principle of Tonometry?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Applanation Tonometry.
 
  • Imbert Fick's Law is a principle in tonometry, which is the measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Imbert Fick's Law is specifically associated with applanation tonometry, which is a common method used to measure IOP.
  • Applanation tonometry involves flattening or applanating a small area of the cornea and measuring the force required to achieve this.
  • By applying Imbert Fick's Law, the force applied and the area of applanation can be used to calculate the IOP.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 21st edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: What is Normal Intraocular Pressure ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 16 mm Hg
 
  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) refers to the fluid pressure inside the eye, specifically in the anterior chamber.
  • The normal range for IOP =11 mmHg - 21 mmHg.
  • The average normal intraocular pressure is around 15 to 17 mmHg.
  • IOP measurement is important in assessing the health of the eye and diagnosing conditions such as glaucoma.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1025.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in case of a child presented with lid lag and an enlarged cornea with a diameter of 13 mm. Examination of the eye revealed double contoured opacities concentric to the limbus.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Congenital Glaucoma.
 
  • Normal infant cornea measures 10.5 mm. A diameter of >13 mm confirms corneal enlargement in congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP), which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. Onset is usually less than 3 years of age.
  • Trabeculodysgenesis (defective trabecular meshwork) is the mechanism of raised IOP, simulating open-angle glaucoma. The CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis of congenital glaucoma. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. 
  • Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm form the classic triad of symptoms of congenital glaucoma.
Signs seen in congenital glaucoma:





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of a 75-year-old patient presented with deterioration of vision. On examination, the pupillary reflex is observed to be sluggish and Intraocular pressure was normal. Optic disc evaluation showed a large and deep cup and primarily showed paracentral scotomas :
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Normal Tension Glaucoma  (NTG)
NTG refers to Optic disc changes and visual field defects of Glaucoma without any rise in IOP.
 
  • The impact of NTG can range from non-progressive, asymptomatic disease to bilateral blindness. A variety of mechanisms have been proposed to explain the pathogenesis of NTG. Whereas IOP is the main driver of progressive visual loss in most patients with POAG, NTG likely represents a heterogeneous or multifactorial group of etiologies, with a common final pathway of retinal ganglion cell loss. Genetics is known to play a role because of the strong association with family history .
Pathophysiology:
  • The histopathological changes in NTG are the same as those found in POAG, namely loss of retinal ganglion cell axons (retinal nerve fiber layer - RNFL) and glial tissue at the optic nerve head, leading to optic disc excavation and cupping.Typically, RNFL loss is more common in the supero- and inferotemporal neuroretinal bundles, leading to notches, but loss may also be global and concentric. Some changes are more common in NTG compared with POAG. These include optic disc hemorrhages and temporal RNFL defects, with localized, deep paracentral scotomas, more often in the superior hemifield.
  • Because the IOP is normal, suspicion will usually be roused by optic disc appearance or a visual field defect on automated perimetry. If the presentation is advanced, patients may have symptoms of reduced vision, difficulty with low contrast situations, and awareness of visual field defects.
  • Optic disc hemorrhages are more common in NTG than POAG.
  • Corneal pachymetry is used to measure the central corneal thickness (CCT). Reduced CCT is associated with progression risk. Thinner corneas are associated with the underestimation of intraocular pressure using applanation tonometry.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1061, 1062.

questions.text: Use of atropine is contraindicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Atropine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis) and paralysis of the ciliary muscle (cycloplegia).**

  1. Angle-closure glaucoma:

    • Atropine is contraindicated because pupillary dilation can worsen the angle closure, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This can exacerbate optic nerve damage and cause acute symptoms like pain, nausea, and vision loss.

  2. Malignant glaucoma:

    • Atropine is generally avoided but not the primary contraindication. Other medications are more relevant to malignant glaucoma.

  3. Corneal ulcer:

    • While atropine is not specifically contraindicated, it may sometimes be used to provide relief from ciliary spasm.

  4. Anterior uveitis:

    • Atropine is commonly used to reduce pain from ciliary spasm, prevent synechiae (adhesions), and keep the pupil mobile.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 108, 164, 247.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act via the trabecular outflow pathway?
questions.solution:
The trabecular outflow pathway refers to the drainage of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and into Schlemm’s canal. Drugs that increase trabecular outflow reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) by enhancing the drainage through this pathway. 

  1. Netarsudil:

    • A Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor and norepinephrine transporter inhibitor.
    • It improves trabecular outflow by relaxing the trabecular meshwork and reducing resistance to aqueous humor outflow.
    • This is its primary mechanism of action.

  2. Timolol:

    • A beta-blocker that reduces aqueous humor production by the ciliary body.
    • It does not act directly on the trabecular outflow pathway.

  3. Brimonidine:

    • An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow.
    • It does not enhance trabecular outflow.

  4. Bimatoprost:

    • A prostaglandin analog that primarily increases uveoscleral outflow, with a minor effect on trabecular outflow in some cases.
    • Its primary mechanism is not trabecular outflow.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 243.

questions.text: Which of the following optic disc changes are not seen in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Roenne's nasal steps is a type of visual field defect and not an optic disc change.

Optic disc changes in Glaucoma:





Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 238-241.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions have a familial inheritance ? 
(i) Retinoblastoma 
(ii) Retinitis pigmentosa 
(iii) Myopia 
(iv) Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
• Familial disease is a disease that is hereditary, passed on from one generation to the next.
  • All four diseases mentioned in the question(Retinoblastoma/Retinitis pigmentosa/Myopia/Primary open-angle glaucoma) have some form of familial inheritance and genetic predisposition. 
  • Hence, option (3) is correct. 
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 38,40,236,237,296,297,314,315 .

questions.text: Which of the following traid is seen associated with angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The triad associated with angle closure glaucoma is 2. Vogt's triad.

Vogt's triad consists of three characteristic signs observed in angle closure glaucoma:

  1. Severe eye pain: Patients with angle closure glaucoma often experience intense eye pain due to increased intraocular pressure. The pain can be described as a deep, aching sensation.

  2. Nausea and vomiting: Angle closure glaucoma can cause gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. These symptoms are a result of the severe pain and autonomic nervous system involvement.

  3. Blurred vision or visual disturbances: Patients may experience blurred vision, halos around lights, or other visual disturbances. These visual symptoms are typically transient and occur during acute episodes of increased intraocular pressure.

Hutchinson's triad (option 1) refers to a set of clinical features associated with congenital syphilis and includes interstitial keratitis, not specific to angle closure glaucoma.

Virchow's triad (option 3) describes the three factors contributing to the formation of thrombosis, which are venous stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury. This triad is not associated with angle closure glaucoma.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 231,246,247,248,250,251,253 .

questions.text:
A child presented to the OPD with progressive vision loss . It was associated with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis of this child?

1. Congenital glaucoma
2. Mucopolysaccharidosis
3. Retinoblastoma
4. Congenital cataract
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Congenital glaucoma

The child with progressive vision loss, lacrimation, photophobia, and an enlarged, hazy cornea with a frosted-glass appearance/ ground glass appearance as shown in the image has congenital glaucoma.

The examination should include following:
l. Measurement of/OP preferably with hand held Perkin's applanation tonometer or Tonopen should be done since scleral rigidity is very low in children. TOP measurement und e r GA is unpredictably altered.

2. Measurement of corneal diameter by callipers.
3. Slit-lamp examination should be carried out with portable slit-lamp.
4. Ophthalmoscopy to evaluate optic disc.
5. Gonioscopic examination of angle of anterior chamber reveals trabeculo-dysgenesis with either flat or concave iris insertion as described in pathogenesis. Gonioscopy in performed under general anaesthesia using Koeppe's lens for direct visualisation of the angle structures

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 234.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with glaucoma. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Glaucoma is characterized by increased intraocular pressure (IOP), which can damage the optic nerve. The first-line treatment aims to reduce IOP, and prostaglandin analogues are considered the drug of choice.

Key points:

  • Prostaglandin analogues (e.g., latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost)

    • Increase uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor

    • Administered once daily

    • Generally well-tolerated; main side effect: hyperpigmentation of iris

Other options:

  • Beta-blockers (timolol, betaxolol): Reduce aqueous humor production; second-line or adjunct therapy.

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral: acetazolamide; topical: dorzolamide): Decrease aqueous humor production; used in combination or acute cases.

  • Rho-kinase inhibitors (netarsudil): Newer agents, used if first-line therapy is insufficient.

Hence, the drug of choice for glaucoma is a prostaglandin analogue.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Photophobia and lacrimation in a three month old child?
questions.solution:
Congenital cataract is a lens opacity that is present at birth or shortly after birth. Symptoms of the condition include:
  • A gray or white spot on the eye pupil.
  • Pupils that appear white.
  • Blurry vision.
  • Cloudy vision.
  • Double vision.
  • Reduced vision.
  • Colors appear faded.
  • Lights appearing too bright.

Congenital cataract may also cause amblyopia but it seldom produces watering and photophobia among the following options

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 386-387.

questions.text: A 74 yrs old female presented with a painful,  left eye. On examination, the lOP of her left eye was 52mmHg and right eye 18mmHg. Slit lamp examination reveals deep anterior chamber, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Painful red eyes, increased IOP and presence of a deep anterior chamber is suggestive of secondary open-angle glaucoma - Phacolytic glaucoma.
  • It in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts
  • Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour.
  • Malignant Glaucoma - Seen after Intraocular surgeries such as Trabeculectomy.
  • Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis- IOP is not usually high.
  • Phacomorphic glaucoma-  Acute Secondary angle closure glaucoma.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 255.

questions.text:
Which of the following are direct gonioscopes?
A. Goldmann
B. Richardson
C. Zeis
D. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Richardson and Koeppe are examples of direct gonioscopes.

A gonioscope is used to measure the angle of the anterior chamber in the eye. Gonioscopes can be categorized as follows:

Indirect gonioprism: Provides a mirror image of the opposite angle. Examples include the Goldmann, Zeiss, and Posner gonioscopes.

Direct gonioprism: Offers a direct view of the angle. Examples include the Koeppe, Richardson, Medical Workshop, Barkan, and Swan-Jacob gonioscopes.


Applications of gonioscopy include:

Viewing the angle of the anterior chamber, where structures are observed in the following order from front to back:

Schwalbe‘s line

Trabecular meshwork

Scleral spur

Ciliary body band

Root of iris


Identifying foreign bodies, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle.

Assessing the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.

Performing goniotomy, a surgical procedure for treating congenital glaucoma.


Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page no 110,116 .

choices.text: In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection.
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot.
Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma

questions.text: which of the following is true about perimetry?
questions.solution:
Perimetry involves assessing the extent of visual fields and comes in two types: kinetic and static. In kinetic perimetry, a target with a specific luminance is moved from an area where it is not seen toward the center until it is detected by the subject. In static perimetry, the stimulus remains in a fixed location, and its intensity is adjusted until the subject either sees it (indicating the threshold is reached) or no longer detects it.

Charting visual fields is valuable for diagnosing various conditions, including glaucoma, neurological disorders, and retinal diseases like retinitis pigmentosa, as well as for monitoring the effects of laser treatment for diabetic retinopathy.

 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 246,533-534 .

questions.text: A female patient comes to the emergency with acute painful red eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The scenario and red eye showing corneal edema and a mid dilated vertically oval pupil is suggestive of Acute Angle closure glaucoma. It is associated with red eye and 1. Acute onset ocular pain with nausea and vomiting 2. Intermittent blurring of vision with Halos. 3. Photophobia 4. loss of vision. Signs- Corneal congestion,corneal edema, fixed and mid dilated oval pupil, shallow Anterior chamber, IOP above 40mmhg. Ref- Kanski clinical Ophthalmology 8th edition Page 363-365

questions.text: What can induce a reduction in vision in a patient with anterior uveitis due to posterior segment involvement?
questions.solution:
• Anterior uveitis is an inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye. It is the most common form of intraocular inflammation, and typically causes redness, pain, photophobia and decreased vision.
  • Uveitis may cause visual loss and blindness due to a variety of causes, including secondary complications such as cataract, glaucoma, choroidal neovascularization, cystoid macular edema, optic neuropathy, and others.
  • In many cases, inflammation of the anterior uvea can cause inflammation in the posterior segment of the eye. In this instance, the inflammation can trigger cystoid macular edema, which is a buildup of fluid in the macula of the eye. The macula is the area at the center of the retina, responsible for central vision.
  • When cystoid macular edema occurs, vision can become blurry and distorted. As a result, overall vision can decrease due to posterior segment involvement.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 700.

questions.text: What causes a band-shaped keratopathy to develop?
questions.solution:
• Band shaped keratopathy is a degenerative change caused due to the deposition of calcium salts in Bowman's membrane, superficial part of corneal stroma and the deeper layers of epithelium.
  • It can be idiopathic, age related or associated with chronic eye diseases such as Chronic uveitis, JRA (Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis), Sarcoidosis, Chronic glaucoma, Chronic keratitis; systemic conditions like Sarcoidosis, Hyper-parathyroidism, Vitamin D toxicity, Extensive metastatic neoplasm to bone, Chronic renal failure (secondary hyper-parathyroidism); or local corneal damage.


 

Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease and it is used to treat:
questions.solution:
Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease with activity against fibronectin and laminin components of the vitreoretinal interface.

It is used for treatment of symptomatic vitreomacular adhesions.

It works by dissolving the proteins that link the vitreous to the macula, resulting in posterior detachment of the vitreous from the retina.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 613, 614.

questions.text: Endophthalmitis does not involve inflammation of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Sclera.
 
  • Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eyeball (except sclera) due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. 
  • There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. 
  • It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 
  • The structures commonly affected in endophthalmitis include the uvea (iris, ciliary body, and choroid), retina, and vitreous.
  • The avascular densely packed collagenous matrix of the cornea and sclera serves as a potent barrier against infectious infiltration in normal eyes.
  • Hence, the sclera, which is the tough outer layer of the eye, is not typically involved in the inflammation seen in endophthalmitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 724.

questions.text: What is the prerequisite for sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
• Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a rare pathologic process characterized by bilateral uveitis following injury to one eye either from surgery or penetrating ocular trauma.
  • The penetrating trauma triggers an auto-immune response to the eye which causes inflammation, redness, swelling, and pain.
  • In order to diagnose sympathetic ophthalmitis, the initial penetrating trauma needs to be identified and ruled out, as the condition itself cannot be confirmed without it.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 770.

questions.text:
Except for __, all of them have Iritis. 
A. Systemic lupus erythematosus
B. Rheumatoid arthritis
C. Behcet’s disease
D, Psoriatic Arthropathy
E. Ulcerative colitis

Iritis is seen in Systemic lupus erythematosus incidence is rare
Iritis is present in juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and rarely in Rheumatoid arthritis.

Iritis causes:
A. Infectious

B. Non-infectious

  • HLA B27 associated 
  • Bechet’s disease
