Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine , 20th edition, Page no 221.
Firestein & Kelley’s Textbook of Rheumatology, 11th edition, Page no 704.

questions.text: A narrow pupil that doesn't change in the dark is present in the condition of:
questions.solution:
A small pupil which remains the same in dark is seen in the condition of Horner’s pupil.

Features of Horner’s syndrome: 
  • Oculosympathetic palsy
  • Miosis which do not improve even in dark
  • Ptosis
  • Anhydrosis
  • Loss of ciliospinal reflex
  • Pseudo-enophthalmos

 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 965, 966.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is currently used for the prophylaxis of non-infectious uveitis in the LUMINATE program?
questions.solution:
In LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) programme a pivotal study LUVENIQ (LX-211) assessed the safety and efficacy of oral form of next generation calcineurin inhibitor, Voclosporin for treatment of sight threatening non-infectious uveitis (as a steroid sparing therapy).



Reference: Anglade, Eddy et al. “A new agent for the treatment of noninfectious uveitis: rationale and design of three LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) trials of steroid-sparing voclosporin.” Clinical ophthalmology (Auckland, N.Z.) vol. 2,4 (2008): 693-702. doi:10.2147/opth.s2452

questions.text: Which of these is true about sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Injured eye is exciting eye
  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare, but serious, immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that can occur after an eye injury or surgery.
  • It is characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis, which means inflammation of the uvea (the middle layer of the eye) that is typically associated with the formation of granulomas.
  • The term "sympathetic" refers to the fact that the inflammation in the second eye occurs as a sympathetic response to the injury in the first eye.
  • Option 1: "Trauma to iris," is generally not a risk factor for sympathetic ophthalmia, indeed Trauma to Ciliary body is usually the triggering factor. Any type of eye injury or surgery can potentially trigger the immune response that leads to sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • Option 2: "Non-granulomatous uveitis," is incorrect because sympathetic ophthalmia is characterized by autoimmune granulomatous panuveitis, not non-granulomatous uveitis.
  • Option 3: "Unilateral," is incorrect because sympathetic ophthalmia always affects both eyes. This is because the immune response that causes the inflammation in the second eye is a systemic response, rather than a local response to the injury in the first eye. The inflammation can occur weeks to months after the initial injury, and it can be severe enough to cause permanent damage to the affected eye if not treated promptly.
  • Option 4: "Injured eye is exciting eye," is correct . The injured eye (exciting eye) is indeed the eye that triggers the immune response that leads to sympathetic ophthalmia, but the inflammation occurs in both eyes, not just the injured eye.


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 506.

questions.text: A young patient with progressive visual blurring in the left eye arrives at the ophthalmology outpatient clinic. Fine stellate keratotic precipitates, aqueous flare, and a characteristic complex posterior subcapsular cataract are all visible under the slit light. There were no posterior synechiae could be seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuch's.
 
  • Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. It is normally seen in middle-aged people who may complain of symptoms such as blurring of vision and persistent floaters.
  • Clinical findings are given in the table below.
  • Long-term monitoring is indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. 




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 775.

questions.text: From where can we see Recurrent mobile hypopyon in Acute Anterior Uveitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Behcets Syndrome.
 
  • Recurrent, mobile hypopyon is particularly associated with Behcet's syndrome, a multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and uveitis.
  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, forming a layer of pus-like fluid.
  • Other options - Hypopyon is common in HLA-B27-associated acute anterior uveitis. It has a high fibrin content which makes it immobile and slow to absorb.
  • In Behcet disease, there is minimal fibrin content, so the hypopyon shifts according to the patient’s head position.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 760.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of blurring of vision. On examination, you note that there are aqueous flares with numerous keratic precipitates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with blurring of vision, aqueous flare, and numerous keratic precipitates (KPs). These are classic signs of anterior uveitis, specifically iridocyclitis.

Key points:

  • Iridocyclitis involves inflammation of the iris and ciliary body.

  • Aqueous flare: Indicates protein leakage into the anterior chamber.

  • Keratic precipitates (KPs): Deposits of inflammatory cells on the corneal endothelium.

  • Symptoms: Blurred vision, photophobia, pain, and redness.

Other options:

  • Posterior uveitis: Involves retina or choroid; does not cause aqueous flare or KPs.

  • Toxoplasma uveitis: Typically presents as focal necrotizing retinochoroiditis in the posterior segment.

  • Intermediate uveitis: Involves vitreous, sometimes ciliary body; KPs are usually few or absent, and aqueous flare is mild.

Hence, the findings point to anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis).

questions.text: identify the marked structure in the eye?
questions.solution:
The marked structure represend the canal of petit
Located in front of the anterior hyaloid membrane and behind the ciliary body and zonule, the capsulohyaloid sinus (or Petit‘s canal) is a notable area for retrolentalhemorrhages. It is also a pathway through which blood can enter the lens, often following a rupture in the posterior lens capsule.
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 184 .

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital with complaints of visual disturbances. On examination, there is tron deposits in his eye. What is the most likely diagnosis behind this occular finding?
questions.solution:
Iron deposits build up in the eye, a condition known as Siderosis Bulbi that is more common in industrial workers. It usually appears two months to two years after the accident and is caused by degenerative changes in the eyes brought on by an iron foreign body. This disorder results from the metal's electrolytic dissociation, which is aided by intrinsic resting currents in the eye. The iron is dispersed and eventually combines with cellular proteins to cause atrophy.

Characteristics of the Clinic:

Iris: Originally greenish-stained, it eventually turns reddish-brown, a condition known as heterochromia iridis.

Pupil: Sphincter iron deposits can cause mydriasis.

Lens: Anterior capsular cataract is caused by radially distributed iron deposits on the anterior capsule.

Retina: Pigmentary retinopathy development is followed by retinal atrophy and
References:

1. Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana, 6th Edition, pp. 433-437

2. Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, pp. 394-395

questions.text: A patient had a compressible unilateral proptosis that worsened with forward bending. There was a neither thrill nor bruit. An enhanced retroorbital mass is visible on MRI. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, proptosis increases when bending forward, is compressible without thrill or bruit, and is seen on an orbital ultrasound as an echogenic mass. This is highly suggestive of orbital varix, a condition in which the veins in the orbit swell and become larger.
  • Symptoms may include eye bulging, constriction of vision, double vision, pain, and headaches.
  • Symptoms frequently are exacerbated by changes in head position, bending forward, or by Valsalva maneuver.
  • On MRI T1 images the varix produces a low isointense signal that typically shows marked enlargement in size with Valsalva. On T2 images flowing blood produces a dark signal void. With gadolinium, enhancement is marked, except in areas of thrombus formation where there is little or no enhancement.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1328, 1329.

questions.text: What is the most common epithelial lacrimal gland tumour?
questions.solution:
These neoplasms are generally classified into two types: epithelial and non epithelial. Non epithelial lesions are the most common, corresponding to 70-80% of solid lacrimal gland masses.
After these, lacrimal gland lymphomas are the most common, accounting for almost 37% of malignant lacrimal gland tumors .
Of the epithelial lacrimal gland tumors, 55% are benign while 45% are malignant.

The most common benign epithelial lesion in the lacrimal gland is the pleomorphic adenoma (PA, also called benign mixed tumor).

Of the malignant epithelial lesions, adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) comprises approximately 60%, with pleomorphic adenocarcinomas, primary adenocarcinomas, mucoepidermoid carcinomas, and miscellaneous tumors making up the remaining 40%.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 424.

questions.text: Inflammation with lipogranulomatous is observed in?
questions.solution:
A chalazion is a focal inflammatory lesion of the eyelid that results from the obstruction of a sebaceous gland, either meibomian or Zeis. Extravasated lipid material produces a surrounding, chronic, lipogranulomatous inflammation.
  • The proper diagnosis given by pathologists for this lesion in paraffin sections. Clear circular empty spaces presumably represent lipids that have dissolved in the organic solvents during processing.
  • The clear spaces are surrounded by nodular collections of epithelioid histiocytes. Special stains are generally performed in cases that show lipogranulomatous inflammation.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1301.

questions.text: An elderly female presented with recurrent swelling of the upper eyelid. Histopathological evaluation revealed it to be a chalazion. What would be the histopathological finding?
questions.solution:
• Chalazion is also known as meibomian or tarsal cyst.
  • It is a chronic, sterile, lipogranulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland containing sebaceous secretion. Occurs due to a chronic blockage of meibomian gland orifice and stagnation of sebaceous secretions.
  • HPE shows clear circular empty spaces presumably represent lipids that have dissolved in the organic solvents during processing.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1301.

questions.text: Phenol red thread test is used for dry eye:
questions.solution:
For Phenol red test, autoclaved, 75-mm-long phenol-red impregnated thread with 3-mm bent end was placed in lower fornix for 15 seconds. When the phenol red comes in contact with alkaline tears, it changes color from white to yellow-orange, yellow and then to red.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 279.

questions.text: An orbital blowout fracture includes:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Floor.
 
  • Blow-out orbital fractures are caused by trauma to the orbit by a large, rounded object, e.g., cricket ball, a human fist, etc. 
  • This force can cause the displacement of the eyeball backward and an increase in intra-orbital pressure. 
  • This leads to fracturing at the weakest point of the orbital wall (orbital floor and sometimes medial wall).  

Image shows Orbital blow out fracture 



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 440-442.
Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 894-897.

questions.text: When chewing, a patient with ptosis exhibits retraction of the ptotic eyelid. This points towards:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Marcus Gunn jaw winking syndrome.
 
  • Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome or Marcus Gunn phenomenon or trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis: Condition characterized by abnormal synkinesis (involuntary simultaneous movement) between the jaw and eyelid.
  • In this syndrome, when the patient opens their mouth or chews, there is an elevation or retraction of the ptotic (drooping) eyelid on the same side.
  • The abnormal synkinesis between the jaw movement and eyelid elevation occurs due to miswiring or aberrant connections between the trigeminal (jaw) and oculomotor (eyelid) nerves.
  • This results in a phenomenon where jaw movement triggers an unintended eyelid movement.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the SAFE trachoma strategy?
questions.solution:
SAFE strategy, which has been endorsed by the WHO, in an effort to avoid trachoma infections and blindness. 
  • Surgery (Tertiary prevention), 
  • Antibiotic use (Secondary prevention), 
  • Facial cleanliness/hygiene (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental changes (Primordial prevention)


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 541.

questions.text: What is the most common lacrimal gland tumor in elderly?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pleiomorphic tumour 
 
  • The most common benign lacrimal gland tumour, also known as benign mixed tumour, is most frequently found in young adult males.
     
  • The eyeball is displaced downward and inward by a slowly developing, painless swelling in the upper-outer quadrant of the orbit.
     
  • It is invasive locally and has the potential to invade its own pseudocapsule.
     
  • Histologically, it resembles a benign mixed tumour of the salivary gland as it contains pleomorphic myxomatous tissue.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 424.

questions.text: Upper lid coloboma most likely complication ?
questions.solution:
Exposure keratitis will be seen in the given condition as the patient will not be able to close eyelids.
Because the eyelid is inadequate, the cornea is constantly exposed to the environment, which can lead to exposure keratitis and subsequent bacterial infections.



Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, Page no 59, 60.

questions.text: What is the most common type of concomitant strabismus?
questions.solution:
The correct is option 2 :Exotropia

 
  • Exotropia is a type of concomitant strabismus where one or both eyes turn outward. It is the most common type of strabismus and can occur in both children and adults.
  • In exotropia, the eyes are misaligned due to a weakness or imbalance of the eye muscles that control eye movement. This can cause double vision, difficulty with depth perception, and eye strain.
  • Convergent squint, also known as esotropia, is another type of concomitant strabismus where one or both eyes turn inward. This condition is less common than exotropia.
  • Paralytic squint is a type of strabismus where the misalignment of the eyes is due to a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the eye muscles. This condition is not as common as exotropia or esotropia.
  • Therefore, based on the information above, it can be concluded that option 2, Exotropia, is the most common type of concomitant strabismus.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 364.

questions.text: What causes dextroelevation during conjugate movement?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Left inferior oblique & right superior rectus.
 
  • Dextroelevation refers to the upward and rightward movement of both eyes during conjugate movement.
  • The correct combination that causes dextroelevation is the left inferior oblique muscle and the right superior rectus muscle.
  • The left inferior oblique muscle helps in upward and leftward movement of the eye, while the right superior rectus muscle helps in rightward movement of the eye.
  • Together, the left inferior oblique and right superior rectus muscles work in a coordinated manner to produce dextroelevation during conjugate eye movement.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1194, 1200.

questions.text: What direction is the eyeball moved in by a lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Lacrimal gland situated in anterolateral area of orbital roof.
If any lacrimal gland tumor occurs the size of the gland increases which cause displacement of the eyeball in opposite direction that is inferno nasal direction



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1306.

questions.text: A patient with an upper lid chalazion that was recurring underwent a biopsy. What is the most likely histopathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Sebaceous cell carcinoma.
 
  • A chalazion is a benign, inflammatory condition characterized by a localized swelling in the eyelid caused by the obstruction of the meibomian glands.
  • A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).
  • A very small, soft, and recent chalazion only requires conservative management with hot compresses and topical antibiotic drops. Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1301.

questions.text: What do Negative Jones-1 and Jones -II Dye test indicate?
questions.solution:
Jones I test:
Differentiates partial obstruction from hypersecretion of tears.
Fluorescein 2% drops instilled into the conjunctiva.
After 5 minutes cotton tipped applicator inserted under the inferior turbinate.
Positive: Detection of fluorescein from nose means patency of the system.
Negative: No dye detected, means either partial or absolute obstruction or failure of lacrimal pump.

Jones II test:
The residual fluorescence is flushed from the conjunctival sac following an negative jones I test.
Clear saline is placed into the inferior canaliculus using syringe/cannula.
Irrigant is retrieved from nasal cavity.
Positive: Recovery of dye stained saline from the nose meaning a partial obstruction of the NLD.
Negative: Recovery of unstained saline through the nose means total obstruction of the upper drainage system or a defective lacrimal pump mechanism.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 427, 428.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1339.

questions.text: A patient had a history of penetrating trauma of the eye and a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was made. Which of the following is seen?
questions.solution:
• The most common manifestation of sympathetic ophthalmitis is panuveitis- inflammation of the whole uvea. 
 
  • It is a granulomatous panuveitis which occurs following penetrating trauma/intraocular surgery. The injured eye ( exciting eye ) and fellow eye ( sympathizing eye ) develop panuveitis. 
 
  • It is an example of type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 155, 158-161.

questions.text: Identify the condition given below in the image?
questions.solution:
• Ankyloblepharon is defined by partial or complete adhesion of the ciliary edges of superior and inferior eyelids.
  • It is usually a sporadic isolated malformation in which the upper and lower lids are joined by tags.

Other options:

  1. Symblepharon: (Option 1)

    • Refers to adhesion between the palpebral conjunctiva (inner eyelid) and the bulbar conjunctiva (eye surface).
    • Commonly caused by trauma, burns, or cicatricial diseases like Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
    • It does not involve fusion of the eyelids themselves.

  2. Blepharophimosis: (Option 3)

    • A congenital condition characterized by narrowing of the palpebral fissure (horizontal eyelid opening).
    • It does not involve eyelid fusion.

  3. Epiblepharon: (Option 4)

    • A congenital abnormality where an extra fold of skin near the eyelid margin pushes the lashes inward.
    • This condition does not involve eyelid fusion.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 393, 395.

questions.text: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month- old child. There is a history of watering and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
questions.solution:
he image depicts right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye, which is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. In a 3-month-old child, the recommended treatment includes sac massage and the application of topical antibiotics.

Key Points about Congenital Nasolacrimal Obstruction:
Spontaneous Resolution: More than 90% of patients with congenital nasolacrimal obstruction experience spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

Treatment Based on Age:
• Less than 9 Months:
Massage: Crigler's massage to increase hydrostatic pressure.
Antibiotic Eye Drops: To manage any associated infection.
• 9 Months to 4 Years:
Probing: A procedure to open the blocked duct.
• Older Children (> 4 Years):
Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): A surgical procedure that creates an opening from the lacrimal sac to the nasal cavity, providing effective drainage.
DCR generally yields the best results for older children with persistent issues.

questions.text: During a dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), which of the following bones are typically removed?
questions.solution:
Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a surgical procedure performed to bypass an obstruction in the nasolacrimal duct and create a direct drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac to the nasal cavity.

Key points:

  • The lacrimal bone forms the medial wall of the orbit and part of the nasolacrimal fossa.

  • During DCR, a portion of the lacrimal bone is removed to expose the lacrimal sac and create a new ostium into the nasal cavity.

  • Other bones:

    • Ethmoid: Not removed

    • Frontal: Not involved

    • Maxillary: Forms part of the lateral nasal wall, sometimes the frontal process of maxilla is shaved for exposure, but the primary bone removed is lacrimal

choices.text: Conjunctival congestion with follicles, papillary hyperplasia and progressive pannus

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in leprosy affecting the eyes?
questions.solution:
Leprosy can cause lagopthalmos I.e inability to close the eyelids due to environment of zygomatic branch facial nerve. Decreased corneal sensation seen in leprosy is due to the involvement of ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve.

Other features seen are:
Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
Miosis
Iris atrophy
Iris pearls
Retinal pearls.

Lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge and foreign body sensation.

Conjunctival congestion, follicles papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features of trachoma

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: In relation to which wall of the orbit is the canaliculi that opens into the lacrimal sac present?
questions.solution:
The canaliculi drain tears into the lacrimal sac, which lies in the lacrimal fossa.

  • The lacrimal fossa is formed by the lacrimal bone and frontal process of maxilla → both part of the medial wall of the orbit.



Anatomy of the Lacrimal Drainage System:
Puncta: Small openings on the eyelid margin.
Canaliculi: Each (superior and inferior) has two parts:
Vertical portion (2 mm)
Horizontal portion (8 mm)
The superior and inferior canaliculi typically merge to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac.
A small flap of mucosa called Rosenmüller's valve is present at the junction of the common canaliculus and lacrimal sac, preventing tear reflux into the canaliculi.
The lacrimal sac measures 10-12 mm in length and is located within the lacrimal fossa, separated from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity by the lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla.

The nasolacrimal duct is 12-18 mm long, running downward, backward, and laterally.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of long-standing dacrocystitis. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Chronic dacryocystitis is due to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, leading to recurrent infections of the lacrimal sac.

  • Treatment of choice: Dacrocystorhinostomy (DCR) – creates a new drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity, bypassing the obstructed nasolacrimal duct.

  • This resolves chronic infection and prevents recurrence.

Other options:

  • Syringing → Diagnostic and temporary relief; does not cure chronic obstruction.

  • Probing → Used mainly in congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants.

  • Lacrimal sac massage → Conservative management for infants; ineffective in chronic adult cases.


Reference
Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition - Page no: 431

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic mucopurulent discharge from her left eye and swelling near the medial canthus. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical Scenario:

A 55-year-old woman with:

  • Chronic mucopurulent discharge

  • Swelling at the medial canthus

This is classic for chronic dacryocystitis, most commonly due to nasolacrimal duct obstruction.

Treatment of Choice: Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

  • DCR creates a direct communication between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, bypassing the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

  • This restores normal tear drainage and resolves infection.

  • It can be done externally or endoscopically.

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • 1. Dacryocystectomy: Involves removal of the lacrimal sac; used in elderly, debilitated patients or recurrent infections where DCR is not feasible.

  • 3. Conjunctivo-cystorhinostomy: Reserved for canalicular obstructions or after failed DCR.

  • 4. Balloon catheter dilation: Preferred in children or early cases; not effective in chronic adult cases with long-standing obstruction.


Reference:Kanski's clinical opthalmology A systematic approach 8e page no 75

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelid margin, most commonly affecting the lower lid. It causes the eyelashes to rub against the globe (as shown in the image), leading to irritation.

Causes include:

  • Horizontal lid laxity

  • Vertical lid instability

  • Preseptal orbicularis overriding the pretarsal part during lid closure

  • Orbital septum laxity

Ectropion, in contrast, is the outward turning of the eyelid margin.

Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid, which may partially or completely cover the pupil, affecting vision and appearance.

Trichiasis refers to misdirected eyelashes that turn inward and rub against the eye, even though the eyelid position remains normal.


Reference: Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page no 406

questions.text: Pick the one that is used as a self tonometer.
questions.solution:
Rebound tonometer can be used as a self tonometer, without the application of topical anesthetic.
Patients/ Caregiver can take accurate IOP measurements at home using Icare Rebound tonometry
Advantages of Rebound tonometer are:
  • Portable
  • Easy to use
  • No anesthesia required
  • Patient comfort
  • Disposable probes


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1026, 1108.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about direct ophthalmoscopy?
questions.solution:
Magnification is direct ophthalmoscopy is 15 times. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, magnification is 4-5 times.

Other features of Direct Ophthalmoscopy:
  • Battery operated, hand-held, Self-illuminated device 
  • Done in sitting posture
  • Mainly used to see central retina (posterior pole of retina upto the equator)
  • 2DD of central retina visible
  • Image formed is virtual, erect and magnified
  • About 15X magnification 


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text: The following tool is utilized for indirect ophthalmoscopy and is depicted in the figure. What magnification should be used along with it to see the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 2: +20D.

The instrument shown in the image is used for indirect ophthalmoscopy.
The principle of this procedure is to make the eye highly myopic. Light is transmitted from the headset to the fundus through a condensing lens held at the focal point of the eye, providing an inverted image that is observed through a stereoscopic viewing system.
A convex lens is used, commonly +20D.
The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified.
It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions.





Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 113, 548.

questions.text: What do you call a tonometer that has a variable application surface?
questions.solution:
The tonometer with variation in application surface is Maklakov tonometer.

In the Maklakov tonometer- a known force is applied to the eye, and the area of applanation is measured - a technique known as constant- force rather than constant-area applanation.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1026.
Yilmaz, Ihsan et al. “Comparison of three methods of tonometry in normal subjects: Goldmann applanation tonometer, non-contact airpuff tonometer, and Tono-Pen XL.” Clinical ophthalmology (Auckland, N.Z.) vol. 8 1069-74. 7 Jun. 2014, doi:10.2147/opth.s6391

questions.text: How much is the image magnified when using a direct ophthalmoscope?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 15 times.
 
  • When using a direct ophthalmoscope, the image of the fundus is magnified approximately 15 times.
  • This magnification enables a closer examination of the internal structures of the eye, such as the retina, blood vessels, and optic nerve.
  • A magnification of approximately 15 times provides a clear and detailed view, aiding in the diagnosis and assessment of various eye conditions.
Direct Ophthalmoscopy:
  • The most commonly practiced method for routine fundus examination.
  • Direct ophthalmoscopy should be performed in a semi-darkroom and the patient's right eye should be examined by the right eye of the observer and the patient's left eye with the observer's left eye.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument below.
questions.solution:
Hertel's exophthalmometer is the most common instrument used to measure Proptosis.
Advantage is it measures both eyes simultaneously.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No: 420- 422.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Lim's Forceps:
Lim's forceps are specialized surgical instruments used primarily in ophthalmic procedures.
They feature fine tips and a delicate grip, designed for precise manipulation of delicate ocular tissues.
Function:
Ideal for handling tissues during eye surgeries, ensuring minimal trauma to the surrounding areas.
Other Ophthalmic Instruments:
• McPherson Suture Tying Forceps:
Commonly used in ophthalmic surgery for grasping and tying sutures.
Characterized by a fine, curved tip that allows for precise manipulation in intricate surgical environments, such as during cataract surgery.
These instruments are crucial for ensuring accuracy and safety in ophthalmic procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement is crucial for diagnosing and monitoring glaucoma.

Key points:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer (GAT):

    • Considered the gold standard for IOP measurement.

    • Based on Imbert-Fick principle, measuring the force required to flatten a constant corneal area.

    • Provides accurate and reproducible readings in clinical practice.

  • Other devices:

    • Tonopen: Portable, useful in children or uncooperative patients, less accurate than GAT.

    • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: Measures proptosis, not IOP.

    • Gonioscope: Examines anterior chamber angle, not IOP.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chalazion clamp.
Chalazion clamp has a distal tip with flat oval plate; other side has a ring-like structure and forceps-like handle. Handle has a thumbscrew, which can be tightened and released so as to achieve the required pressure.

Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 7th edition • Page no: 625, 621, 624

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows KERRISON'S PUNCH

  • Type: Bone punch forceps

  • Function: Removes small bony fragments, especially thin bones like the lacrimal bone or parts of the nasal bone.

  • Commonly Used In:

    • External or endoscopic DCR – to remove lacrimal bone and create a bony ostium.

    • Neurosurgery – spine decompression procedures.

    • ENT surgeries – for removing small pieces of bone in the nasal cavity.

      In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR):

  • The Kerrison punch is used to remove part of the lacrimal bone to create a direct communication between the lacrimal sac and the nasal mucosa, bypassing the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

  • This ensures proper tear drainage into the nasal cavity.


Reference: Comprehension opthalmology by AK khurana 6th edition page no 603,602,600
